content:
Posted: January 27, 2014
												Deus EX: Human Revolution.Hmm.How do i even begin this?From the start, i was interested in the game. Hell, even the name has a certain ring to it that makes it sound so imposing.I immediately fell in-love with the story. I love how you have choices about how you'd go about your mission, choices about Adam's augmentations, choices about what weaponry you carry with you and what upgrades you put in it, and choices about what to say.I loved how even with all the augmentations you have, you'd still be vulnerable and mortal.I loved how the Side missions unfolded, i loved the not so hidden pieces of lore and secret areas where you find free praxis kits and of course the END of it all.It accomplishes what it set out to do in my opinion. Tell a gripping story, engage the player and show me what being human truly means when you are now thrust into a world where man becomes half machine. A vision of what might be in the far future and a sort of warning to those with the intellect to make augmentations in the future. Traditional morality and humanity fight a seemingly hopeless battle against the lust for power and the darker side of technological advancement. Absolutely gripping.I have some qualms about it though:-The citizens don't seem to feel believeable, its like they're generic NPC's. This disappointed me because of all the technological advances in gaming, they could not make it feel like i was in a techno centric world filled with interesting randomly generated NPC's.-I keep hearing about harvesters in-game. They apparently take augmentations from people and sell them, literally ripping and harvesting them off people. IT WOULD HAVE BEEN SO EPIC TO FIND AND FIGHT OFF HARVESTERS.Something like "The more you get aug'd the more they'd come after you" kind of thing.-For an augmented person, Adam Jensen's movements were quite stiff. Minor issue but an issue nonetheless.-I feel that this would have been great if you could choose to shift between third person and first person view. WAIT. Hear me out. I know the deus ex games have always been FPS games. Sure. But look at Fallout 3 and New Vegas, the ability to choose makes a lot of difference. I'm the kind of guy who likes to see his character do some cool♥♥♥♥♥♥and sometimes i'm in the mood to see it in first person so i feel truly immersed. To each his own but yeah you get the point.All in all, this game is something you must play. Period.Damn, if you feel like the price is steep, wait for the sales. But the Devs deserve the money so buy it even if it isn't on sale.I give this game a solid 9.5/10. If this game was a chick, i'd totally bang her.In all seriousness, get the game, play it, play it again afterwards. and again and again and again.And again and again and again until augmentations become available to the general populace and then you get to live the game.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												Deus Ex Human Revolution is a brilliant yet flawed game. A game that I love for a multitude of reasons. But as per usual, I want to quickly place a little disclaimer for those planning to buy this game with a LOW-END PC. You'll be able to run this game perfectly well with no issues. Maybe 720p or hell, native resolutions. My old laptop didn't pass the minimum requirements (it had a 1.8GHz Dual Core CPU) and it ran the game with 30FPS at it's native resolution (1366x768) with minor slowdowns at times. But the game is well optimized and not really a bother in that department so don't worry about that. Now. Let's get into the meat of this review. Deus Ex Human Revolution is the prequel to 2000's Deus Ex. There were no other sequels (Don't mention the Fall or Invisible War, they don't count in my book) and it plays out the story of Adam Jensen. A former SWAT member that got ''kicked'' out of the team for taking part in the Mexican Town Massacre. This leads to Adam becoming the head of Security at Sarif Industries. Recommended to David Sarif by his ex-girlfriend, Megan Reed. I'm not going to spoil much of the story as the game's story is a brilliantly crafted experience.  The gameplay It works and is easier to understand than 2000's Deus Ex in my opinion, but then again, I'm an idiot and took me a while to understand Deus Ex (2000)'s UI. The gameplay has been a bit simplified but the enemy AI is quite dumb at times but are accurate. There is infact Health Regeneration (which is meh in my opinion when it is done wrong which means that you're basically immortal), but it only heals you after a battle so you don't worry about running around looking for Medpacks, but that means that Devs can skimp over the level and not have to bother with Health Packs. The gameplay let's you do the usual ''Play it your way'' that most Stealth games let you. I'm calling this a stealth game as the game rewards you more for stealth rather than the original rewarding you equally for any sort of playstyle. The controls feel quite fluid in my opinion as it worked well. At first it was a bit awkward but then it became easier for me to play and was easier to see why they chose the default keymappings as they were. I also recommend having a 5-button (or more buttons) mouse due to the fact that the Augs themselves are mapped to F1-F4 like the original, but at times, it's easier to just press a sidebutton on your mouse to activate the Stealth Cloak Augmentation or the Smart Vision Augmentation. The Audio The OST itself is a brilliant one with tracks that consistently fit the mood of the area or situation you're in. The main menu track itself is a beautiful one that brings joy to me each time I boot up the game. The opening theme itself, named ''Icarus'' is amazing to listen to in both in game and outside the game.Either way: The OST is lovely and awesome. That's always a plus in my opinion.  Enviroments and Levels The game will often recycle areas but for reasons within the story, you'll go to Detroit and Hengsha twice. But that doesn't mean that the game is just being cheap and making it seem awkward. It's just reusing the same areas but with some sort of reasoning within the story and has some new areas to explore or new side missions to play around with, or even a new bunch of characters or existing characters that have new interactions with for your past actions.The enviroments seem realistic and yet futuristic. Most areas have atleast two or three ways of traversing around or fighting your enemies. The thing I hate about the areas and gameplay is that you can camp in the vents and just pick off the enemies one by one which makes it a giant camp fest if you're not bothered to try thinking to defeeat your enemies. Well, in my personal opinion, you should most definitely play this title for all the positives. And the Boss Battles are reimagined so they're not giant turds like they were in the original version of this game.. BUT this game has more glitches. (none that I encountered but some others have)

content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												Played this game on release back on 2011, and I must say first things first, it has visually aged quite poorly for the most part, unfortunately, especially when i remember being absolutely blown away first time playing it. The director's cut version of this game provides the extended DLC called the Missing Link that was I believe to be a separate game (typical transaction bs from publishers). REMINDER: THE DLC PLAYS IN CONJUNCTION WITH THE MAIN STORY, IT IS UNMISSABLE, so don't worry about somehow skipping it.Human Revolution is a game about politics, philosophical questions on what makes us human, and throwing vending machines at people. It is also set in the Year 2027, which from playing the game, it seems they probably shoulda pushed the years quite a bit further into the future, because we are FAR from reaching this point in technological evolution.The game's story, characters, and development throughout is refreshing, and the atmosphere put down on the table is one of a futuristic Renaissance-esque type, floral patterns and colouring indicating a style they were going for. Quite different from the original Deus Ex's straight up cyberpunk atmosphere. The change, while making it more mono coloured, is a very unique one, giving it a very distinct feeling.The soundtrack also deserves a special mention because it truly encapsulates the feeling of Deus Ex on a whole, providing an epic score of emotional but revolutionary sounding music, blending a mixture of the old and new.The gameplay itself is one of great variation, and like many stealth games on the market, like Dishonored and MGS, the game provides whatever playstyle you want to go for, whether it is guns blazing, stealth approach making little noise, strongman which can jump 3 metres in the air (no I didn't make that up). The best part of this is, unlike other games, where the options are available but are gimmicky, and provide no real advantage over just doing the same thing over and over, is that EVERY playstyle is important. playing non lethal and stealth will punish you in some aspects, along with rewarding in others, so preferring to one playstyle will make it more difficult on the player in certain areas, and vice versa.It really feels like the developers wanted to balance out the augmentions (essentially your character's skill trees) to make it feel like you werent some overpowered player, unlike certain games like Dishonored, where you become some one man army. Careful preparation and strategy is rewarded in the long run, and can also affect the game's AMAZING variation in speech in dialogue based on decisions and choices, along with your own playstyles. characters in game will react differently to your different playstyles, while one person may like your upfront "kill all" playstyle, another character may take interest in your "stealthy infiltration" playstyle. The game makes replayability a joy, just like the first game in the series.I didn't wish to discuss the story, because while it is incredibly good and engaging overall, it is best that the player unravels it himself, and like I said, you carve your own path based on decisions, so most people's storylines will vary.Overall, a game of incredible depth and enjoyment, a close call to its ancestor in the series, and shows what developers can do when they are creative.Here's hoping to a successful and wonderful sequel, Deus Ex: Mankind Divided.

content:
Posted: July 29, 2015
												A little review on a big game!Graphics: Everything looks like it's been drawn using oil paint. It is cool, but gold-brown colors nearly everywhere make game look the same other and other again. At least, you will not hurt your eyes. [8/10]Gameplay: You can complete the game without killing anyone (except for bosses) ... WITHOUT KILLING ANYONE, CARL!. Or, you can go gunz'blazing  and kill every single person in a game, even civilians, they won't do a damn thing xD. Lots of augmentations which will enhance your gaming experience and will give the game higher replayability chance. Also, choices you make really affect gameplay. You might get a few codes from the guy you saved or get a few achievements :P. Maps are big, you can explore them to find new paths to your target. [10/10]Music: "It's a ♥♥♥♥ing Miracle!" [11/10]Story: Once upon a time, a guy was thrown through the bulletproof glass and got shot in the head... He barely survives the accident and is supposed to find the group who nearly took his life and took his friends. Game has a high replayability due to tons of choices and approaches you can make. [10/10]Difficulty: Well, it's not that hard to complete the game on it's hardest from your first try, AI is not as smart as it could have been. You can just run'n'gun everyone easily or stealth through the whole game. (Dev's shoud have added: "I never asked for this" difficulty :3 ) [8/10]Verdict: "I ALWAYS ASKED FOR THIS!", Freaking awesome re-boot, totally a must-have.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2016
												So I finished my first playthrough today. I learnt about this game a long time ago, shortly before it's release in a gaming magazine review. I was impressed by what I saw, so it's stayed in the back of my mind until recently.I don't consider myself the master of stealth in any way. This game, like all the Deus exs so far, is centred around Stealth; but it's much more than that. It allows you to be resourceful, persuasive, and is an overall immersive experience, I actually felt like I was a special op agent the entire time.Story: 9/10; The story is great, and I could follow it with rich enthusiasm. I thought it would be predictable, but it wasn't, and was actually emotionally moving/confronting at times. There's a lot to follow, but if you're patient, the story will be quite a fulfiling experience. Several elements of the game broke proffesionalism/realism, and therefore immersion, but it's forgivable.Gameplay: 10/10; the stealth approach wasn't a chore, the combat controls are great, the large selection of weapons and gadgets is nice, and the ability to combine brains and brawn is a welcome change.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												!!! DEUS EX !!!Fortunately, the massive hype surrounding 2011’s “Deus Ex: Human Revolution” was matched by an equally outstanding game. With its beautifully-realized cyberpunk world; stealth gameplay that rivaled top-shelf espionage titles; enough conspiracy theories to shake a tin foil hat at; and, best of all, its return to the “play how you want” formula that made the first game so good, “Human Revolution” was a success.  Despite its brilliance, “Human Revolution” was far from perfect, bogged down by unfairly difficult boss battles that were skewed towards specific play styles, the occasional bland texture, and sometimes wonky enemy A.I. The Updated Version of this game "Director's Cut" has solved these problems and polished the game so much more.The main complaint of the game, to date, is its color choice while looking through Adam Jensen's augmented visor. A hew of yellow coats the screen. Acourse this can easily be solved with any one of the many many graphic mods for this game revealing it's true colors. The color choice, for me, was never an issue. With its flowing, open approach to mission structure, thoroughly engrossing story and gorgeous visuals, this is the kind of game that all others should strive to be. While there are some elements that don't feel quite as developed as they should have been, and augmentation is more Hobson's choice than true choice, Human Revolution provides a level of quality that only the most adamant cynic could fail to be impressed by. More importantly, it is everything a fan of Deus Ex could want in a game.I highly recommend this game to anyone who loves Si-fi worlds and rpg based games. A "Must Play" game for sure. - XeroSyphon

content:
Posted: September 6, 2014
												Games commonly offer you a choice in whether you want to be good or bad. To go guns a blazing or to be a ghost seen by none. Often the way it is done is so obvious that the illusion of choice is broken. This is where this game shines. I was able to play the way I wanted to throughout. If I wanted to sneak around and crawl through grates to get through to the room I wanted I could. If I wanted to speak to someone and convince them to let me in, more often than not, I could. If I wanted to hack the door to let me in undetected I could. Those are only some of the ways that the developers  employ  in progressing through the game. There are some drawbacks however. During the bossfights you would have to exercise some sort of violence against your enemies. Otherwise, this game was a lot of fun. It wasn't just a polarizing good or bad story line but it felt like I could really choose my own path in this cyber punk world. This inlcludes the leveling system. No matter which way you go you'll find that there is no bad power. Although it's old, I'm glad I gave it a chance.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												A wonderful game. Deus Ex: Human Revolution is a FPS RPG set in the future where cybernetic augmentations have created a rift between the people in society who can afford them and those who can't. You play as Adam Jensen, a bad♥♥♥♥♥Pros:+ Level design(except bosses): Human Revolution's levels and maps are ridiculously flexible, as there are hundreds of ways to go through the levels. You can sneak past everyone, not harming a soul, or leap in, guns blazing. I've seen a video on Youtube where someone went through the whole game with nothing but a box as a weapon, throwing it to deal damage.+ DLC: The DLC is integrated into the game - I didn't even realize it wasn't part of the regular game.+ Gameplay: There are many kinds of guns and many mods for those guns, which allows you to supplement your chosen playstyle with your preferred weapon(s). You are also offered "augmentations", or, in other terms, a skill tree. These can significantly affect playstyle, as you can leap higher or take no fall damage, punch or see through walls, shoot rockets, take less damage, etc. There are also parts of the game where you talk to people. These scenes are relatively fluid, as you choose your dialogue options in an attempt to persuade or interrogate. It is very similar to an actual, real life conversation.+ Story: Your typical action-packed conspiracy theory rich Deus Ex story.Cons:- Uneven FPS(maybe just my problem)- The graphic aren't very good, but the cutscenes look nice.- Boss battles: "Boss" battles are a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥ as it forces you to go "guns blazing" playstyle and feels out of place.I can add more to this list, but that would be nitpicking an otherwise solid game.I rate this game 7.25/10 - recommended to just about anybody.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												Played the original human revolution. This game got me immediatly due to the theme. I like the conspiracy concept with the near-futuristic slightly possible technological advancement.The added missing link will boost the playtime, however, after completing the original within 30 hours, I was a bit shocked by the ease of difficulty imho. Maybe this is due to me playing Deus Ex 1 a lot ;). I should note that i didn't do all the side missions, not looked for all the books.The biggest downer after playing 20 hours or so is seeing 2 hub districts and realising these are the only 2. Though I did not expect anything, I was hoping for a larger plot, and maybe 1 more hub city. The missing link, nor the directors cut don't feature a new hub city, though there was mention of it during development.All in all, I'd recommend this game due to theme, game franchise done right and gameplay. The story is ok, a bit short in my humble opinion. The difficulty could've had 1 more mode (the 'do not sound any alarm achievement' was easily achievable) where the AI would shine more.

Posted: April 5, 2014
												It's a masterpiece in my view. I always want to play it over and over again. Sometimes the enemies can be stupid enough to don't see you while in direct eye contact but it's a game I can't judge it. It gives you multiple choices. Like kill or spare and go slient or loud. You always have to choose the sensible choice depens on your situation. You play as an ex-SWAT Adam Jansen. The whole game connects to you because you are special. I am not giving any spoilers so find out yourself. But sometimes it can be confusing because there is so much detail and miscellaneous things. You should focus on the main problem and the main story. Of course there is side quests which give more experince points and some information about the main quest but you don't have to do those in order to complete the game. With "Director's Cut" version "Missing Link" DLC comes along with the game. There is a lot of weapon selection and weapon setups. Silencer, laser targeting etc. You will definetly enjoy this game. And don't forget to check "Praxis Kit Locations" on the Steam Forum because you are going to need it. :)

content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
												[Small Spoilers]Deus Ex: Human Revolution - Director's Cut is a solid first person action/stealth game set in a wonderful, cyberpunk future. You play as Adam Jensen, an ex-swat member, who now is the lead security at a massive biotech company. After an accident at the facility, you became badly wounded. Thanks to the power of "augmentatioins" you were rebuilt, and now possess many possible enhancements to help better your stealth, combat, and various other things. You're tasked with finding out what actually happened the day of the attack, why it happened, and who is behind it. For my playthough I mainly focused on stealth. Other than boss fights, which even after being enhanced in the Director's Cut are still dull, I did not have kill a single individual (which I really like). Exploration, things like finding hidden air vents to crawl through, hacking doors, and hacking into computers, are really satisfying and help set the atmospehere. I encountered a glitch late game that didn't let me progress, but other than that I found few bugs. Deus Ex: Human Revolution - Director's Cut is a soild game. I highly recomend it, especially if you're a fan of steath. Gameplay: 9/10 (Focusing primarly on stealth, not gunplay)World Design: 7/10 (The "hubs" are made of many different levels, because of this it can sometimes be confusing on where exactly you're susposed to go.)Graphics: 7/10Voice-Acting: 7/10 (The main characters are voiced very well, but some of the minior characters are absolutly horrible.)Overall: 7.5/10

content:
Posted: December 27, 2014
												Human Revolution is an awesome game. It took me a while to get into the dark scenario and to be honest, I didn't do much exploration. The story however is okay and the gameplay, especially when playing stealthy, is just awesome. The controls (i used keyboard and mouse) where smooth and did what I wanted in the very most cases. This makes sneaking around and even waiting and observing fun while keeping it a challenge at the same time.The story feels a bit generic but has quite a few surprising moments and decent characters. There could've been more though and especially the end is disappointing. Since your previous descisions don't really play a role for the ending sequence you'll see, there is practically no re-play value to it. So you'll get some 20 hours of really nice gameplay with a motivating story. Since the game is utterly cheap these days i certainly recommend it to anyone who does not absolutely hate anything first person.

Posted: February 27, 2014
												Deus Ex: Human Revolution - Director's Cut is an amazing game with all of it's weaknesses fixed. Terrible bossfights used to be it's downside but now it's completelly rewamped and allows you to kill bosses with bit more of variety. If you wonder whenever you should buy this game or or not I'd say it's worth full price. It's well written, well executed game which will make you play it more than once. You may play how you please (rambo mode or ghost), but I find it more challenging and fun to play as hacker/ghost type since you heavily rely on stealth. You play as Adam Jensen ex-swat who got augments against his will and is pretty conflicted whenever he speaks to somebody about it. As much as he tries to look like a victim his augments makes him BAMF. Anyway after accident in which his girlfriend died he tries to live on as an augmented person. 6 months after he got augmented he got a call from his boss asking for Adam's help. And so your journey starts to find who's responsible for an incident in which Adam's girlfriend presumably died and destroyed her research and why terrorists wanted to take out Sarrif Industries out of augment bussiness.Overall good game, finished it 4 times and enjoyed it 8/10.

content:
Posted: March 25, 2015
												pros: multiple conversation choices, main story has a ton of content (can be a bit convoluted, full of plot twists & conspiracies), side quests are interesting to do, many interesting characters (except pritchard), multiple routes to approach an objective, multiple endings, a lot of objects in the world are interactable & plenty of things to hack, hacking mini game is a mix of skill & luck, expansive quest hubs, multiple skill upgrades & weapon selection (lethal & non-lethal), epic soundtrack, director's cut offers extras on the main menucons: frame rate drops especially when loading map sections, clunky movement & controls, graphical glitches & instability (ive experienced several crashes), I couldn't complete a quest because the npc bugged out (I had to leave the instance & return so the npc could reset), im supposedly augmented but I can't sprint longer than 2 seconds, awkward animation every time you do a melee takedown, map display is unhelpful especially when trying to navigate higher & lower levels, a lot of missions have you backtrack through long distances, low res skyboxes, boss battles are tedious & uninteresting, terrible execution of the final game objectiveOverall, this game is a complete rpg/fps experience with 20+ hours of content to offer. I suggest trying to hack as much as possible to gain all the bonuses. Eidos Montreal can't for the life of them create a map display that is easy to understand & navigate, they should outsource mapping to a different studio imo. This game to me was a worthwhile experience from start to finish, which I never asked for this.Deus Ex: Human Revolution - Directors Cut has my recommendation.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2014
												Deus ex: Human Revolution is an amazing dark and gritty FPS set in the dystopian future of 2022 where humans are divided on how they feel about the new augmentation technology. Augmentations allow humans to rise above their limitations by being able to do things such as react quicker, run faster, or jump higher among many other things. The story focuses on an ex-swat turned private security director, Adam Jensen, for Sarif Industries, a major biotech corporation. Because of a discovery that was made at Sarif Industries a team of highly augmented mercenaries attacked their headquarters and killed the team responsible for the discovery making sure that it would never reach the light of day severely injuring Adam. As a result of his injuries Adam had to be heavily augmented against his will to keep him alive. With his new found abilities it is up to Adam to track down those responsible for the deaths of the scientists and to find out the truth about what really happened that day. The player has the ability to choose how Adam goes about a situation being able to choose between dealing with enemies passively or lethally which changes the way characters address him. With multiple endings the game offers many choices for the player to make that affects the story. Overall, the game poses a question that can be applied to science even today a decade before the game takes place which is should humans play god and it is up to the play to choose where they stand for themselves based on what they see throughout the game.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2015
												DE:HR is a fantastic experience with enjoyable writing and acting, mature themes and some of the coolest art direction I’ve seen. My main disappointment is how it motivates you to play in a very narrow way (a certain stealth approach); rendering all of the cool gadgets you collect null. I’ll explain later.The game throws you right into the middle of things, and you need to pay attention to understand who’s who and what’s what. There’s no slow prologue telling how the world came to be in the state it is and how you find yourself there. It's something I like, because it helps establish this sense of realism that sticks throughout the entire game - that this is an actual world, not dependent on your existence to continue moving. You are part of it, not the center of it. Still, I’ll help you with the basic orientation.You’re Adam Jensen, former SWAT and currently chief of security at a biotech company, that is at the forefront of human augmentation (mechanical upgrades to humans) research and development. You are an existing and set character, not a blank slate, so the choices you make are limited to what is reasonable for Adam to do. Many people enjoy creating their characters out of scratch. This is not that kind of game. Personally, I prefer this format. It’s a fine balance that offers some amount of input, but not too much to the point that it sacrifices the depth of the story just to give you more choices that end up being shallow. Speaking of which, the consequences of your decisions are also pleasantly felt later on. I didn't find them to be too drastic, but the small nods were satisfying nevertheless.Augmentation is the main topic the world is embroiled in at 2027, and the debate about its pros and cons extends to ethical, political, economical and social aspects. It’s a nice take on sci-fi that manages to keep things still relatively grounded and credible, while also enjoying some creative liberties where the developers wanted to emphasize the subject. Suspension of disbelief is required in some places more than others, but overall the game manages to sell a believable, alternate world. And it’s a bleak one. Earth is in the midst of a cyber renaissance, but once you move away from the socialites to the streets and alleyways, you will feel an atmosphere that is opposite from the optimistic aura of revolution that is present among the upper class. The change the world is going through isn’t embraced by all, doesn’t grace all, and there is an obvious tension in the air. The title of the next game is Mankind Divided, but the hints and seeds of that segregation are already found here.The progression through levels is linear. While you revisit some of them, they’re in a changed state, and you can never go back to a level you’ve finished. They’re divided into the regular hub areas you know from most RPGs – open areas for your exploration to restock, talk with people, do side quests, etc – and the hostile levels that are much more fight or stealth oriented. Less talk, more action.Augmentations are the source of your abilities, and they’re varied enough to make leveling up an exciting occurrence. DE:HR isn't plagued by endless passive upgrades (e.g. 4% damage increase) that leave you with nothing to look forward to. You have plenty of enhancements that are new abilities, which allow you to do things you couldn’t previously achieve. There’s an interesting dialogue system that triggers with certain, important NPCs. One augmentation helps you better analyze these key figures to find the correct answer. Hacking is everywhere, and the mini-game that seems confusing at first turns out to be simple and fun. You can choose to jump higher to reach new areas, punch through weak walls or move heavy objects to open additional routes. And on the RPG note, you even have an old-school inventory system that forces you to choose what to take and what to ditch. Weapons or stealth equipment? You can't have everything.All these abilities and gadgets have their uses thanks to great level design. Stealth games can be compared to puzzles, and each room in DE:HR has multiple solutions to it. You can crawl through vents around your enemies, hack into the security system and turn turrets or robots against them, move huge crates that offer you a shortcut or jump up high to snipe them. You also have some cool tactical augmentations that make things easier and allow you to better plan or execute your actions. You can see through walls, turn invisible or run silently without alerting enemies. It’s all very fun, and part of the reason for my inflated play time – other than just enjoying the stroll slowly and taking in all the details of this beautifully crafted world (or, uh, alt-tabbing) – is because I always wanted to explore each region to its fullest after I cleared it of enemies, in order to see all the alternate routes I didn’t utilize.You can also just shoot your way through, but here is my main complaint about the game, and it’s a fairly big one. DE:HR, strangely, offers you a huge array of tools, from lethal to non-lethal, loud or silent, but doesn’t encourage their use. You can silently kill people with your crossbow, loudly blast them with a rocket launcher, tranquilize them, stun them, throw grenades, set mines, use robots, or just engage in massive gunfights with several fun options in weaponry. And while the fighting mechanics aren’t top of the end, from what I toyed around with, they’re still fun. On the hardest difficulty you die very quickly if you’re reckless, but your enemies aren’t bullet sponges, either – and that makes for intense battles. The problem with all of this is that DE:HR rewards an extremely specific game style. It’s not even that it’s just stealth – it’s stealth takedowns (melee). Meaning that even all your stealth equipment might go unused.If you don’t care about min-maxing, this won’t matter to you. But I have this suspicion that most gamers do want to unlock more powers, and when you get 10 XP for shooting down an enemy from afar, or 50 for taking them down in a non-lethal manner from up close, I imagine you’ll be inclined to do the latter. That 50 piles up in the long run. You also get bonuses at the end of the mission, depending on whether or not you were spotted, and whether an alarm was raised. Together, these bonuses amount to a huge sum that you’ll never enjoy in an aggressive approach, since it doesn’t offer some alternate reward for different achievements. This also caused me to quick-load over and over, since letting things develop dynamically felt more like a punishment. By the end of the game, a non-lethal, melee takedown playstyle will end up rewarding the player significantly more, mechanically, but will also become very repetitive. It’s disappointing that the game offers so many fun instruments, but motivates you with its XP distribution to use one single function alone throughout the entire playthrough. There’s an NG+ option in the director’s cut, and I might do a second run sometime in the future with my developed build, so I can enjoy fighting my enemies guilt-free and without that fear of missing out. But for a single playthrough, it ends up feeling like wasted potential. The gameplay offers you many options but draws a thick, red circle around a very specific one with a big smiley above it.It’s a major complaint from my perspective, but regardless, as a whole, the experience remains terrific. For anyone interested in a stealth-oriented game with a mature and interesting story and awesome setting, DE:HR is highly recommended. For those who want a sci-fi action game, you can find it here too, albeit discriminated against. You need to approach it with a mentality that doesn’t fret about receiving the bare minimum XP.

												Deus Ex:  Human Revolution does justice to the original.  With the augmentation system, you can approach every obstacle in multiple ways. number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2014
[This an elaborate/analytical review not only from the perspective of Deus Ex 1, but also from a die hard fan of the original since the years it was made. If you haven't played DX1, don't read the following - just buy Human Revolution, you'll absolutely love it]Seems like Eidos Montreal decided they could never equal or better the first game, and given the colossal mess that was DX2, they made DX3 a tribute to the first, instead of an independent prequel. The number of similarities to DX1 are overwhelming, and so many elements are copy-pasted that as a die-hard DX1 fan, it makes for a bittersweet experience; it's a reminiscent mashup of things most people love: DX1 + Batman + or other games, yet it lacks depth and originality.Deus ExAdam Jenson from DX3 and JC Denton from DX1. Same syllables in name. If that sounds like a silly similarity, relax, I'm just easing you in. The list is endless: [spoilers] being captured, getting set free by an anonymous hacker, your pilot's chopper gets blown but you had a chance to prevent that fate, ladies-restroom scene, identical ending choices; Illuminati; Dark Age; "Merge and Rule," conspiracy theories, Francis - your hacker colleague. Even the so called "Purity First" group look like a graphically enhanced version of NSF personnel BatmanThe original DX3 was orange/gold bearing a stark resemblance to the general theme of the movie The Dark Knight. They sort of went overboard with that, but after backlash from critics and players, ended up normalizing it in the Director's Cut edition. If you pay close attention to the Detroit music, there is that famous intro theme to Batman TAS, which I'm surprised they would throw in there and expect to get away with it. Moreover, a lot of people have even commented that Adam Jenson talks like Batman.ProsThe hacking mini-game is a terrific change, Typhoon augmentation, tons of "easter eggs," holstering your weapon, overall the music is very cinematic and atmospheric, with cultural influences too such as the zhong-hu instrument in "Hengsha LIMB Clinic", and vending machines are finally made useful, environments are much more "fuller" than doors/vents on an empty canvass like in the original Deus Ex, different ammo takes up inventory space (instead of one kind of ammo for everything), which is realistic. There is still a lot of detail in the world, which is great as it makes the world immersive. Critical conversations actually require you to listen to the other person, analyze their personality, and at times even their body language, which is brilliant.ConsBut 13 years have passed since DX1 and the AI still says, "huh, what? nevermind I'm hearing things" after you drop something in front of their face and successfully hide. This AI mechanic was revolutionary when it was introduced in Thief but games haven't built upon that. I threw 5 cartons on top of several open cubicles at a police station and everyone only said, "what was that?" and got "suspicious." This even goes for sound. Takedowns don't alert an enemy standing 2 feet away, even when the person you're taking down lets out a muffled squeal. I felt that was weak. Any alarmed state can be nullified if you simply "walk away" from the scene, which is so manipulative it becomes unfun, and I think is an element largely influenced from the batman games. Of all the games whose AI they imitated, if only they would have sampled Metal Gear Solid; once there is a state of alarm it never reduces back to normalcy.DX1 broke boundaries, and was The actual "revolution" in the gaming world. DX3 is just a revision of the first, and a safe recipe of things that all gamers would love. It's unfortunate that Warren Spector was excised from the DX3 project by Eidos Montreal. Silly how the world works, doesn't it? He made a mind-blowing blockbuster of a game (DX1), but DX2 fell short of that standard, therefore he was boycotted. Cruel, given that he was the main brain behind this whole series, how could you leave such a man out completely? If DX3 has a 9/10 rating for you, then relatively DX1 should be 11/10. Eidos played it safe when making this prequel, and I guess you can't blame them. Not everyone can improve on perfection, but many can merely honor or mimic it, which is what they've resorted to.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2015
												EDIT: I have beaten this game 2 times, one of which I didn't kill a single person or set off any alarms.Deus Ex: Human Revolution is one of the most amazing RPG games I've ever played. An interesting story, amazing gameplay with multiple paths to your objective, and some of the best voice acting I've ever heard make Deus Ex a "revolutionary" approach to FPS RPG games. The story is absolutely amazing, that always keeps you interested throughout it's main course. With so many twists and turns it's hard to tell who's good and who's bad. Not only that, the voice acting in this game is superb, with real emotion pouring through every line. Gameplay is so varied, you could play this game 4 times and get a different way to every level and different ending every damn time. The graphics are OK at best, but who the hell cares when you have this deep of a game. 9/10

content:
Posted: September 17, 2014
												To me Deus Ex: Human Revolution is an absolutely brilliant and astonishing cyber-punk. The environment of the game is simply fantastic: beautiful cities, locations that you want to explore, characters you want to talk to and quests that can be completed in so many ways that the game requires at least 3 playthrough to see all possible scenarios. In this game a traditional RPG and a linear shooter are so intensely mixed giving the impression of a whole different game genre. I can’t compare the visual aspect of the “Directors cut” with the original since I never saw the original. But, in conclusion: 20 out of 10! There is nothing like it, a masterpiece!

content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												Deus Ex: Human Revolution is number 8 on my top 10 favorite games list; it isn't the greatest game ever made, but it definitely deserves your attention and a few bucks from your wallet. It takes the fantastic concepts of the first DE game, fixes what Invisible War messed up, and adds a thick and convoluted new story to enjoy. My personal score for Deus Ex: Human Revolution is a 9/10. There are a few kinks that keep it away from perfection, particularly the less-than-ideal gunplay mechanics, but it's an overall blast to play and certainly shouldn't be missed by any fan of games with a strong story and lots of replayability.

												Basically a masterpiece. Except for the final boss fight, which you can beat in literally 10 seconds if you have the laser rifle. Nope, I'm not kidding. However, the flexibility this game allows you is quite amazing. You can take pretty much any path to beat the game, and there's so many side quests you probably won't ever beat the game. And if you open up the game, play the prologue, and think "this sucks", remember, the game normally has an ammo counter. Only issue besides the boss fight is that after you get  taken on the boat and strapped into the EMP chair	 in about chapter 15, you lose all of your weapons. Probably not a disaster if you had a 10mm pistol and a stun gun, but a bit more of a disaster if you had a laser sighted, tracking bullets, silenced, damage upgraded combat rifle, a laser-sight damage upgraded silenced armor piercing 10mm pistol, a silenced sniper rifle (which can only be found in one place to my knowledge), a grenade launcher (again, you  can only find it in one place) and a laser rifle with 600 ammo like I did. I considered rage-quitting after that, but just stick it out, there's only like 5 more hours if you forget about all of the side quests.Worth it. Take the time to beat the game. content:
Posted: November 14, 2014
												Deus ex: Human Revolution is an amazing dark and gritty FPS set in the dystopian future of 2022 where humans are divided on how they feel about the new augmentation technology. Augmentations allow humans to rise above their limitations by being able to do things such as react quicker, run faster, or jump higher among many other things. The story focuses on an ex-swat turned private security director, Adam Jensen, for Sarif Industries, a major biotech corporation. Because of a discovery that was made at Sarif Industries a team of highly augmented mercenaries attacked their headquarters and killed the team responsible for the discovery making sure that it would never reach the light of day severely injuring Adam. As a result of his injuries Adam had to be heavily augmented against his will to keep him alive. With his new found abilities it is up to Adam to track down those responsible for the deaths of the scientists and to find out the truth about what really happened that day. The player has the ability to choose how Adam goes about a situation being able to choose between dealing with enemies passively or lethally which changes the way characters address him. With multiple endings the game offers many choices for the player to make that affects the story. Overall, the game poses a question that can be applied to science even today a decade before the game takes place which is should humans play god and it is up to the play to choose where they stand for themselves based on what they see throughout the game.

												Completed DE:HR (100%) in 45h yet still managed to enjoy DE:HR - Director's Cut for ... 70 hours more!Slightly improved graphics since non-Director's Cut version and integrated Missing Link DLC are pretty nice additional features to the already great story the game offers. However the best new thing for me are boss battle changes - it's good enough to get the Director's Cut and play it.Loved the developer's commentary (thanks to the guide that lists the location of all of them) - it shows how much effort was put into the game, changes view of the game a bit, makes you look around even more often and notice small things left in the game you might have missed. Even if you have played original, Director's Cut version is best excuse to experience the story again, and again, and again ....

content:
Posted: November 22, 2013
												This game is possibley my favorite game and story ever made (apart from Deus Ex GOTYE) it takes you a variety of places and absoluteley nails it with the sound track and atmosphere. there is ALOT to do and it's worth doing, maybe 30 hours + if you do all the side quests and explore the universe.9/10~SPOILERS~Only down side is that because this is a preqel, the game has a set destiny. this is a issue towards the end where it gives you 3 choices to end the game on, you stand there and think: "well, it doesn't really matter what one i choose, because the universe will just be a run down, terrorist riddled, infected and corrupt world with my back stabbing x girl friend made a clones/virus (for no reason) as depicted in Deus Ex." Another thing i thought was stupid was the lack of closure. Assuming you chose the canon ending and killed your self and every one else in Panchea, it just didn't really answer your questions: was Megan all ways working for Bob Page from the beggining? wich project did she end up working on? why did she allow all the suffering (and future suffering) "just for science"?In the end, it doen't matter who you do or don't kill.all in all its a epic game and series, it just could have enlightend us more. 9/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
												Really enjoyed it. The freedom of choosing your own play style is woven well into level design and story telling. In my eyes, the weakest part was the "Missing Link" quest line, that was a DLC/Add-on in the original game and "built-in" here in the Director's Cut (repetitive and with hardly any consquence on the main story). It just felt out of place while playing it.Played it the stealth way on "Give me Deus Ex" (hardest difficulty) and was very pleased with it. The cover system works, augmentations are interesting and using them is fun. Also, there is plenty of optional lore detail hidden on datapads and computers. The issue of human augmentation, with progress, purity and morality in between, managed to captivate me like no other in any other video game lately.Graphics and audio are satisfying (really liked the soundtrack), most animations are fluent and good looking. On the other hand: cut scenes vary vastly in terms of quality (some seem old and some might have been freshly added with the Director's Cut) and a lot of face textures and animations look like PlayStation2 imports.Well presented, immersive and fascinating vision of the future with some story lengths and gameplay flaws you can easily overlook if you let yourself in for it. 8/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 30, 2015
												I can declare - without any doubt - that this is my favorite game. It helped me see things different and finally I could be in a universe which really interest me: our world. I believe that this game shows the truth. The fate of mankind both in the present days and in the future. This version includes all the extra content you can get, the Missing Link DLC (see below) and many hours of developers' commentar. I played through the regular version in 24 hours, while this one took more than 40. Worth the extra money?Definitely!But don't worry, I'm not going to chant odes about how great this game is, simply because it isn't. From a technical perspective, mostly. First of all, this Director's Cut version uses an older build of the game, so the many bugs they fixed in the normal version are still present. These include graphical issues, like presented here, here, here, and here.  The character animations - especially during dialogues - are also ugly, and it seems they forgot mimics too. Although they said they had a lot technological limitations, it's a shame considering it came out in 2011. I found one npc fail as well. Also, I had problems with getting a decent fps. It dropped many times below the playeable limit. It was nice to see how they improved the visuals in the DLC. It was stunning . The "improved AI" as they promoted is still dumb as a rock. Once you get into a fight they can hunt you down, but as far as you prefer stealthing, they're easy to fool. Too easy.Other than these, it's an outstanding piece of art. As I listened the developers I kinda realized how much effort they've put into this game. Level designers, voice actors, story writers, everybody did an honest and dedicated job. The story, is by far the most complex and well-written I have seen. It always keeps the tension, has many twists and makes you play more only to see what'll happen next. They hit the nail on the head with this cyber-renessaince design. It fits very well to the atmosphere. I mean, it creates the atmosphere. A dark near future world full of transhumanist aspirations and the contrary between technologycal advancement and human dignity. Takedown animations are badass, the weapon arsenal is diverse, the stealth mechanics works as well as combat situations. There are plenty of ways how you can achieve your goal. I discovered many (and I mean MANY) other alternate routes for the second playthrough. One very important thing I can not go past without a word is the music. Michael McCann is an amazing talent, his melodies define my every day life. I listen to this album regularly, and yet I can not get enough of it. It's a masteriece. To sum up this review, you must really play this game if you're interested in the topics mentioned above. It worth every minute you spend with it. Wait for a sale, then go, buy it!

content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												Played the original human revolution. This game got me immediatly due to the theme. I like the conspiracy concept with the near-futuristic slightly possible technological advancement.The added missing link will boost the playtime, however, after completing the original within 30 hours, I was a bit shocked by the ease of difficulty imho. Maybe this is due to me playing Deus Ex 1 a lot ;). I should note that i didn't do all the side missions, not looked for all the books.The biggest downer after playing 20 hours or so is seeing 2 hub districts and realising these are the only 2. Though I did not expect anything, I was hoping for a larger plot, and maybe 1 more hub city. The missing link, nor the directors cut don't feature a new hub city, though there was mention of it during development.All in all, I'd recommend this game due to theme, game franchise done right and gameplay. The story is ok, a bit short in my humble opinion. The difficulty could've had 1 more mode (the 'do not sound any alarm achievement' was easily achievable) where the AI would shine more.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2014
												It's a masterpiece in my view. I always want to play it over and over again. Sometimes the enemies can be stupid enough to don't see you while in direct eye contact but it's a game I can't judge it. It gives you multiple choices. Like kill or spare and go slient or loud. You always have to choose the sensible choice depens on your situation. You play as an ex-SWAT Adam Jansen. The whole game connects to you because you are special. I am not giving any spoilers so find out yourself. But sometimes it can be confusing because there is so much detail and miscellaneous things. You should focus on the main problem and the main story. Of course there is side quests which give more experince points and some information about the main quest but you don't have to do those in order to complete the game. With "Director's Cut" version "Missing Link" DLC comes along with the game. There is a lot of weapon selection and weapon setups. Silencer, laser targeting etc. You will definetly enjoy this game. And don't forget to check "Praxis Kit Locations" on the Steam Forum because you are going to need it. :)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
												[Small Spoilers]Deus Ex: Human Revolution - Director's Cut is a solid first person action/stealth game set in a wonderful, cyberpunk future. You play as Adam Jensen, an ex-swat member, who now is the lead security at a massive biotech company. After an accident at the facility, you became badly wounded. Thanks to the power of "augmentatioins" you were rebuilt, and now possess many possible enhancements to help better your stealth, combat, and various other things. You're tasked with finding out what actually happened the day of the attack, why it happened, and who is behind it. For my playthough I mainly focused on stealth. Other than boss fights, which even after being enhanced in the Director's Cut are still dull, I did not have kill a single individual (which I really like). Exploration, things like finding hidden air vents to crawl through, hacking doors, and hacking into computers, are really satisfying and help set the atmospehere. I encountered a glitch late game that didn't let me progress, but other than that I found few bugs. Deus Ex: Human Revolution - Director's Cut is a soild game. I highly recomend it, especially if you're a fan of steath. Gameplay: 9/10 (Focusing primarly on stealth, not gunplay)World Design: 7/10 (The "hubs" are made of many different levels, because of this it can sometimes be confusing on where exactly you're susposed to go.)Graphics: 7/10Voice-Acting: 7/10 (The main characters are voiced very well, but some of the minior characters are absolutly horrible.)Overall: 7.5/10

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												!!! DEUS EX !!!Fortunately, the massive hype surrounding 2011’s “Deus Ex: Human Revolution” was matched by an equally outstanding game. With its beautifully-realized cyberpunk world; stealth gameplay that rivaled top-shelf espionage titles; enough conspiracy theories to shake a tin foil hat at; and, best of all, its return to the “play how you want” formula that made the first game so good, “Human Revolution” was a success.  Despite its brilliance, “Human Revolution” was far from perfect, bogged down by unfairly difficult boss battles that were skewed towards specific play styles, the occasional bland texture, and sometimes wonky enemy A.I. The Updated Version of this game "Director's Cut" has solved these problems and polished the game so much more.The main complaint of the game, to date, is its color choice while looking through Adam Jensen's augmented visor. A hew of yellow coats the screen. Acourse this can easily be solved with any one of the many many graphic mods for this game revealing it's true colors. The color choice, for me, was never an issue. With its flowing, open approach to mission structure, thoroughly engrossing story and gorgeous visuals, this is the kind of game that all others should strive to be. While there are some elements that don't feel quite as developed as they should have been, and augmentation is more Hobson's choice than true choice, Human Revolution provides a level of quality that only the most adamant cynic could fail to be impressed by. More importantly, it is everything a fan of Deus Ex could want in a game.I highly recommend this game to anyone who loves Si-fi worlds and rpg based games. A "Must Play" game for sure. - XeroSyphon

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 21
												It's 2027, and the world reaches new heights in technology with every day passing. New innovations arise, such as augmentation implants that allow people to achieve an higher level of body prowess such as thinking faster, move faster, and act faster.However, this apparently incredible technology is hiding a terrible flaw: in most of cases people bodies do not react well with their mechanical parts, causing excruciating pain and suffering to their owners. Many industries in the world are trying to obtain a new type of augmentation that can solve the issue, without the need for augmented people to take on drugs in order to relieve.Sarif Industries is very close to achieve this, however soon before the research is completed the structure is savagedly attacked by a team of mercenaries which seem to murder every scientist in cold blood. Adam Jensen, the playable character, head of security in Sarif Industries, is involved in the attack and suffers severe body trauma, almost dying from it. However he turns out to be still alive when medical aid comes, and the only way to save him is by implanting augmentations on his body.After six months spent recovering, he decides to take on himself the investigation about the slaughter:eventually he will find himself in something way bigger than he expected, involving governments and corporations worldwide.The game, which is a prequel of the first Deus Ex, is strictly loyal to the original, featuring many different ways to solve missions, which the player will discern based on his/her playstyle. Many easter eggs about the first game are present, which add a well thought touch from the developers.Worth noticing are the game's length and focus on the plot: the story results interesting and the characters' development is to be praised as well.

Posted: April 5, 2014
												It's a masterpiece in my view. I always want to play it over and over again. Sometimes the enemies can be stupid enough to don't see you while in direct eye contact but it's a game I can't judge it. It gives you multiple choices. Like kill or spare and go slient or loud. You always have to choose the sensible choice depens on your situation. You play as an ex-SWAT Adam Jansen. The whole game connects to you because you are special. I am not giving any spoilers so find out yourself. But sometimes it can be confusing because there is so much detail and miscellaneous things. You should focus on the main problem and the main story. Of course there is side quests which give more experince points and some information about the main quest but you don't have to do those in order to complete the game. With "Director's Cut" version "Missing Link" DLC comes along with the game. There is a lot of weapon selection and weapon setups. Silencer, laser targeting etc. You will definetly enjoy this game. And don't forget to check "Praxis Kit Locations" on the Steam Forum because you are going to need it. :)

content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												I had a blast.---Deus Ex: Human Revolution - Director's Cut is the first and only game yet, that I played from this series. As the original game came out in 2000, it wasn't the type of game I liked to play back then. And the sequel from 2003 seemed to be a disappointment. So I skipped these games...... and I got more than positively surprised, without knowing what I had to expect:The gameplay with all his diversity is awesome. It's always your decision how you play (upseen from the boss fights). You can be a stone cold killer, a tactician, hacker or a sissy. That's also depending on the cool assorment of augmentations ("skills") from which you can choose. The atmosphere/graphic/audio is amazing. You get literally drawn into the world of cyberpunk. Only the textures and cutscenes could have a higher resolution for a game that was released in 2011.One thing I didn't liked was "The Missing Link" DLC which got added to the last third of the story mode. It just doesnt't fit in. Upseen from that... if you want to check out everything while playing the game.. hacking stuff and reading (all) ebooks can be a little bit bugging. But just a bit.I give it a 9/10

Posted: January 6, 2015
												One of a kind, cyberpunk RPG with astonishing storyline, 4 completely different endings, plenty of side quests and choices almost in every (side) quest. Full stealth entire walkthrough option make the game different and epic (i`ve been doing Foxiest of the Hounds /stealth achievement/ for a three walkthrough, so strict and challenging stealth requirements needed), heaven for stealth based gamers.Graphic is just,, idiomatic,, but cool sceneries (future hongkong), Adam`s mystery voice and good sounds/music makes up the atmosphere of high-tech future.DLC is worthy, well accurated between 2 chapters, pretty long and tough (unless u cleanin da house).Only thing i dont like on Director`s cut edition is really loud discussions of developers, sometimes interesting stories of creating a game, but most of the times, one would like to enjoy story, and that LOUD conversations just ruin it :)For achievement hunters i`d say prepare for at least 3 walkthrough even with good schedule. A lot of achievements based on choices, so reload save is also the way. With some achievements, study google hard, or die cryin and playin it a couple of times :)For me personally, this game is masterpiece and a jewel in my "perfect games" collection.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												Excellent game all around.  I'd recommend it just that much more for people who really like to explore and become immersed in a good story.THE UPSIDE:Great story that somehow manages to combine a frighteningly possible future with a slightly ridiculous one (IMHO).  There are numerous opportunities to really engross yourself in the 'blade runner esq' universe.  While there isn't anything super innovative in the cover mechanics it's very polished and smooth.  The different chooses in play style really let you decide how you want to advances through areas.  There are generally not one, not two, but three or more different ways to accomplish almost all the objectives in the game, using various augments, stealth, manipulation or even brute force.  There are many paths and alternative ways to go about virtually everything.THE DOWNSIDE:I have two major complaints about the game... the first.  I LOATH the way the game handles 'lethal' take downs.  Not being able to silently take down an opponent lethally is just comical.  Some of the take downs are SO over the top and just ridiculously unnecessary it makes no sense why you couldn't simply use your blades to quietly dispatch an opponent, but instead are forced to do this elaborate take down which could do nothing but draw attention.  Conversely the 'non lethal' take downs being no less over the top (most of the time) are silent despite the guy being thrown about and clearly verbalizing this 'discomfort'.  In a game that does such a great job with immersion i find this very irritating.The only other complaint i have is with the hacking. Great little mini-game the first 50 times... the next 100 are pretty damn irritating... after that you want to just cry.  The problem is if your like me and enjoy the enormous amount of back-story hidden behind the terminals found throughout the game you find it very hard to just skip them.THE LOWDOWN:  7.5/10It's good not great... the game was a good fit for me... but i can see people who arn't as concerned with immersion finding this game pretty tedious.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												With the fixed boss fights and other small tweaks plus the integration of The Missing Link DLC in to the main game, this is easily the best version of Deus Ex: Human Revolution. Biggest changes in DC is the fact that boss fights are doable pretty much by hacking. There is still no non-lethal way to beat the bosses like in Metal Gear games, but that's not such a big deal. Also new game+ and developer commentary are great added features. On lower difficulties than "Give me Deus Ex" the game is now slightly easier, because two energy bars get charged automatically. The energy system is still flawed, but at least it's now a bit more fun when you can combo stealth cloak in to double takedown in every situation.There aren't that many "pure" cyberpunk games around (there are some cyberpunk elements in a loooot of games), so the scenery is very refreshing. The world Eidos Montreal has created is very believable and the characters from their looks to dialog are great.That's on my short 2 cents on DE: HR Director's Cut.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												The good: I don't know what I can say about the amazing Deus Ex universe that hasn't already been said. Human Revolution is incredibly immersive; the enviroment is beautiful, the characters well rounded (even the side characters), and the story compelling (espeically if you take time to read the avaliable material and track down clues off the beaten path). The gameplay is fun, especially if you enjoy stealth games. The soundtrack is amazing; check out the cinematic trailer if you want a good example of this. If you're a stealth player, this game will really allow you to shine. The bad: Human Revolution encourages you to take a stealth approach, which runs a little contrary to the prior Deus Ex games, in which multiple paths were equally rewarding. You get more in-game rewards for stealth and non-lethal approaches. I'd have liked to see a more balanced approach. Also under bad, the boss fights were developed by a different company, so they really don't fit the feel of the rest of the game.Director's Cut specific notes: The Director's Cut attempted to fix the boss battles, and they are certainly much better than they were in prior versions; however, you still have to kill the bosses, which is jarring in the midst of a non-lethal run. Many people have experienced performance issues with the Director's Cut. Those with Nvidia graphics cards seem to experience more difficulty on the whole; however, a lot of it is down to your configuration. I'm running a Nvidia card in a laptop and I'm able to play the DC without any framerate or stuttering issues. However, your mileage may vary - something to be aware of.General info: All of the DLCs available with the original Human Revolution have been integrated into the Director's Cut (except for the 10,000 credit bonus). The extra weapons are now available in-game as opposed to being dropped into your inventory from the beginning, and the Tong mission and Missing Link are both part of the story line. Overall: This is my favorite game, to be honest, and I would strongly recommend it to absolutely anyone. The story is great, and if you care to spend any time seriously contemplating it, can raise some interesting questions about technology and humanity. If you haven't played the Deus Ex games, do yourself a favor and play them ASAP.System Specs Used: Intel Core i7-3610QM, Nvidia GeForce GTX 670M / 3GB GDDR5, DDRIII 12GB RAM, Windows 7

content:
Posted: February 13
												Deus Ex Human Revolution is a immersive deep story involving conspiracy, international conflict, human dilemmas and choices in dialogues and most important, in actions, choices that affect gameplay and the outcome of your adventure presented in stealth FPS/RPG complemented by deep character progression, that open various options based on player style of play, tough, stealth is encourage by the game, not only bc of the experience gain but also feels more satisfying that blazing trought the levels.You have many tools at your disposal to avoid combat or you can simply blast your way trough to progress, the levels are big enough to give you various options, the graphics are good and voices actors did a awsome job, making the story believable enough to keep you attached to the game, Jensen narration kind of reminded me from Max Payne, its impossible not to enpathize with him and the gameplay is also satisfying going stealth or using guns, since the cover mechanics work very well, be it to avoid combat or to protect you from enemy bullets.My only concern about this game was the limited inventory space (like STALKER, many weapons but nowhere to carry them since this is game, not real life, but this is just personal opinion), but since there are mods that were released after the game, im not even considering that a bad thing bc it can please each person way of play the game.Now, i just wanted to give some personal toughts about this version and the original, there are many opinions about the vannilla and the DC, and every each one of them is just about preference, i personally loved to play both games, but finded the DC more balanced over the original, and the fact that TML was introduced in DC at the right point, made the story feel more sense that playing TML was standlone, but the HR Yellow UI had more impact in the cyberpunk feeling.Since i love to play Deus Ex, to me, any of the games is a must in my library, and the fact that each one was is strong points over the other, i never feel that im playing the same game, just the same story.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2015
												Simply put one of the best stealth/infiltration games of 2011 and arguably one of the best cyberpunks games ever.As for the plus/minus of this game, here it goes:The good things * Story: It mainly revolves around the ethics of "augmentations", that is cyberntic extensions that can be attached to a human being to improve the body or/and the mind. You are Adam Jensen, one who was recently cybernetically augmented. Yes, you are the the main character but you'll quickly see that you are part of a very big story with multiple secondary characters having their own agendas. The ending is satisfactory as there is no loose plot, and everything falls nicely into one place.* Level design: There are many ways for you to complete an objective. There generally is the main way (rambo), and many other paths. There is always a secondary path that will allow anyone to get inside a building without requiring special augmentations, while other may require you to level up a cybernetic part of your body. Being curious is a good thing. Also, being a "hacker" is great: it's a bit difficult to invest on this from the start but it pays off quickly as you are able to get to places you couldn't reach easily otherwise.* Stealth: You can finish the game without killing anyone, except the bosses. I wish more games do that.The less good things* Boss battles: it's certainly the weakest point of the game. Yes, you can use the environment rather than weapons to kill them, but all boss battles (except the last one maybe) left me underwhelmed.* Difficulty: If you go the "hacker" way, you'll find that the game gets much easier. I had only one playthrough (too many games to play to do it a second time) so maybe it's true only for the hacking part.Other than that, except good graphics (for 2011), and 40 hours of solid gaming if you want to resolve secondary missions and/or plan to play to get all achievements.I suggest this game to anyone that likes stealth/infiltration, cyberpunk or good story. If you happen to like all three, like I do, then you'll have a blast.NOTE: It's also supposed to be an action game, as you can play it "rambo" style... But you would miss a lot by doing that. I suggest anyone wanting to get the best from this game to play it in stealth mode: also, try to avoid killing anyone (Pacifist achievement) and avoid starting off alarms. And, play in on max difficulty. This combination should arguably be the best way to play the game.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2015
												Deus Ex: Human Revolution - Director's Cut follows the story of Adam Jensen, an ex-SWAT and security specialist, handpicked to oversee the defense of one of America's most experimental biotechnology firms and forced to submit himself to the scientific advancements, also known as augmentations, after being severely injured while trying to save the scientists he was hired to protect.The game offers an open approach to mission structure, thoroughly engrossing story and gorgeous visuals combined with an simply amazing soundtrack and exceptional gameplay.The boss fights are very well-designed, the different choices and multiple approaches will have consequences later in the plot and the stealth mechanics are just great.I highly recommend Deus Ex: Human Revolution - Director's Cut.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2015
												A prequel of what many consider the best game ever made, and a spiritual descendant of System Shock, Deus Ex HR is old-fashioned and new at the same time. The FPS-RPG game style allows many and creative ways to procede in the action sequences, while well constructed and clever dialogues sustain a brilliant plot. Maps are rich of possibilities and often placed in open areas, giving a true sense of freedom and reality. Augmentations expand even more the gameplay variety, which never relies on scripts, and that's more unique than rare in modern games.93/100

The world Eidos Montreal has created is very believable and the characters from their looks to dialog are great.That's on my short 2 cents on DE: HR Director's Cut.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2014
												The good: I don't know what I can say about the amazing Deus Ex universe that hasn't already been said. Human Revolution is incredibly immersive; the enviroment is beautiful, the characters well rounded (even the side characters), and the story compelling (espeically if you take time to read the avaliable material and track down clues off the beaten path). The gameplay is fun, especially if you enjoy stealth games. The soundtrack is amazing; check out the cinematic trailer if you want a good example of this. If you're a stealth player, this game will really allow you to shine. The bad: Human Revolution encourages you to take a stealth approach, which runs a little contrary to the prior Deus Ex games, in which multiple paths were equally rewarding. You get more in-game rewards for stealth and non-lethal approaches. I'd have liked to see a more balanced approach. Also under bad, the boss fights were developed by a different company, so they really don't fit the feel of the rest of the game.Director's Cut specific notes: The Director's Cut attempted to fix the boss battles, and they are certainly much better than they were in prior versions; however, you still have to kill the bosses, which is jarring in the midst of a non-lethal run. Many people have experienced performance issues with the Director's Cut. Those with Nvidia graphics cards seem to experience more difficulty on the whole; however, a lot of it is down to your configuration. I'm running a Nvidia card in a laptop and I'm able to play the DC without any framerate or stuttering issues. However, your mileage may vary - something to be aware of.General info: All of the DLCs available with the original Human Revolution have been integrated into the Director's Cut (except for the 10,000 credit bonus). The extra weapons are now available in-game as opposed to being dropped into your inventory from the beginning, and the Tong mission and Missing Link are both part of the story line. Overall: This is my favorite game, to be honest, and I would strongly recommend it to absolutely anyone. The story is great, and if you care to spend any time seriously contemplating it, can raise some interesting questions about technology and humanity. If you haven't played the Deus Ex games, do yourself a favor and play them ASAP.System Specs Used: Intel Core i7-3610QM, Nvidia GeForce GTX 670M / 3GB GDDR5, DDRIII 12GB RAM, Windows 7
