content:
Posted: October 30, 2014
												A rock solid game on many levels. It is one of the best stealth games that I have come across in the last few years. Yet, it's not just a stealth game. It provides several playstyles in which you can utilize during the game. The replayability factor simply rises because of it, as you naturally are tempted into playthroughs targetted to specific goals and playstyles.The graphics are solid, yet don't tax mid-range systems. Even some low end systems should be able to run with this title and still look decent. It's very easy on the eyes and the gpu at the same time. The story line is a cut above for it's genre, in my opinion. It has depth, color, imagination, and well-thought out twists and turns. When it's time to decide your stance in the world, you really feel like you're a part of this world. My advice is to not rush this game; don't view it as stages to be completed. Go everywhere, do everything... explore and take your time at each stage of the game... get lost in the character you're playing instead of the goal you're trying to achieve.This game doesn't fall short many places, but that's not saying it's perfect. There's room for expansion and improvement. I, for one, am really looking forward to any news of a sequel worthy of to succeed this game and see where they go with this amazing creation. I say one that is worthy of this game, because this game is quite literally the best entry into this franchise and the other titles that bear it's Dues Ex mark can't even stand in the same arena as this entry in my opinion.All in all, I give this game a 9/10 overall and highly recommend this game to anyone!

content:
Posted: November 3, 2013
												Phew - finally done with the replay of DX. While it is fun to knock out people again, it is just the same game with a sharper / clearer image plus the Missing Link DLC added into it  - IMO I didn't really see much differences. Never have issues with the boss fights previously so I don't really see much even if it is changed a bit in this Director's Cut.Pros: *Above average storyline (provided you haven't played it before)*Good gameplay with either fun stealth features or average shooting/weapons to rush through it all*Good music (at least good enough for me to go download some of them =D)Cons:*Chat options doesn't affect the main storyline much (there are multiple endings but it is not really related to chat options)*Not much replay value (one run to do it all and I am removing this after 100%)*So-so AI (turning up the difficulty doesn't do much to me except increasing damage by guards and longer detection cooldown time)*A little bit repetitive on the hacking/sneaking if you are trying to max out on the experience Summary:While I might stated a few cons, it is still a good game that deserves your time if you haven't played/gotten it yet - especially after how cheap it is now. However if I can choose again, I probably won't be bothered to buy the Director's Cut, the plain vanilla + Missing Link DLC is more than sufficient. If you have not gotten any of the vanilla etc before, wait till Director's Cut get discounted and get it straight.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 5, 2015
"IT'S NOT THE END OF THE WORLD, BUT YOU CAN SEE IT FROM HERE"Deus Ex: Human Revolution (more especifically the Director's Cut) was one of my first games on Steam. A gift, I was actually a bit hesitant on accepting as I've never been a big fan of FPS. The RPG part made me go through the download size and didn't quite prepare me for the stealth. I believe it's more accurate to call DX:HR a stealth with FPS and RPG elements, as the first is the most proeminent trait.As Adam Jensen, you're tasked with security in Sarif Inustries, a top notch corporation specialized in augmentations. Not too long after you started, however, the matrix (located in a 2027 Detroit) is attacked by a mysterious black ops squad and a number of questions rise as you're basically resuscitated by your employer. Seems like your typical cyberpunk setting, except it feels more realistic, more relatable. The secrets you come to know during Adam's journey for answers and revenge easily get you involved while one question is answered and another one is made. And as any person asking the dangerous questions, Adam does so mostly in the shadows. Even though the game offers a large range of strategical approaches and paths, the stealth mechanic can be more rewarding and fulfilling, not to mention lore friendly. On higher difficulties keeping a low profile is actually necessary as augmentations aren't enough to withstand a bulletstorm. Fear not, though, as you can literally be a ghost by taking full advantage of the incredible level design!Not only the story is well written and filled with branches, but the artwork and soundtrack are some of the most relatable and beautiful in recent game history. The architecture feels unique and real, while the soundtrack tries to unite a feeling of old and new by mixing classic notes with electronic beats. It's easy to dive into Deus Ex's universe and get lost in its mature themes, such as transhumanism.Even though the experience is one worth having, it's still far from perfect. The Director's Cut came with a number of performance issues and bugs that -- after almost four years of the game's first release -- haven't yet been fixed by the developers. The game performers poorly on computers above its rcommended specifications and fixing it is no easy task. Still to this day there's no definitive method for AMD users to get completely rid of stuttering and small FPS drops, not to mention a proper (official or from the community) fix for the various bugs that lurk around the corners -- one of which got me frustrated and made me leave the game aside for more than a year. This might be one of those cases where you have to ignore the performance issues to fully enjoy the game, as DX:HR-DC is not a proper PC title/port.Pros:  Friendly to newcomers of the franchise  Very sharp stealth mechanics aligned with a decent AI  RPG elements with the augmentations upgrades  The player is not constantly forced to make use of the FPS mechanics  Large variety of paths and strategies within a single level  Intelligent hacking mechanic  Immersive cyberpunk setting with a deep story, mature context and complex, relatable characters  Beautiful design and soundtrack  Hard and meaningful choices that matter  Multiple endings  Adam's dark pastCons:  Performance issues  Bugs -- lots of them  AMD users might have more difficulty in fixing problems  No "auto-sort" in the inventory  Too many endings (a total of twelve)If you like cyberpunk themes and stealth games, Deus Ex: Human Revolution is a safe bet. And even if you're not particularly interested in what the game has to offer, it might surprise you!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6, 2014
												Deus Ex: Human Revolution is a prequel to the original Deus Ex game and follows the story of Adam Jensen, a security chief at an augmentation (cybernetic implantation) industry, who finds himself augmented against his will and put against a myterious conspiracy he must discover and twhart in time.The story of Human Revolution keeps itself interesting for the whole game, with a very clever portrait of technology advancements debates, few cameos from characters of Deus Ex and a good bunch of original protagonists. As with every Deus Ex title there is a lot of reading and exploring to do for players who really want to dig further in the game's setting: doing so even awards you nice chunks of experience every time.Gameplay-wise, one must say that Human Revolution offers less freedom of action than its predecessor. While in the original Deus Ex you could go around destroying anyone and anything or decide to either incapacitate or plain evade both regular enemies without any consequence, truly allowing you to slowly build your own way to overcome the game's challenges, this sequel still gives you the same amount of freedom, but turns the table more in favor of an action-packed approach. Each boss encounter requires you to kill your enemy and every one of them are very durable augmented agents that will torn apart a player that relayed only on stealth and evasion up to that point. You can't run away either. There are also several instances in the game where going full killing mode against your enemies is required to achieve certain results.The Director's Cut DLC tried to fix such design choices by adding to the bosses arenas more way to eliminate them with indirect means. However, it's worth mentioning that you still HAVE to kill them and they have been severly buffed up from the first version of the game, to the point that even trying to off them with hacking or unconventional means is very hard without some protective or straight combat augs.The Missing Link DLC is a four hours worthy new content that was fully integrated in the main story of Human Revolution with the Director's Cut. The DLC takes place on a Belltower cargo ship, the Hei Zhen Zhu, and requires you to find and neutralize the local mercenary leader in order to continue your main story to Singapore. Whyle the ship features very crampy environments, the whole DLC still feels like a Deus Ex game, with plenty of alternative options to choose from. The final boss of the Missing Link is also much more Deus-Ex-esque than the ones from the vanilla game.I would totally reccomend Deus Ex: Human Revolution due to its outsanding story and gameplay united with a huge replay value that allows you to experience a different kind of game every time you decide how to deal with the enemies and the other NPCS your own special way differently

content:
Posted: September 13, 2015
												I'm writing this review from the perspective of someone who's never touched the first game. Deus Ex: Human Revolution, to me, is the pinnacle of modern RPG games. It has super satisfying gunplay and extremely tense stealth moments when playing on the hardest difficulty. The areas are incredibly detailed and you are rewarded greatly for not barging though every room. Around every corner there's some kind of secret, a piece of lore in the form of an eBook, Email, Newspaper, etc., and there's always multiple ways to attack any given situation (With some exception to scripted boss fights, which still can technically be taken down any way you please, I took out the first boss with sniper headshots instead of using the explosives in the room)The hub areas are massive and filled with unique stories and side quests to be done. The world is alive with police, gang members, and civilians, all able to share specifically two pieces of dialogue with you. The combat in this game is extremely satisfying, as is the stealth, as are the persuasion moments, as are the non-lethal takedowns, as are the lethal takedowns. This game lets you approach in any way you choose and you can have a good time doing it.That's being said, this game obviously is not without it's faults, and here's a quick pro/con list to help sort some of these things out.PROS:Stealth and Combat are equally satisfying:  Though one option is technically better, and I'll get to that in a moment, neither is more satisfying than the other. The stealth mechanics work really well, where if one enemy thinks he sees you the others aren't immediatly alerted. They'll question whether the guy who saw you is going crazy or drunk or something before searching for you, if they even do. Enemies don't just instantly drop what they're doing, they go through a few stages of detection. Oblivious, Suspicious, Alterted, and Hostile. At each stage it will take longer for them to ignore you, and they will be more and more alert. The gunplay is also extremely well put together, with the guns feeling satisfying and being extremely fun to use effectively. So in the event you're caught, you won't feel dissatisfied (Other than with your lack of ability to stay hidden)The areas are extremely detailed: There's something unique around every corner, and if you pay close enough attention you can find terminals to hack that lead to weapon mods, money, and ammo. This game rewards you for not rushing it, it rewards you for thinking, and it rewards exploration in a really nice way. These are really the two main pros, obviously there's the interesting story backed with gamey voice acting that we're all used to. Some of the voice acting is pretty good, but most of it is pretty corny and obviously read from a script, but that's okay. Now onto the con.Con:Stealth is clearly the superior way to play. Non-lethal takedowns and hacking reward extremely highly. Normal kills get you 10 whatever points, headshots get you 20, while non-lethal takedowns always get you 30 or more. Hacking also gives you points, so even if you know the code to a door or computer, you might as well just hack it for the extra points and upgrades. Using stealth you can easily unlock every augment in the game, which breaks a lot of replay value. The only reason not to use stealth would be to see how the story changes when you kill everyone, which is extremely difficult on the hardest setting. I wish that it wasn't such a clear choice to go for stealth if you're looking for all the money and upgrades, but it is. Anyways, this game is extremely fun, and very deep. There's tons of content and i've barely scratched the surface of the game 12 hours into it, because I can't stop finding new places to go and new areas to explore. This game does exploration and discovery in a uniquely satsisfying way and I highly recommend picking it up.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 6, 2015
												In it's core Deus Ex: Human Revolution is a good game.I was pleased to see, that it can both run smooth and look good (surprisingly, at least for me, it runs better with Directx 11 enabled than with disabled), although it took some research and tweaking with game's settings.I don't have much negative things to say about sound either. Outside of fight music is more to the subtle side, after a while I started to not notice it much anymore and got used to it being there, it became inseparable part of the surroundings.Voice acting was mostly good too.The time you spend in the game will be divided into exploring the level, taking care of bad guys and talking to people.Levels are designed with different player's approaches in mind. There are many paths which you can take to get on better position or to get straight past the enemy, you just have to find them or have the augmentations to use them. There is of course always an option to go head on and shoot through the enemies.Every level has also many hidden items scattered around, which rewards exploration.There is also a lot of hacking to be had and hacking minigame here is one of the better you will see.Combat is cover based and stealth oriented.Sneaking around and taking down enemies one by one is the easiest way how to play the game. Sticking to cover will get you to 3d person mode, so you can look around corners, not to mention you have radar which shows position and facing of nearby enemies.When the enemies don't know where exactly you are, they behave really stupid. They walk on their paths, they never notice a missing buddy, when they briefly see you they will investigate but then they will quickly return to their path, sometimes they will play with their phones/tablets paying almost no attention to what is going on and they can be easily lured out of group with noise. It's the standart stealth AI we all know, nothing new but it still works.In direct combat their AI is sufficient. They will make use of cover, they remember your last location and will try to pin you down with fire, sometimes they throw grenades and may even divide and try to get closer to you.The story is the usual conspiracy, which you are uncovering bit by bit. For the most part it's focused on following the trail to find kidnapped scientists with sidestories on the way. There are choices to be made here and there but only a few has an impact on the game.There are some good characters with well written dialog, but unimportant characters can deliver few pretty terrible lines. Talking animations could use some work too, I don't talk about lips but body movement. Characters have tendency to repeat animations often and sometimes they look unsettled, almost shaking. For an RPG there is not that much talking here, but it's balanced out with persuasion minigames.Inventory system is a tetris on checkerboard with pieces of different sizes. Some might find it too small, but with upgrades it's more than enough. You won't fit all weapons there, but you will stick to few weapons which you upgrade anyway and you don't need to loot everything you find, because most things you need you will find, not buy. Unless you have a real problem with hording consumable items, you will get over it.Augmentations, you will unlock them using praxis kits, which you can find and also you will gains them for experience. There are just a few augmentations which I found useless, the others are usefull, more or less in dependence on your playstyle.Experience gain is problem though. You are rewarded with more experience for using non lethal methods and even more for non lethal takedowns (your close range attack consuming energy). It makes sense, unconscious enemy can be revived and for takedown you have to get close. But if you want to maximaze your experience, you are forced to certain playstale. It's either having fun or being effective. For me it would be better if there was just no set experience for every enemy, but it's more a nitpick.There are some things, which was bothering me though.First of all is lack of detail. Outside of main characters, there is little to no interactivity with other npcs in the levels. There are also numerous things which breaks immersion. Just to name a few, you can walk into a shop, go right past it's owner into back room, steal whatever you find there and the npc will not even take notice of your presence. Or in Alice Garden Pods during Belltower attack, you can still see closed pods with silhouettes of people just reading a book while civilian npcs are laying around dead. I guess Belltower soldiers are just kind enough to not disturb them and will settle for killing those who stand around.What makes it even worse is that developers had balls to put in pocket secretaries with unfinished text like the writer was interrupted by the attack.Also, if you will steal from offices in Sarif industries Headquaters, you will get emails from personel blaming each other for your thefts. This is a nice detail, which makes the overall lack of detail even more annoying.Also, if you have Direct's Cut version, there is dlc content integrated into the game. In practice it means, that when you get into cryopod to get yourself on a boat, which is near end of the game, you will be thrown into dlc, where they will take all your augmentations away at the beggining.I personally really hate when game takes all your benefits away without a possibility to avoid it. When you go trough most of the game exploring every inch of the level, taking down every enemy, going for the bonus experience for completing level unnoticed to get augmentations you want, and then when you have them and you finally don't have to care about experience and you can go trough level as you want, you just don't want to suddenly do that again, because game will take it away.That made me stop playing for few months. I'm glad I take a break, or else I would rush through that part just to get over with when actually it is a well made set of levels and dialogs with Quinn were great too.Just a few last things to mention - unskippable intro sequence and npcs interrupting you in persuasion minigame with "You have nothing to say?". Unnecessary.So, the game is good, just rough on the edges. It is definitely a worthy sequel, recommended.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
												Background: Big fan of the original, love stealth games and the Bladerunner cyberpunk genre.The Good:* Interesting plot and missions* Real options for both stealth and assault * Interesting powers change gameplay* World looks great and lived in* Large, well planned sandbox type maps* Long and varied location campaign* Feels a lot like a solo Mass Effect missionThe Bad:* Bland character models and stiff animations* Stealth sections are far too easy with obvious routes and dumb cameras* Weapons and upgrades lack impact* Buggy quests make completion impossible* Hacking mechanic is boring & characters ignore you stealing from them* Sandbox play makes for nonsensical conversations* Map system is oddly weak in a technological future* NPCs speak as if you aren't standing there and totally ignore you doing awesome featsImpressions: I really liked the experience despite some terrible lack of refinement and  buggy gameplay. The stealth options are a blast even if the enemy is really easy to predict.Recommended for: sci-fi stealth fans.Conclusion.7/10. Despite it's flaws it's a lot of fun to play and not being too taxing always keep you moving forward.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 13, 2016
												I've promised myself muitiple times that the next playthrough was the last, but no, I had to play it several more times that I've lost count. In fact, I might even play it again several more times, even if I'll follow the same mindset/route(s). Hell, I might even discover a new route or two, or even a cache of items. With this in mind, each playthrough may or may not be similar depending on how you go on about it. In fact, certain paths might even trigger some dialogue, give you a better vantage point, lead to a shortcut, or even all three.So the Director's Cut adds the DLCs released for the game and some changes for the boss fights as well. The Missing Link story is implimented into the game instead of seperate from it entirly. This adds at least 3~5-ish hours to a somewhat long game. Though I haven't played the original version of the game, I can't really tell you the differences in glitches or visuals, so I'm leaving that out.Gameplay falls under the stealth and action genres, so You can go in guns blazing, stealth kill eveyone(or just a few), or go full pacifist, but you still have to kill the bosses to progress the story though. I find it easier to just kill off everyone as stealthily as possible before I get caught, or just use the cloak augment and book it for next area.Overall, the game is great. I look forward to my future playthroughs even though the experience might get stale but I don't mind. I'll give this game a 9/10, but why a 9? because it can feel a bit slow at times (obviously because its a stealth game of course). But don't let that deter you, that's just from my experience. If you are still on the fence with it, just think it through. Buy it when it's on sale if you're still not sure so it's not a waste of twenty bucks if you regrete it.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												(For those of you wondering whether this is a version of Human Revolution with Montreal and/or Upper Hengsha city hubs: sorry, this isn't it.  At this point, I doubt it'll ever come our way, at least barring a "Super Director's Cut" edition.  Don't be waiting for it.)The DE:HR Director's Cut integrates The Missing Link, a previously standalone story, into the original game, and adds in a New Game Plus mode which carries over all abilities (but no items, sadly) from a completed playthrough.  Some preorder-bonus missions are also added in, but the best addition here is a stellar commentary from the biggest names behind the game.  Seriously - give it a listen.  There's a ton of it (about 8 hours total), but quite a bit of it is insightful and interesting.  A new gold standard for commentary in video games (sorry Valve).Newcomers: this is an absolute steal for twenty bucks.  A playthrough of the Director's Cut will take you anywhere from 35-60 hours, depending on how much you see and do, and it's just a flat-out great game besides.  The art direction, soundtrack, and story are first-rate, as are the scenarios that accommodate a range of playstyles the Deus Ex universe is renowned for supporting.  Whether you try to sneak, hack, or shoot your way through this universe, it's a good time.

												The Director's Cut offers some enhancements over the original version as well as Developers Commentary and Making of footage. Among the new features are the improvements in Boss Fight where you are not limited or forced to front armed combat, and the integration of The Missing Link DLC.Putting the Director's Cut tag to a side, and having played on Normal, I must admit I was faced with one of the dumbest AI. Controls are awkward as shooting mechanics, but once you get used to them it becomes a much enjoyable experience.Graphics are very nice, and characters are coupled with good quality voice acting, but it's in the music department where this title really shines. Character leveling and the choices you make give replayability to the different stages and situations.In short, nothing too outstanding, but in spite of it's flaws I still recommend this game. After all, it's surely in the top 10 of AAA titles of the year.Edit: Added screenshots.

content:
Posted: May 29, 2014
DISCLAIMER: Don't get fooled by many negative reviews, most of them compare Director's Cut to the original. Original, however, doesn't seem to be available on Steam anymore, so if you've never played it, this is your best (and only) chance!Now, let's get on with the review.Never played Human Revolution? - Get it!Already played HR, should I get Director's Cut? - Got money to spare? Want trading cards/badges? Missed DLC? Sure, go for it. Otherwise, not really. Pros- amazing story- dialogue and other choices have effects later on- you can choose stealth and not kill a single enemy or go on an all-out killing spree. You can also combine those two approaches- multiple solutions to various situations- custom select your abilities (augmentations) to fit your playstyle- a lot of playtime for purely single-player experience (first playthrough is likely going to take you 20-30 hours, how many single-player games offer that nowadays?)Cons- a lot of moving between objectives and your sprinting doesn't last all that long(Wow, that's all I could come up with. I may add some more later but right now, I can't seem to think of anything else that could bother someone. Note: See the Differences section below for potential cons)Differences between regular and Director's Cut [+/-]+ re-worked bossfights, making them less harsh on players who choose stealth + integrated DLC- colors seem washed out, can be fixed with ENB- may encounter some performance issues and/or bugs. Personally, I didn't notice any but maybe I'm just lucky.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2014
												Oh, where to begin?  Deux Ex is a decent game, blending concepts of stealth, shooting, and social engineering.  Unfortunately, it doesn't really excel in any area.  The stealth sequences are very old-fashioned, in that they work well enough if you choose to stay concealed but fall apart badly if you prefer to kill quietly.  The shooting mechanics are hindered by poor controls - left trigger dives for cover instead of aiming down sights, etc - and by guns that just don't feel good.  It's great that the weapons can be upgraded in all manner of ways, but it's all for naught if they don't feel good to shoot.  Case in point: the round from a sniper rifle shouldn't drop in flight by 18 inches during a 25 yard shot.  Also, a guy that gets hit in the head with a finger-long projectile traveling at roughly 700 mph shouldn't immediately snap to attention and try to figure out who shot him just because he's wearing a helmet.  Finally, the parts of the game that attempt to challenge players by way of dialogue choices feels like LA Noire - the clues and responses that you're given don't correspond very tightly to the desired outcomes; two players making the same choices won't necessarily get the same result - it's stupid.All that said, the game features an intriguing story and is good enough (barely) at what it does to be worth playing.  The director's cut (poorly) incorporates the Missing Link DLC into the main campaign and adds some optional DVD-style commentary.  Unfortunately, because the upgrade exists as a separate title in the Steam library no saved games or achievements carry over into the new game.  I'd say that it's worth grabbing, but only if you don't already own The Missing Link.

												I have played Deus ex Human Revolution on my Ps3 for a long time and in the summer sales of steam i saw this offer for just 5 euros and I just knew I had to buy this upgraded version of Deus ex Human Revolution, but the question for me is, is this upgraded version worth it or not. To start of with, Deus ex Human Revolution is a very good game that lets you play whatever way you want to play, if its stealth, more violent or a mix between both or even without killing anyone, you can play all those ways and lots more. This gives it a lot of replay value ( at least for me). The stealth system is pretty well done, i've seen better stealth games but it's still a great stealth game, the more violent way of playing isn't the great part of this game as its not really enjoyable at least if you play it on the hardest difficulty. The story is superb and I love how this is a openworld game but still linear. Oberall the normal version of this game is for me one of the best game of the last 3 years and i would highly suggest it.Now the question is, is this marveallous game worth it if you already own the normal version, firs of all if you havent played this game yet I highly recommend you buy this version and not the normal version because it also includes the dlc. This upgraded version comes with 3 mayor upgrades: first it includes the dlc, second it has the developers commentary which I find highly entertaining and it just gives you more depth in the game and thirt boss fights can be done stealthly. It also upgrades a bit the graphics and some game mechanics. I recommend this version if you dont own th dlc, but if you dont own it  recommend it because of the dlc and developers commentary because it gives your new playthrough more depth at the cost of just 5 euros. I find this version superior to the normal version and a must have on your gaming library

content:
Posted: November 4, 2013
												This game is a monumental achievement, a unique singleplayer experience combining FPS elements with stealth, puzzles and a complex and engaging story.The atmosphere created by the impeccable graphic design, good voice acting and stunning soundtrack is truly memorable. The game world is crafted masterfully and in great detail: from the essential characters that are interesting and flawed to the futuristic settings for the intriguing tehcno thriller of a story, the player is treated with such quality and class that only a few games do. The game offers an astounding amount of information and small details for the player to consume (should they be so inclined).The levels and character customization provide the player with a number of options to achieve the goal in any given mission and indeed DX:HRDC is one of the very few first person games that actually offer the player multiple ways to finish the game. Moreover, depending on player choice the mission outcomes may vary significantly and the story unfold in a different manner. If you explore the world and finish side quests it will probably take around 25 - 35 hours to finish the game. The new Director's Cut edition integrates the Missing Link DLC seamlessly into the main game in addition to which it also comes with a "making of" documentary, commentary mode, a new game+ option and a host of other changes and tweaks. DX:HRDC is the best version of the game yet and a truly epic experience that should not be missed!

content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												Deus Ex: Human Revolution (DXHR) is the third installment in the Deus Ex series of games. This is a prequel previous to both Deus Ex and Deus Ex: Invisible War.The previous games were set in the distant future (2050's) where human augmentation is a reality, the United States is no longer a major global power, mega corporations have filled the power vacuum and conspiracies underpin all of it.DXHR is however set some twenty years earlier in 2027. You portray Adam Jensen, chief of security of Sarif Industries, a mid-sized manufacturer of human augmentations and contractor to the United States military. Along with Megan Reed your former flame and chief scientist of the same company. Along with her and CEO David Sarif, they are about to make a major announcement of a discovery that will potentially make human augmentation accessible to all and not just those who can afford the drug Neuropozyne, which is required to prevent the body from rejecting the augmentation. With the goal to enhance human lives, David Sarif sees this as the start of the next stage of human evolution.This is the initial premise of the game as shown during the introduction/tutorial of the game. Like the previous installments it is a first person shooter with stealth elements and ability to complete tasks using different paths. Deus Ex was a personal favourite of mine when I played it because you could play the game largely as you liked (main plot missions withstanding) and then experience the consequences of your actions play out accordingly. In most respects DXHR features the same gameplay elements.There are three styles of play: direct approach, indirect approach and avoiding contact altogether. For instance to open a door you can take out a guard then take the code from them, hack a computer terminal for the code or just bypass the door itself.Combat likewise has varied options with melee combat (called a takedown), an array of short to long range ballistic, energy and chemical weapons as well as the option to (depending on the weapon of choice) lethally and non-lethally taking out your opponent. Almost all weapons can be upgraded to suit your style of play as well.This of course leads to the element of the game. Augmentations can be aquired as the game progresses and allows you to essentially gain superhuman abilities over time. I won't go into specifics as this is what makes Deus Ex stand out from other FPS's. But they are well worth the wait as they help you to complete tasks in a variety of new ways.Pro's:A lot of work and attention to detail went into the in-game environments and characters to create a credible immersive experience.Excellent writing and voice work by all involved. A lot of work went into getting everything right.Amazing soundtrack by Michael McCann. Fits and enhances the atmosphere and immersion in game immensely.The game strikes the right balance between being giving you many options in-game and the tasks themselves not being too generic as is the case in other FPS sand box style games.Con's:It felt like the developers were running out of time during production as the story speeds up significantly towards the end of the game.Diehard players with feel the game helps you too much in completing a task, some visual aids can be however turned off.The animations (especially during conversations) are repeatedly used which ruins some of the work gone into the characters themselves.Overall the game comprises a healthy mix of a well structured story, game play, character development all set in a cyberpunk, distopian future. If you feel this is up your alley I do recommend giving this game a go.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												Deus Ex follows on from both a Genre defining classic, and a disappointing cash-in kludge.Fortunately, though Human Revolution began by following in the footsteps of "Invisible War" with bugs and design mis-steps, notably having two levels of the game and some of the usable items ripped out to be game-store exclusives, and the entire bridghing third act yanked out to be a DLC... Not to mention the Boss Fight Thing.Human Revolution has grown up into a a sucessor to the original game: The missing levels and game section, complete with it's story and tools has been re-integrated, the graphics tweaked, bugs removed, and crucially for feel of it, you're now allowed to do more than run into a room screaming and shooting the boss characters in the face.As in the previous games, you get the chance to evade these situations and use alternate methods.Also included are Making Of and Commentary options and a new system to allow you to play through from the start with all your hard won upgrades.Sadly the Intel Intelliscreen system that was to allow you to use your phone or tablet as a controller seem to be nowhere to be found apart from as a commet that there is such a thing.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Still a great game.Lots of choice in how to approach situations, an interesting story and a very good non-lethal option.Graphically, it's distinctive, but texturing, both on characters and the environment, is spotty. While relatively high detail in most cases, it just feels a little amateurish sometimes. Character models also look a little odd, especially for characters that don't play a central part in the story.The orange/gold colour scheme can end up wearing you down too.I've never actually played the game focussing on weapons and combat, choosing the non-lethal route, so I can't comment on how gunplay feels, but stealth options are very satisfying.It is however a very long game, so doesn't lend itself to immediate replays. And this length is punishing if you're chasing achievements, particularly if you're going for one of the ones that relies on a perfect playthrough, such as Pacifist or Foxiest of the Hounds. There's no way of knowing you've failed these achievements until you've completed the game, and the systems can occasionally break beyond your control, potentially costing you the achievement.Still, the journey's a great one and the game deserves to be played

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 24, 2014
												For fans of the original title from 2000, this game is everything you could want and more. Without spoilers, the storyline was engrossing, weaving all the characters together into a network of conspiracy and intrigue. The time I needed to play through the game first-time was about 50 hours, so you're getting your $$'s worth in gaming content. The characters you encounter are memorable and unique in their own ways. (The Chinese still have bad voice-acting, but thats no negative). Social persuasion was a part of the interaction with key characters as well as in the storyline. I'll admit, some of the conversations to convince somebody got pretty intense; hearing what they have to say in response to your own.The Combat is an interesting place to address. The mechanics are largely successful in allowing varied gameplay across the missions. If you want to stealth, there are ways to stealth. If you want to be Rambo, you can be Rambo (just expect a bit tougher experience). While going Rambo can get you through a mission, the game rewards the player for being "ghostly", or not detected by the enemy. The maps and locations gave many different approaches to get to an objective or in a firefight. Vents are sometimes seen in walls to allow the hiding of bodies or escaping from fight heat.The vast array of augmentations allows the player to shape Adam Jensen into the character you feel comfortable playing as. One of the things I liked about the augmentation system is that it didn't force any down your throat. When you collect Praxis Kits for augmentation upgrades, you have the choice to apply them or not. An interesting game playthrough worth considering is a No-Aug run, where you never upgrade (out of the thoughts of Jensen's aug-opinions).Overall, after completing the game myself, I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys story-driven gameplay and well-executed stealth mechanics. Combining engrossing storyline with gameplay mechanics and player-choice, I rate this game a 9.5/10.

And, there's a lot of decisions that you make that you'd think would come back to bite you in the♥♥♥♥♥ but there's really only a select few that will serve to impede you in any way if you make the 'wrong' choice.The game is somewhat difficult if you're playing it for a stealth-based game, and pathetically easy if you're not. You can typhoon to victory, and you don't really need anything more than a 10mm pistol in the game if you're not a total ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ (but the game is notorious for HAVING NO ♥♥♥♥ING PISTOL AMMO LATER IN THE GAME SERIOUSLY WHAT THE ♥♥♥♥)

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												Deus Ex follows on from both a Genre defining classic, and a disappointing cash-in kludge.Fortunately, though Human Revolution began by following in the footsteps of "Invisible War" with bugs and design mis-steps, notably having two levels of the game and some of the usable items ripped out to be game-store exclusives, and the entire bridghing third act yanked out to be a DLC... Not to mention the Boss Fight Thing.Human Revolution has grown up into a a sucessor to the original game: The missing levels and game section, complete with it's story and tools has been re-integrated, the graphics tweaked, bugs removed, and crucially for feel of it, you're now allowed to do more than run into a room screaming and shooting the boss characters in the face.As in the previous games, you get the chance to evade these situations and use alternate methods.Also included are Making Of and Commentary options and a new system to allow you to play through from the start with all your hard won upgrades.Sadly the Intel Intelliscreen system that was to allow you to use your phone or tablet as a controller seem to be nowhere to be found apart from as a commet that there is such a thing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												Deus Ex: Human Revolution (DXHR) is the third installment in the Deus Ex series of games. This is a prequel previous to both Deus Ex and Deus Ex: Invisible War.The previous games were set in the distant future (2050's) where human augmentation is a reality, the United States is no longer a major global power, mega corporations have filled the power vacuum and conspiracies underpin all of it.DXHR is however set some twenty years earlier in 2027. You portray Adam Jensen, chief of security of Sarif Industries, a mid-sized manufacturer of human augmentations and contractor to the United States military. Along with Megan Reed your former flame and chief scientist of the same company. Along with her and CEO David Sarif, they are about to make a major announcement of a discovery that will potentially make human augmentation accessible to all and not just those who can afford the drug Neuropozyne, which is required to prevent the body from rejecting the augmentation. With the goal to enhance human lives, David Sarif sees this as the start of the next stage of human evolution.This is the initial premise of the game as shown during the introduction/tutorial of the game. Like the previous installments it is a first person shooter with stealth elements and ability to complete tasks using different paths. Deus Ex was a personal favourite of mine when I played it because you could play the game largely as you liked (main plot missions withstanding) and then experience the consequences of your actions play out accordingly. In most respects DXHR features the same gameplay elements.There are three styles of play: direct approach, indirect approach and avoiding contact altogether. For instance to open a door you can take out a guard then take the code from them, hack a computer terminal for the code or just bypass the door itself.Combat likewise has varied options with melee combat (called a takedown), an array of short to long range ballistic, energy and chemical weapons as well as the option to (depending on the weapon of choice) lethally and non-lethally taking out your opponent. Almost all weapons can be upgraded to suit your style of play as well.This of course leads to the element of the game. Augmentations can be aquired as the game progresses and allows you to essentially gain superhuman abilities over time. I won't go into specifics as this is what makes Deus Ex stand out from other FPS's. But they are well worth the wait as they help you to complete tasks in a variety of new ways.Pro's:A lot of work and attention to detail went into the in-game environments and characters to create a credible immersive experience.Excellent writing and voice work by all involved. A lot of work went into getting everything right.Amazing soundtrack by Michael McCann. Fits and enhances the atmosphere and immersion in game immensely.The game strikes the right balance between being giving you many options in-game and the tasks themselves not being too generic as is the case in other FPS sand box style games.Con's:It felt like the developers were running out of time during production as the story speeds up significantly towards the end of the game.Diehard players with feel the game helps you too much in completing a task, some visual aids can be however turned off.The animations (especially during conversations) are repeatedly used which ruins some of the work gone into the characters themselves.Overall the game comprises a healthy mix of a well structured story, game play, character development all set in a cyberpunk, distopian future. If you feel this is up your alley I do recommend giving this game a go.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												I did not know Deus Ex before i saw it on Steam. I purchased this game because it was on sale, cost only $4.99. I watch some trailers and reviews reckoned i could give it a shot. And gladly its worth the money. For starters, this game is somewhat like Mass effect + Dishonored hybrid, assuming you know both these games. You might not agree, anyways its just my opinion. But be warned, to me this isint quite a shooter game. It's an FPS, it has got a handful of guns and you can shoot things as shown in the trailer but most of the times you'll be doing lots of stealth, hiding behind covers trying to sneak past enemies. Sounds pretty familiar? (Hitman). Well if you dont like the stealth approach, you could go gun blazing, but i dont think this is the way this game is meant to be played, especially during the first half of the story which is after llike 10+ hours of gameplay (for me) mainly because you could be easily outgunned. Of course you could jump right infront of the enemies and shoot them in the face tough later in the game prior to sufficent upgrade of your carecter.So..... If you are looking for fast-paced shooter like COD, your wont get it. Its a slow-paced game involved lots of thinking as in how do i get past this, how do i access that, something like that. If you're in it for the story telling and RPG experience then i recommend you to grab it. The voice acting might not be fantastic but it works and it surely gave me a somewhat unique experience that not many games could offer.I'd love to give it a 9/10 but -1 for the graphics/visuals, so it's 8/10 ! Dont get me wrong, its graphics aren't crappy at all, is just that i adore better ones.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Still a great game.Lots of choice in how to approach situations, an interesting story and a very good non-lethal option.Graphically, it's distinctive, but texturing, both on characters and the environment, is spotty. While relatively high detail in most cases, it just feels a little amateurish sometimes. Character models also look a little odd, especially for characters that don't play a central part in the story.The orange/gold colour scheme can end up wearing you down too.I've never actually played the game focussing on weapons and combat, choosing the non-lethal route, so I can't comment on how gunplay feels, but stealth options are very satisfying.It is however a very long game, so doesn't lend itself to immediate replays. And this length is punishing if you're chasing achievements, particularly if you're going for one of the ones that relies on a perfect playthrough, such as Pacifist or Foxiest of the Hounds. There's no way of knowing you've failed these achievements until you've completed the game, and the systems can occasionally break beyond your control, potentially costing you the achievement.Still, the journey's a great one and the game deserves to be played

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2014
												Deus Ex Human Revolution is the third chapter in a legendary series that innovated genres such as stealth and rpg, and gave great freedom to the player's choices.Unlike Invisible Wars, HR, imo, is a great continuation to the series and delivers an experience on par with the original Deus Ex.To begin with, all the mechanisms of the game, from shooting to stealth and interactions, works great.Stealth is particularly important in the game and such approach is greatly rewarded by the game (as in Deus Ex).Of course, shooting is still there and is viable too.The rpg elements are well done with things like exp bonuses ,upgrading and the many different choices beign well implemented.Augmentation in HR, imo, works the best in the whole series with, at last, passive augs and a few meaningful active.Story-wise the concept is of course...CONSPIRACIES! For a few hours the player will see a corporate warfare unfold but later the story begins to broaden and eventually getting the player to choose his road.Take note that HR is a prequel to the first DE but whoever played the first 2 will get a nice treat, through easter eggs.Graphics and sound are well done too (NOTHING beats DE main theme ofc).The characters are well-written and Adam Jensen comes VERY close behind JC (maybe more in-depth than JC).All in all, DE HR is worthy of the Deus Ex title, and succeeds to do all that which IW couldn't.So I recommend this great game, especially the Director's Cut version with the redesigned bosses, for all those people who want to taste a bit of gaming history and either remember the fond times of DE or get initiated in this great universe.

content:

												A fantastic Cyberpunk RPG. While your actions in a given quest don't have the biggest impact on the overall story, the freedom and possible resolutions available within any given quest is pretty impressive. Gameplay is pretty solid; it's slower and more tactical than your average shooter, but it's executed well and blends great with the tone of the game world.The Director's Cut has some great improvements over the original, the most notable being turning off the Jarate filter, redesigning the boss fights to allow for a variety of approaches instead of forcing you into cover-shooting regardless of what your playstyle thus far was, and including the expansion as an in-built portion of the story.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												Deus Ex: Human Revolution is a prequel to Deus Ex and is the third game in the series. The main features of the game are true to their expectations, allowing you multiple ways to handle missions, varied upgrade choices and enough side stories to keep you engaged in the world around you. An explorer is rewarded as are compleitionists for the multiple difficulty settings and achievements they can receive like no kills, no detection (ghosting) and no alarms. If you waited for the discounts and all dlc included be sure to pick this up if you like Thief style genres. My only critique would be remembering  the promise of additional cities during pre-release hype but it still has enough content to be worth your steam dollars.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2015
												Deus Ex HR is personally one of my favourite games of all time, top 10 at least. Like the original Deus Ex, it's very open world before open world games became all the rage. Although the game is still driven by quests, you are given alot of latitude in how you do them. You can be mega sneaky, or run and gun, or whatever.I thought that the story was particuarly well done. You are Adam Jenson, an ex-cop who was brought back to life with cybernetics (ever seen this plot before? =) and now works for the people who designed the augmentations that saved him.As with many games of this genre, your past comes back to haunt you and everything is not what it seems, etc.The story is very long, it took me about 38 hours on easy mode (almost certainly take longer on hard mode). however, I personally loved playing it. I've always been a big fan of the cyberpunk genre and Deus Ex HR delivers in spades, with tons of augmentations you can get (some of them rather useless imho, but I suppose it all depends on your playstyle.)The plot is long and involved and eventually winds up with you having to decide the future of humanity (something else common in games I have noticed.. =)I personally thought the graphics, and especially the cutscenes were great, if you have a powerful enough computer, playing it in full 1080 is beautiful.I really can't reccommend this game highly enough, especially now that they have incorperated the DLC. My only niggle was with the inventory, which is kind of limited, but then I suppose that is sort of realistic.There are lots of weapons in the game, some great, some useless without augs, but as I said above, because it's an open world game, you get the benefit of choice.The characters are well written and the voice acting is really good, although you may find that the fact that Jenson has only one kind of voice (deep and husky, sort of menacing, like some action movie stars.. =) gets a bit samey after a while.Still the only things I can fault in this game are very small things that are really just a matter of personal taste.Overall, if you like cyberpunk and you like FPS and stealth, then grab this game.99/100 Would doom the world again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2015
												While reading my review, please keep in mind that I never played the original Deus Ex games.I went into this game thinking it would be your every day shooter game with average story and decent game mechanics. What I got was something much more pleasing. Deus Ex: Human Revolution has got to be one of my most favorite games of all time. Every penny I spent on this game was well worth it and I will never forget the experience Human Revolution has given me.The game takes place in the future where robotic limbs and augmentation is possible. A lot of thought went into this concept as you've got the pro-life supporters stating that augmentation is wrong and that you shouldn't do anything to your body. On the other hand you've got those who support human augmentation stating that this is how the human race will evolve. You play as Adam Jensen- a security guard. You used to be "fully human" without any augmentations until a day came where you were attacked by an augmented human and left nearly for dead. Practically every limb in Jensen's body has been replaced due to the severity of the attack he barely lived through.6 months fly by and you are called in again to help stop those responsible for the attack on Serif Industries and get revenge on those that made you what you are. The story is rich and deep- and the characters are very memorable. Adam questions if he is still human, or something more. As mentioned- the developers put a lot of thought into the story of this game and it stands out. I haven't played the game in months and I still remember the story as if I played the game yesterday.The game mechanics are wonderful. It's more of stealth game or taking enemies out one by one than anything. Adam is not a Call of Duty soldier by any means and can't step into a middle of a room unprotected. The game requires strategy. You can tackle a level in several different way whether you try and go in fully stealthy or take out enemies every time they are encountered. You are rewarded in XP for exploring or not being seen at all or not killing enemies but rather, knocking them out. The more you level or find certain collectibles to upgrade your augments, the more you can do with them. For instance, you couldn't fall from a certain height without dying unless you got enough XP to purchase the Icarus upgrade which would allow you to fall from any height and not be hurt let alone die. Or you can't lift anything with the exception of like a remote unless you put XP into an upgrade that would allow you to move heavy things such as dumpsters. A great concept that makes the game challenging or sometimes making you wish you put your upgrade into some other augmentation based on the current situation you are in. The game has branching paths. You can choose certain dialogue options and some of these options do have an impact on how the mission progresses or ends. You'll have speech checks that if you fail- could be the death of a hostage or information being withheld from you. Speaking certain things or asking questions helps you understand the story more. I've never been more interest in doing side quests and reading emails and everything as I have with Human Revolution. This game makes you want to complete the side quests. This game makes you want to explore and find out every little secret that you can find out about. And if that wasn't enough, the soundtrack to this game is beautiful and well compose and fits Human Revolution perfectly.Don't go into this game thinking you are a super soldier who can soak up bullets. You might be a very augmented individual- but you are still human and can take damage like crazy if you are careless. The best strategy of this game is to go in stealthy or taking enemies out one by one when necessary. Strategy is going to be your best friend in this game. If this is not your play style or you aren't willing to play that kind of play style, don't get this game. However- if you are looking for a great story with lots of lore to get into along with great game mechanics, I cannot recommend this game enough.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 12, 2016
												Much like the humans in this world who augment their bodies and minds to gain an upper hand in society, Deus Ex: Human Revolution aspires to be greater than other videogames on the market, and it succeeds impeccably. You are Adam Jensen an augmented cyber security agent for the world’s leading augmented research corporation Sarif Industries. Your goal is to solve who is behind a serious of terror attacks on the company by any means necessary. However, just because you are given the tools of the gods does not mean you should necessarily utilize them. Deus Ex is a game about choice and unlike other games that advertise choice as a key aspect of the game and fail to deliver Deus Ex delivers it, and with a cyber fueled bang! You influence the story and you decide your play style whether it involves becoming a sneaky hacker or a near indestructible cyber death machine, there is no hand holding or hints of what the game wants you to do, make your choices and live with your consequences. Whether that means changing the course of a characters path into an ill-fated direction or not properly preparing for a mission and getting destroyed by your opponents it’s all up to you. The story takes an immense amount of shocking turns as it stacks the stakes with every second you play the game resulting in an ending where based on your perceptions of the world you decide what the best course of action for its survival, and boy is this world something. Resembling the light on shadow styles of renaissance paintings Deus Ex strongly resembles a crumbling Sci-fi dystopia somewhere along the lines of Blade Runner or Dredd with a mesmerizing soundtrack and a hypnotizing environment. Deus Ex: Human Revolution is truly fire stolen straight from the gods.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 5, 2016
												If you are wondering whether to buy this game or not, just do it. I can assure you that you won't be disappointed.And if you decide to buy it then keep playing it until you finish it. The first 2 hours of the game aren't that interesting, but it gets so much better. The reason why i like it so much is because you choose how you want to play. You can play lethal guns blazing or maybe some nonlethal stealth, maybe you want to play the whole game without hurting anyone. (With the exception of the bosses.) The choice is yours. The choices you make isn't just limited to the type of playstyle you have but also what you choose to say in the dialogue sections. Speaking of which, the moral choices you make are really tough decisions and they definetly have an impact on the storyline. I found myself thinking about what to do a lot, and I kept doing that until the end. I didn't know if I made the right decisions. Not many games will make me question my outlook on life and my morals, but this game opened my eyes to problems that might actually happen in the future. That is really cool.It does have it's problems though, for example; The boss fights are boring and unnecessary, the guns are a bit clunky (Barely used guns anyway but still), the lack of a fast travel system made side quests a bit of a chore (Even though the actual side quests where really interesting) and I personally didn't enjoy the the first couple hours of the game.I would rate this game: I never asked fo this/10Keep in my mind that these are my personal opinions and nobody else's.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6, 2014
												Deus Ex: Human Revolution is a prequel to the original Deus Ex game and follows the story of Adam Jensen, a security chief at an augmentation (cybernetic implantation) industry, who finds himself augmented against his will and put against a myterious conspiracy he must discover and twhart in time.The story of Human Revolution keeps itself interesting for the whole game, with a very clever portrait of technology advancements debates, few cameos from characters of Deus Ex and a good bunch of original protagonists. As with every Deus Ex title there is a lot of reading and exploring to do for players who really want to dig further in the game's setting: doing so even awards you nice chunks of experience every time.Gameplay-wise, one must say that Human Revolution offers less freedom of action than its predecessor. While in the original Deus Ex you could go around destroying anyone and anything or decide to either incapacitate or plain evade both regular enemies without any consequence, truly allowing you to slowly build your own way to overcome the game's challenges, this sequel still gives you the same amount of freedom, but turns the table more in favor of an action-packed approach. Each boss encounter requires you to kill your enemy and every one of them are very durable augmented agents that will torn apart a player that relayed only on stealth and evasion up to that point. You can't run away either. There are also several instances in the game where going full killing mode against your enemies is required to achieve certain results.The Director's Cut DLC tried to fix such design choices by adding to the bosses arenas more way to eliminate them with indirect means. However, it's worth mentioning that you still HAVE to kill them and they have been severly buffed up from the first version of the game, to the point that even trying to off them with hacking or unconventional means is very hard without some protective or straight combat augs.The Missing Link DLC is a four hours worthy new content that was fully integrated in the main story of Human Revolution with the Director's Cut. The DLC takes place on a Belltower cargo ship, the Hei Zhen Zhu, and requires you to find and neutralize the local mercenary leader in order to continue your main story to Singapore. Whyle the ship features very crampy environments, the whole DLC still feels like a Deus Ex game, with plenty of alternative options to choose from. The final boss of the Missing Link is also much more Deus-Ex-esque than the ones from the vanilla game.I would totally reccomend Deus Ex: Human Revolution due to its outsanding story and gameplay united with a huge replay value that allows you to experience a different kind of game every time you decide how to deal with the enemies and the other NPCS your own special way differently

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
Pros:+ Challenging, enjoyable gameplay+ Massively variant playstyles possible+ High replayability+ Good amount of content+ Stealth system is fantastic+ Open combat is also good+ Many different approaches to each challenge+ Compelling storyline+ Polished final productCons:- Slight railroading due to episodic content- Boss fights require you to kill (Deus Ex heresy)- Pacing problemsOverall: The third installment in the Deus Ex game series is a prequel to the first game.  The premise is that you're Adam Jensen, a bionic security guard given top of the line mechanical enhancements.  These enhancements function as your "character growth", allowing you to become a better hacker, gun slinger, stealth fighter, tank, or any other plethora of fun upgrades.  It's a cool system that's been refined across several Deus Ex games, and it works perfectly.  Graphically the game is very stylized, with the world having tints of gold to it everywhere, making the game immersive in its own way.The downsides are fairly minor.  In every previous Deus Ex game, it was possible to finish the game without ever taking a life.  In this game, there are a few boss fights, all of which require you to kill your opponent.  This takes away from the novelty of never killing anyone in a combat-oriented game.  The storyline stops in the middle to do a side story that was DLC for the original game, and which was released in a package deal for the Director's Cut.  In it, you're stripped of your biomodifications and forced to finish the side story before you can come back to the main tale.  This disrupts the pacing quite a bit, but the side story is still fun.  Finally, the game is fairly linear, with several side quests in addition to the main goal of each area.  However, you can't really go backwards or choose where the next area is.All in all, this does not take away from any of the game's charm, however.  It's still fun to play through it without setting off alarms, or without killing, or by killing absolutely everything.  It's a polished game that's fun to play several times through.Bottom Line: Definitely recommend.  This is one of those priceless games that I keep coming back to over and over again.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2013
												Phew - finally done with the replay of DX. While it is fun to knock out people again, it is just the same game with a sharper / clearer image plus the Missing Link DLC added into it  - IMO I didn't really see much differences. Never have issues with the boss fights previously so I don't really see much even if it is changed a bit in this Director's Cut.Pros: *Above average storyline (provided you haven't played it before)*Good gameplay with either fun stealth features or average shooting/weapons to rush through it all*Good music (at least good enough for me to go download some of them =D)Cons:*Chat options doesn't affect the main storyline much (there are multiple endings but it is not really related to chat options)*Not much replay value (one run to do it all and I am removing this after 100%)*So-so AI (turning up the difficulty doesn't do much to me except increasing damage by guards and longer detection cooldown time)*A little bit repetitive on the hacking/sneaking if you are trying to max out on the experience Summary:While I might stated a few cons, it is still a good game that deserves your time if you haven't played/gotten it yet - especially after how cheap it is now. However if I can choose again, I probably won't be bothered to buy the Director's Cut, the plain vanilla + Missing Link DLC is more than sufficient. If you have not gotten any of the vanilla etc before, wait till Director's Cut get discounted and get it straight.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 5, 2015
"IT'S NOT THE END OF THE WORLD, BUT YOU CAN SEE IT FROM HERE"Deus Ex: Human Revolution (more especifically the Director's Cut) was one of my first games on Steam. A gift, I was actually a bit hesitant on accepting as I've never been a big fan of FPS. The RPG part made me go through the download size and didn't quite prepare me for the stealth. I believe it's more accurate to call DX:HR a stealth with FPS and RPG elements, as the first is the most proeminent trait.As Adam Jensen, you're tasked with security in Sarif Inustries, a top notch corporation specialized in augmentations. Not too long after you started, however, the matrix (located in a 2027 Detroit) is attacked by a mysterious black ops squad and a number of questions rise as you're basically resuscitated by your employer. Seems like your typical cyberpunk setting, except it feels more realistic, more relatable. The secrets you come to know during Adam's journey for answers and revenge easily get you involved while one question is answered and another one is made. And as any person asking the dangerous questions, Adam does so mostly in the shadows. Even though the game offers a large range of strategical approaches and paths, the stealth mechanic can be more rewarding and fulfilling, not to mention lore friendly. On higher difficulties keeping a low profile is actually necessary as augmentations aren't enough to withstand a bulletstorm. Fear not, though, as you can literally be a ghost by taking full advantage of the incredible level design!Not only the story is well written and filled with branches, but the artwork and soundtrack are some of the most relatable and beautiful in recent game history. The architecture feels unique and real, while the soundtrack tries to unite a feeling of old and new by mixing classic notes with electronic beats. It's easy to dive into Deus Ex's universe and get lost in its mature themes, such as transhumanism.Even though the experience is one worth having, it's still far from perfect. The Director's Cut came with a number of performance issues and bugs that -- after almost four years of the game's first release -- haven't yet been fixed by the developers. The game performers poorly on computers above its rcommended specifications and fixing it is no easy task. Still to this day there's no definitive method for AMD users to get completely rid of stuttering and small FPS drops, not to mention a proper (official or from the community) fix for the various bugs that lurk around the corners -- one of which got me frustrated and made me leave the game aside for more than a year. This might be one of those cases where you have to ignore the performance issues to fully enjoy the game, as DX:HR-DC is not a proper PC title/port.Pros:  Friendly to newcomers of the franchise  Very sharp stealth mechanics aligned with a decent AI  RPG elements with the augmentations upgrades  The player is not constantly forced to make use of the FPS mechanics  Large variety of paths and strategies within a single level  Intelligent hacking mechanic  Immersive cyberpunk setting with a deep story, mature context and complex, relatable characters  Beautiful design and soundtrack  Hard and meaningful choices that matter  Multiple endings  Adam's dark pastCons:  Performance issues  Bugs -- lots of them  AMD users might have more difficulty in fixing problems  No "auto-sort" in the inventory  Too many endings (a total of twelve)If you like cyberpunk themes and stealth games, Deus Ex: Human Revolution is a safe bet. And even if you're not particularly interested in what the game has to offer, it might surprise you!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 5, 2015
"IT'S NOT THE END OF THE WORLD, BUT YOU CAN SEE IT FROM HERE"Deus Ex: Human Revolution (more especifically the Director's Cut) was one of my first games on Steam. A gift, I was actually a bit hesitant on accepting as I've never been a big fan of FPS. The RPG part made me go through the download size and didn't quite prepare me for the stealth. I believe it's more accurate to call DX:HR a stealth with FPS and RPG elements, as the first is the most proeminent trait.As Adam Jensen, you're tasked with security in Sarif Inustries, a top notch corporation specialized in augmentations. Not too long after you started, however, the matrix (located in a 2027 Detroit) is attacked by a mysterious black ops squad and a number of questions rise as you're basically resuscitated by your employer. Seems like your typical cyberpunk setting, except it feels more realistic, more relatable. The secrets you come to know during Adam's journey for answers and revenge easily get you involved while one question is answered and another one is made. And as any person asking the dangerous questions, Adam does so mostly in the shadows. Even though the game offers a large range of strategical approaches and paths, the stealth mechanic can be more rewarding and fulfilling, not to mention lore friendly. On higher difficulties keeping a low profile is actually necessary as augmentations aren't enough to withstand a bulletstorm. Fear not, though, as you can literally be a ghost by taking full advantage of the incredible level design!Not only the story is well written and filled with branches, but the artwork and soundtrack are some of the most relatable and beautiful in recent game history. The architecture feels unique and real, while the soundtrack tries to unite a feeling of old and new by mixing classic notes with electronic beats. It's easy to dive into Deus Ex's universe and get lost in its mature themes, such as transhumanism.Even though the experience is one worth having, it's still far from perfect. The Director's Cut came with a number of performance issues and bugs that -- after almost four years of the game's first release -- haven't yet been fixed by the developers. The game performers poorly on computers above its rcommended specifications and fixing it is no easy task. Still to this day there's no definitive method for AMD users to get completely rid of stuttering and small FPS drops, not to mention a proper (official or from the community) fix for the various bugs that lurk around the corners -- one of which got me frustrated and made me leave the game aside for more than a year. This might be one of those cases where you have to ignore the performance issues to fully enjoy the game, as DX:HR-DC is not a proper PC title/port.Pros:  Friendly to newcomers of the franchise  Very sharp stealth mechanics aligned with a decent AI  RPG elements with the augmentations upgrades  The player is not constantly forced to make use of the FPS mechanics  Large variety of paths and strategies within a single level  Intelligent hacking mechanic  Immersive cyberpunk setting with a deep story, mature context and complex, relatable characters  Beautiful design and soundtrack  Hard and meaningful choices that matter  Multiple endings  Adam's dark pastCons:  Performance issues  Bugs -- lots of them  AMD users might have more difficulty in fixing problems  No "auto-sort" in the inventory  Too many endings (a total of twelve)If you like cyberpunk themes and stealth games, Deus Ex: Human Revolution is a safe bet. And even if you're not particularly interested in what the game has to offer, it might surprise you!

content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
												Background: Big fan of the original, love stealth games and the Bladerunner cyberpunk genre.The Good:* Interesting plot and missions* Real options for both stealth and assault * Interesting powers change gameplay* World looks great and lived in* Large, well planned sandbox type maps* Long and varied location campaign* Feels a lot like a solo Mass Effect missionThe Bad:* Bland character models and stiff animations* Stealth sections are far too easy with obvious routes and dumb cameras* Weapons and upgrades lack impact* Buggy quests make completion impossible* Hacking mechanic is boring & characters ignore you stealing from them* Sandbox play makes for nonsensical conversations* Map system is oddly weak in a technological future* NPCs speak as if you aren't standing there and totally ignore you doing awesome featsImpressions: I really liked the experience despite some terrible lack of refinement and  buggy gameplay. The stealth options are a blast even if the enemy is really easy to predict.Recommended for: sci-fi stealth fans.Conclusion.7/10. Despite it's flaws it's a lot of fun to play and not being too taxing always keep you moving forward.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2015
												If you're like me - old - you played the first Deus Ex and you found it amazing. So when you approached Deus Ex: HR you probably thought: "This stinks, the first one is obviously better, they don't make good videogames anymore blah blah".Well my friend you're wrong, because Deus Ex: HR is a pleasure. Gameplay wise it's ok, it's more hide-and-shoot than I hoped it to be, but it plays smooth and you quickly find yourself breezing through vents like solid snake. Graphics are good: not amazing, but the areas are full of details. Great care was used during the design - especially the city hubs. They are basically the same stuff, yet they FEEL so different.The story and the environment are legendary. I'm not gonna talk about it, because I haven't finished it yet and because everything is a major spoiler, but the environment is really, REALLY immersive.The conflict between people seeing augmentations as progress, and the ones seeing them as something that curses you to live under medications for the rest of your life is excellent. Whenever you feel you're doing something right, something else happens and you're all like: "What if I was wrong all along...?"This, THIS is what Deus Ex: HR is all about for me. The struggle, the insecurity, the feeling you COULD do something for someone, but you're never sure if you SHOULD do it.A beautiful game so far. Feels just like the original. And the protagonist is quite likeable.

You free to do in it whatever you want.The dialogues. GOD I ♥♥♥♥ING LOVE'EM. Instead of COD breaching you can actually TALK with your enemies and try to convience them to stop what they're doing.Exploring. You get rewarded if you explore the action-bubbles.Augmentation. Watch the trailers and you know what I'm talking about :p2nd playthrough. If you play DE:HR second/third time, you start with the augmentation which you bought in the last playthrough. Best feature ever.Why you SHOULDN'T buy DE:HRThe boss fights. You have to kill 3 bosses through out the game.WHAT ARE YOU WAITING FOR. BUY IT!!
