content:
Posted: May 15, 2016
												Despite rather aging graphics, it is the aesthetic design that really makes me like the overall design of the game. Dark colors  often reflected by strong, vibrant lightning. Curiously, I found the main campaign to be boiler-plate AAA design, while the side missions were a little bit more interesting. Furthermore, while main character changes location from time-to-time, the areas look rather similar, but that can be personal thing. Gameplay is as good as it ever was; no complaints outside few bugs and some aiming problems that seem to appear when in small areas. Experience/Progression system is interesting, but player becomes pretty much master of everything in the end. Speaking of the ending, pretty awful cop out. I dont know what it is, but this may seem like a review that I'd recommend, but it really is. Its the atmosphere, combined with excellent combat mechanics and suitable graphical design that really makes this game very good indeed. Word of warning thou, if you appreciate graphical fidelity, this game may not be for you anymore.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2014
												Very great game, this was the first Deus Ex game I have played, and so I have started playing the others. Although I have noticed how "easy" this game is compared to the others... but that can dealt with by going through the settings and disabling a few things here and there. It definitely has a great storyline and it is amazing compared to other video games I have played. They have created this universe so realistically well that it actually feel it could happen. In the DIrector's Cut edition of the game, it adds in The Missing Link DLC and another DLC-thingy with weapons and such. The Missing Link suprisingly was implemented well into the game, and I loved it. It delved farther into the discovery of the conspiracy behind the "Tyrants" and such. And, the art style for this game is truly magnificient. It has that "cyberpunk noire" with the gleaming yellow lights and the triangularly-shaped objects most commonly seen give off a deep sense of some sort of movement, or revolution as you will, from modern times into a new future. I was a bit dissapointed in the Director's Cut when they lowered down the yellowness in the game. But it sorta balanced out my mood with the added in weapons. This game has made me move on to read the book Deus Ex: Icarus Effect and also play Deus Ex 1! Very amazing game.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												The Deus Ex Series has had tremendous ups and downs over it's lifespan.  It began with the critically acclaimed Deus Ex, but that was followed by the widely panned Deus Ex: Invisible War.  A straight up FPS sequel was under development at the time of Invisible War's release named Deus Ex: Clan Wars, but was retooled and released as Project Snowblind.It wouldn't be until 2011 that Deus Ex would finally see a worthy sequel in Deus Ex: Human Revolution, well...actually it's a prequel, so the wait's still going on in that department.The Director's Cut isn't a tremendous upgrade over the original, the largest difference is the inclusion of "The Missing Link", a challenging DLC for the original game.  With or without The Missing Link however, this is still a tremendously fun game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 2, 2015
												Deus Ex is a game where you uncover a deep and mysterious, yet believable story behind a growing world of biotechnology.You play the role of a security specialist named Adam Jensen who works in a firm that develops augmentations to restore or enhance human capabilities. Jensen sees his life turn around for the worst when his company suffers from a terrorrist attack, leaving him in a coma for 6 months and forcing him to use that same biotechnology to prevent him from dying and take his revenge against the criminals.The best thing in Deus Ex is that your choices matter, the way the objectives are approached is rewarded differently as you complete both the main story and the side-missions. Use brute force or stealth, it's all up to you.27 hours of pure entertainment and gaming quality with plenty of replay value to easily double that amount.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 9, 2014
												One of the most interesting games in recent years. Deus Ex: HR thrusts you into an immersive, highly detailed and interactive, deeply conflicted, and plausible future world that asks many questions about where technology will lead us, but doesn't give clear cut answers. Not only is it thought provoking, but the blend of stealth action and role-playing is second to none. Choices matter and you'll often find yourself in really intense scenarios, for which the outcome is ultimately decided by the player.This game thankfully avoids many game design pitfalls, and really shines because of it.  The plot is elievable the whole way and doesn't push your suspension of disbelief too much, which is rare for games... and movies and TV shows too.  The character development is noteworthy, the story is quite easy to relate to I find.  The stealth gameplay is a bit more rewarding and enjoyable than combat, but the player can choose either one or both whenever they feel like it.  It has much bigger, more content heavy hubs than the original, and overall far more detailed level design.  It has a bit less "choice and consequence" than the original though, along with a more serious and mature tonality.

content:
Posted: March 16, 2016
												This is one of the best games I have ever played. It combines the best stealth mechanics of the metal gear solid games, the cover based shooting of any modern 3rd person shooter, and one of the best narratives since Bioshock. The mechanics are similar to the system shock series, with spending points to upgrade your augmentations and the same inventory system. The shooting and stealth provide enough of a challenge to make you not feel like a tank, and the behind-the-scenes stuff and extra missions are exemplary. Every decision you make influences the world around you, whether it be through rewards, subtly different endings, or dialogue. It makes you feel like you are a part of the world, and I would give this game a 9 out of 10 stars.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 3, 2016
												The dev team thought of everything.Other reviews can praise this game's stealth, combat, upgrades, art, characters, and story, I just want to show my appreciation for the sheer amount of player choice in this game. Sometimes I was flabbergasted after a mission, going back through the level and realizing just how impressive its design was in terms of making sure that you can get through it ANY way you want to. Pacifict? Check. Terminator? Check. Hacker? Scavenger? Little-of-everything? All of the above. I loved it.And more than just the amount of choice was the implementation. I've said in other reviews that what I want in a game is one where the challenge comes from fighting the bad guys, not from fighting the controls. 99% of everything I tried in this game was a fair challenge. No shoddy, sloppy work. I push the button; thing happens the way it's supposed to. And there were plenty of times when I had a nutty idea and thought, 'Can I do that?' Yes I could. Punch civilians in the head! Throw turrets into the sea! Make modern art with piles of unconscious enemies! Steal EVERYTHING!My only real complaint was with the implanted DLC. While I did grow to enjoy it by the end, (especially Quinn), at times it felt uneccesary and shoehorned in, and there were parts when the writing was bizarrely sexist. Oh well. Once I got off the boat it was back to the main game and everything was fine again.Overall, DXHR is going in my favorites list. I look forward to New Game+. The D-Row Ballers won't know what hit 'em.P.S. Major congrats to Adam Jensen's voice actor. The Neo-esque gravelly growl could have easily been monotone and emotionless, but he managed to put a ton of subtle personality into the performance. Often through taking the lines as read, and knowing exactly which words to punch emphasis into. Kudos!

content:
Posted: May 28, 2015
												Deus Ex: Human Revolution is a surprisingly good game.I'd been told it was a good game previously, but never had a chance to try it out. By the time I remembered about the game, it was a few years after release and the graphics looked somewhat dated and I was foolish enough to give the game a skip based on that.Then a friend of mine offered me a spare copy of the game going free, so I thought 'Ack, why the heck not!' and installed with haste. I played it straight over the following three days, putting 25.8 hours into the game, completing it on the hardest difficulty (or at least, the hardest available. I think there might be an even harder level now available after completing the game).Oh boy, it was good.Problem was, I went through the entire game without killing anyone. Or so I thought. Then I remembered I shot someone in the tutorial. Whoops. Oh well, just an achievement.The game was rather easy to play, especially if you play non-lethal ghost. I've not tried out going loud - I suspect it'd be much harder, considering the amount of damage they deal on harder difficulties. So one might want to take that into mind. Gameplay wise the game is above average - it's not exactly a great shooter, but the stealth is decent enough. It could be improved and I hope in the new game they make the combat a little more intuitive and/or realistic. But there will always be more one can want.Yet what makes it great is the world and the story, and how people react to your actions. It feels nice when people comment about your lack of lethal use throughout the game - and, without spoiling anything, saving certain characters also happens to have a significant impact on the game too.Obviously in my review, however basic it may be, I'm biased to a degree because I didn't actually purchase the game - but having played it, I would've bought it (at sale price, because I'm stingy) had I know what the game was actually like to player.P.S. IlluminatiP.S.S. Thanks Zero!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2016
												This may very well be one of the longest reviews I will ever write...First off, I'll admit it. When I first played Deus Ex: Human Revolution, I didn't like it at all. I found the game to be boring and difficult. It may also have something to do with the fact that I first played this on the Playstation 3, but I digress. The fact is, this game is probably unlike any other game I've ever played in my life.You play as Adam Jensen, an ex-cop now working for Sarif Industries, a massive company that is pretty much the poster-boy for cyberpunk mega-conglomerates. When the company is about to move to a new location, it gets hit by a terrorist attack, leaving Jensen near-death while he watches his lover, Megan Reed, get killed. In typical Robocop fashion, he is rebuilt using  AUGMENTATIONS™  . Six months later, he is back at the company, and is now on a quest to discover the truth of what really happened that fateful night.As far as presentation goes, I've heard a lot of people give this game a hard time for having a consistently yellow/orange aesthetic to it. Personally, I didn't mind this that much, and thought the game looked fine. Actually, I'd say that in a lot of areas, the game looks fantastic, especially on some of the later levels. (I personally thought that the penthouse level was absolutely gorgeous) There's so many fine details in every nook and cranny in this game, that it really makes the game look and feel like it's own universe. Of course, looking at the Final Fantasy games, this is to be expected from Square Enix. If I really have any complaints, I thought that the characters sometimes felt a bit robotic, and the lip-syncing can kinda get screwy at times. However, this is a pretty small problem that can be overlooked.I say that because, for the most part, the voice actors really do a good job; putting a lot of effort forth for some pretty riveting dialogue at times. I personally thought that the voice actor of Jensen, Elias Toufexis, did an amazing job potraying his role. As a matter of fact, the sound design in most of the game is actually really good; the guns sound like they have a punch to them, and of course, a bunch of little details here and there that, again, make this game truly come to life. Now, when it comes to the music, it ranges from "pretty good" to "♥♥♥♥ing incredible". Some of the tracks on here are an audible feast. I just hope that Mankind Divided has just as good of a soundtrack, if not better.In typical Deus Ex fashion, you are given a wide array of choices and methods of getting past levels. You can go in guns blazing, sneak around Metal Gear style and take out enemies quickly and quietly, you can hack turrets, turn off security cameras, and you can even go through levels quietly without killing anybody, if you'd like. And that's not even all you can do. Throughout the game, you get Praxis points which you can use to level up your augmentations. You can spend these on new abilities, such as seeing through walls, being able to hack harder terminals, to fall any height without taking damage, lift heavy objects such as vending machines and dumpsters, and much more. Jensen controls pretty solidly, so you won't have too much trouble pulling off any play style you wish to go in with. Out of all of these, I'd say that Hacking is probably an essential skill to level up, as the game is extremely difficult without it. There's actually a hacking minigame this time around instead of waiting for the ICE Breaker bar to deplete. It's not incredibly hard, and it does add tension to the game at times, because the world around you doesn't freeze when you're in hacking, so keep an eye on your surroundings before you hack something.Personally, I don't think you need to play the first Deus Ex in order to appreciate this one, as it is a prequel to the first one. Even if you aren't familiar with the first game at all, I think this game is well-crafted enough for a large number of people to enjoy.If I have any other complaints, is that there are some sections of this game that do get extremely frustrating. This may have been a foul-up on my part, but still, some parts of this game had me FURIOUS. I personally think this is one of the best games of the 2010's. It's action-packed, it's smart, and it's a pretty lengthy game if you're into that sort of thing. I finally clocked in at about 16 hours when I did my first playthrough of this game. It's one hell of a ride.10 augmented, cyberpunk, haXX0r McLovin's out of 10.

												Ultimate badassery, beautiful soundtrack, amazing graphics, interesting and intriguing story... This game is a must-have for everyone, who isn't allergic to cyberpunk and renaissance.The best thing for me is stealth. Or just go invisible. Poof! You hate stealth? Non problemo. Pick up a rocket launcher or laser rifle and have fun, brother. Maybe more close combat? Pick someone's back and kill him with the blades, coming from your arms. It's up for you to decide...The boss fights are also improved. Now you can kill them without shooting - hack the turret, hack the gas tubes, hack the robots and use them for your advantage. Adam Jensen is badass <3

content:
Posted: March 10, 2016
												Short Version:Everything is orange. Everything can kill you quickly with well-placed headshots, so get in cover. The cover system is clunky. The lethal guns are fun. Not enough explosions or destruction for me. The story is meh and hte game feels a little short... But still nice.7/10 would reccomend to buy on sale, but is still great either way.Long version:Everything is clunky, but ok in it's own odd way, and every gun in the game is useful (at least the lethal ones, I didn't bother with silly concepts like "restraint" or "stealth and subtlty" or "mercy" or "doing the right thing." :P) I blasted my way through the game and had fun getting yelled at by every character who had a problem with it (I only wish you could flip them off more often.)I found myself dying and reloading saves often, and my advice is to use the weapons you have now, and not bother with sparing ammunition. You'll almost always have the resources to spare, especially near the end of the game where you're an expert at placing one-hit-kill headshots on your enemies like no tomorrow. So seriously! Hurl that grenade, don't stash it! You'll miss out on all the fun if you're just using the pistol all the time or saving your superpower energy!I kind of wish the game's story was a little clearer. I still don't know what Adam's initial mission was- something about figuring out who's behind a terrorist attack at the Sans Serif Font Building or something. The relationship between Adam and the girlfriend was shoehorned into the plot, and Adam Jensen's voice actor doesn't emote half the time, and needs a throat lozenge (seriously, it's really bad. I reflexively cringe half the time that he talks.)All three endings to the game (without spoiling anything) are just essentially slideshows, like Fallout.Unsorted thoughts on the game:-Alcohol blurrs the screen really badly, and it's unreasonable. It's also hard to use items in your inventory. You would think that sorting your inventory by clicking and dragging would be easy, but somehow it's not. Using items that aren't on your hotbar requres the use of a dropdown menu, like you're in windows Explorer. Even dropping items.-Your inventory gets pretty small, even when you can upgrade it. It would be kind of fun to not have to worry about inventory space, like in Half Life, but meh.-Everything is orange. I suggest downloading a mod to remove the silly orange filter, because it gets kind of annoying, especially when you get to the China area.The city hubs are a little... Dull. Not a lot of things going on, just lots of people standing around in the street. There are two city hubs: Detroit, and Generic China Future City with bad stereotypical accents. I hate "China City Who's Name I've Already Forgotten." It's layout is like a maze, and you get lost easily, even with a map and a compass. A simple task of getting from objective to objective turns into a game of wandering until you find the right path.Mine templates are useless. It's hard to gauge how far a thrown weapon will go, and sometimes you'll have to throw a second grenade because you missed. Stores don't sell enough ammo. There's not enough superpowers, but the ones you have are awesome.The cover system is really poorly implemented, and sometimes it doesn't even work right in firefights- jerking your gun around suddenly or in directions that you didn't expect.Even with full armor upgrades, a pointblank shotgun blast will still almost always kill you in a single hit. This makes the game unforgivingly hard.One last note: I -HATE- the sprint function. You run for literally three seconds at maybe 10% faster speed, then have to wait three seconds to recharge it. Sure, you can spend valuable exp on expanding that sprint by two increments of 2.5 seconds each, but it doesn't do much of anything.All in all, a flawed gem.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												Although heavily plagued with game-breaking bugs, this combined role-playing cloak-and-carbine first person shooter really revives, revamps, and reconstructs every single criterion that defined the timeless Deus Ex series. Well-designed stealth system, choice of non-lethal pacifism or brutal kill-everyone gameplay, extreme dark dystopian Gattaca+Bladerunner style speculative fiction setting, easy-to-control COD style weapon aiming, cyborg-level customisable character leveling, and most importantly the power to manipulate the entire plot, storyline, boss-fight conditions and final outcome implicitly and cumulatively via emotionally-intensive multiple-choice dialogues throughout each mission. As the title indicates, this game really tests the limits of what it means to be "human" philosophically. +1337 points for  actually calling the antagonists The Illuminati. ILLUMINATI CONFIRMED.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
												Deus Ex: Human Revolution - Director's Cut (Spoiler Free Review)I own both base Deus Ex: Human Revolution (DE:HR) and the Director's Cut version.  It was a game I enjoyed so much that I bought it twice.  I am reviewing the Director's Cut version since it appears to be the only version you can get anymore on steam.  Please read my full review but to cut to the chase, DE:HR was really the better game.  The only reason I am recommending the Director's Cut is the experience the game provides.     (Story)"They say they saved me, but I'm not sure saved is the right word".  In the not too distant future, mankind has pushed the limits of human existence.  Prosthetics and biomedical engineering have reached unprecedented levels.  People can even freely choose to be "augmented", or have technology put into their body to give them some kind of edge or replace a lost limb.  Unfortunately, Adam Jensen (the character you embody) does not get to choose and is instead augmented in an effort to save his life.  As Chief of Security for a large biomedical firm, you are caught in between your allegiance to your business colleagues and the opposition who view your augs as unnatural.  Adam rubs elbows with politicians, gangsters, and everyone in between to uncover the culprit behind a violent act of espionage conducted against his employer.  Adam also investigates the death of his girlfriend all the while coming to terms with his new condition.  The Director's Cut version includes the Missing Link DLC, except it is inserted into the story in its logical place and you have to play thorugh it to beat the game.  While Missing Link does allow you to unlock and upgrade nearly every augmentation Adam has, it adds little to the main story and you only get the big reward once you finish it (and finishing it is a little tedious).  (Gameplay)The game is first person with a third person cover mechanic.  Stealth, hacking, or a guns-blazing approach are all valid for combat and all are just as fun due to the variety when it comes to weapons and augmentations.  As you play, Adam gains XP which is used to upgrade his augmentations so there are RPG like elements, including an inventory.  You can literally play this game through without killing anyone, choosing to focus on exploration, social, and hacking type augs.  At various times, you will have to engage in dialogue and choose responses.  This is what makes the DE:HR experience: living with the decisions you make during a conversation, especially if you cost someone their life.  Players will face many a dilemma and that is what makes this game great.  Many side missions are optional but all feel relevant and some provide hefty rewards for the dedicated player.  The DLC will strip you of most your augmentations in an attempt to make you vulnerable and force stealth.  Director's Cut also adds several new weapons and different ways to defeat the game's bosses.   (Design)As other reviewers mention, DE:HR had a unique look about it.  A golden haze shoruded certain environments and textures looked more detailed.  The game features several unique locales, all of which are industrial, futuristic, cosmopolitan, corporate type environments with their own flavor.  Attention was paid to each one and it is nice to just listen to NPC's converse with one another.  From the clothes to the interior design, the game oozes cyber punk.  Director's Cut by comparison looks noticeably different and not in a good way.  Textures were muddier in my experience and faces looked waxy.  I never had sound issues with either version of the game, though you may have to tweak the video settings.  The DLC has an interesting part where you are on a ship in a storm but this was my favorite part of it since the remainder is spent in closed quarters that feel gray.  The DLC has very little in the way of new dialogue and its characters are not as memorable as the main game's.(Final Comments)DE:HR is an excellent Deus Ex game with interesting characters and great design.  Gameplay can be clunky at times but is fun for the most part.  DE:HR is a contender for my favorite game of all time and I enjoyed every minute of it.  It's too bad you cannot buy the base DE:HR anymore through steam otherwise I'd recommend it.  Though it lacks the appearance of its predecessor, do not miss out on this extremely smart and highly relevant game.

content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
												Deus Ex: Human Revolution - Directors Cut is a breath of fresh air, especially after the disappointing sequel to one of my favourite games of all time, Deus Ex. Invisible War was a mess. BUT, Human Revolution rejuvenated the franchise after returning to the core roots and pillars of gameplay which were founded in the original. Stealth, action, meaningful choice and consequence events, and of course many other role playing elements. Adam Jensen, ex-SWAT and military, is an awesome protagonist, and is easily one of the franchises best characters, just as JC Denton was in the first game. Augmentations are back, and are as awesome as ever. These give Adam a slick feel, especially as time progresses, and allows endless possibilities with character development. Augmentations give the player new avenues into approaching objectives which allows the game to feel more open ended and replayable.BE WARNED, not all augmentations can be purchased in one playthrough so choose wisely depending on your playstyle.5th time playing it myself (1st time on PC), and I was still discovering new and rewarding approaches to tackle my objectives. The dialogue system, which is very similar to Mass Effect, works extremely well in giving the player more choice and is intricately designed, much like the new hacking system. As far as the story goes, it absolutely works with the themes of the game. Conspiracies, secret organisations and of course...the Illuminati. And not to mention, the writing in the game is impeccable. One of the best scripts I've seen in a video game.The "Directors Cut" tag has added quite a few benefits over the original, the most noticeable being the New Game+ mode which was widely requested by fans for a long time. It's here and it absolutely works. Being able to continue on from where the game ended and keeping all augmentations just makes the game more enjoyable and also a little bit easier, allowing the "Give me Deus Ex" difficulty to be quite manageable, as it is very tough (1 or 2 hits and its "See ya later, Frank"). Only weapons and other inventory items will have been discarded if New Game+ is activated, which is not a very big hassle as it would have made the game way too easy, and that is not at all good for a game like this. The new "Directors Cut" also adds developer commentary which is quite insightful as it delves deeper into how different aspects of the game were considered and made.In conclusion, Deus Ex: Human Revolution - Directors Cut is one of last generation’s best games, in MY OPINION. The rewarding gameplay, multiple approaches to objectives, and just the sheer amount of replayability along with the engaging and well written 20+ hour storyline makes for an extremely enjoyable and immersive experience, especially for fans of the franchise, like myself. The only downsides, which I haven't yet mentioned have to be that the game only rewards one approach of gameplay, stealth and non-lethal, which is actually fine because ultimately this is how Deus Ex should be played, and it’s the way I played it. The other disappointment is in the boss fights. Although the "Directors Cut" added more flexibility to these encounters, they still lacked in the multiple approach department, especially taking these bosses down non-lethally, which isn't very much like Deus Ex. Lastly, the inclusion of the "Missing Link" DLC, adds to the games total play time, but nothing more as it is quite a disappointment. The "Missing Link" should not have been embedded into the main game, as it seems rather forced due to the tedious objectives that need to be completed in a constricted hub, which ultimately results in rather stale and boring gameplay. All in all, I wish I could go over everything, but this was a short review. Deus Ex: Human Revolution - Directors Cut is one hell of a game and can easily be respected as one of the series' best. Hardcore fan or newcomer, this game should be played by anyone who enjoys lasting and rewarding RPG's. Having played the PC and console version, the PC version is far superior.9.3/10Note: I managed to do everything in the game, including most achievements and the DLC, in around 17 hours (speedrun, kinda). If it is your FIRST time playing the game, expect to put in at least 30-35 hours to finish the story and do some of the side quests. I just memorised MOST of the games layout and approaches, and also knew where the main interest locations were.

content:
Posted: July 22, 2015
												I did like Deus Ex, but I found the game frustrating at times. For example, I played through the game using only weapons described by the game as "non-lethal", and only using non-lethal takedowns. Despite this, the game did not give me the achievement for beating the game without killing anyone. Looking on the wiki, two of the three weapons labeled "non-lethal" still have a chance to kill people, which means someone may have died due to random bad luck. The wiki also says people can die if you move their unconcious body, which the game tells you to do so that other people won't find them.I also never set off any alarms, but I failed to get the achievement for doing so, because the game apparently respawned enemies behind me after I had cleared out the level, who then found the other knocked out guards and set off an alarm that I could never hear because I had already completed that area of the level.The boss "fights" are also terrible. I was doing a non-lethal run, so I didn't have any weapons. But it still forced me to do a boss fight, which ended up being half an hour of me hiding in a vent shooting the boss with a pistol over and over until he died.The game also had a cutscene where a character remarked that I had killed quite a few people off camera during a level transition, despite me (attempting to) only use non-lethal methods to disable guards.I also found the The Missing Link DLC annoying, because it resets out back to level 8 two thirds of the way through the game. (I did not know that it was DLC, because I got the game as a gift) and so I lost all of my abilities and no longer could open locked doors or hold my entire inventory because it takes 7 levels for lockpicking and another 3 for a full inventory...

content:
Posted: February 9, 2014
												Very great game, this was the first Deus Ex game I have played, and so I have started playing the others. Although I have noticed how "easy" this game is compared to the others... but that can dealt with by going through the settings and disabling a few things here and there. It definitely has a great storyline and it is amazing compared to other video games I have played. They have created this universe so realistically well that it actually feel it could happen. In the DIrector's Cut edition of the game, it adds in The Missing Link DLC and another DLC-thingy with weapons and such. The Missing Link suprisingly was implemented well into the game, and I loved it. It delved farther into the discovery of the conspiracy behind the "Tyrants" and such. And, the art style for this game is truly magnificient. It has that "cyberpunk noire" with the gleaming yellow lights and the triangularly-shaped objects most commonly seen give off a deep sense of some sort of movement, or revolution as you will, from modern times into a new future. I was a bit dissapointed in the Director's Cut when they lowered down the yellowness in the game. But it sorta balanced out my mood with the added in weapons. This game has made me move on to read the book Deus Ex: Icarus Effect and also play Deus Ex 1! Very amazing game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												The Deus Ex Series has had tremendous ups and downs over it's lifespan.  It began with the critically acclaimed Deus Ex, but that was followed by the widely panned Deus Ex: Invisible War.  A straight up FPS sequel was under development at the time of Invisible War's release named Deus Ex: Clan Wars, but was retooled and released as Project Snowblind.It wouldn't be until 2011 that Deus Ex would finally see a worthy sequel in Deus Ex: Human Revolution, well...actually it's a prequel, so the wait's still going on in that department.The Director's Cut isn't a tremendous upgrade over the original, the largest difference is the inclusion of "The Missing Link", a challenging DLC for the original game.  With or without The Missing Link however, this is still a tremendously fun game.

												Despite rather aging graphics, it is the aesthetic design that really makes me like the overall design of the game. Dark colors  often reflected by strong, vibrant lightning. Curiously, I found the main campaign to be boiler-plate AAA design, while the side missions were a little bit more interesting. Furthermore, while main character changes location from time-to-time, the areas look rather similar, but that can be personal thing. Gameplay is as good as it ever was; no complaints outside few bugs and some aiming problems that seem to appear when in small areas. Experience/Progression system is interesting, but player becomes pretty much master of everything in the end. Speaking of the ending, pretty awful cop out. I dont know what it is, but this may seem like a review that I'd recommend, but it really is. Its the atmosphere, combined with excellent combat mechanics and suitable graphical design that really makes this game very good indeed. Word of warning thou, if you appreciate graphical fidelity, this game may not be for you anymore.

												This game is my favorite so far in the franchise.  One thing that makes this game so great is that you can choose how to take out enemies. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2016
TL;DRHolds up marvelously for a (at the time of writing) 5 year old game, Deus Ex: Human Revolution (DXHR) is a game that strives to let each player enjoy the experience in his or her way.Meeghan!!!How do you revive a game series more than a decade old? DX:HR should be a shining example of such an accomplishment. It took a story-line with potential, mixed it with a bag full of modern tricks and we end up with a fun to play game and a solid adventure to boot. Perhaps the most exemplary of it's traits is that this is a game that offers a stealth option, and then actually rewards the player for playing stealthily. This is a true adventure-stealth game, as evidenced by the fact that one can go through the game without killing a single enemy (save for the bosses). BreakdownPros You Can't See Me: No need to go into every situation guns blazing. Play it Again: Even though the storyline is linear, there's no reason the gameplay is. The game is choc ful of shortcuts and hidden secrets that you'll definitely want to replay it again. Decisions decisions: How you play, what paths you choose, and choices you make create noticable differences in the gameplay. Checkpoint: Thank the devs for creating a lenient save system that allows quick-saving, quick-reloading, and more than a dozen save slots, so every failure doesn't equate to half and hour or more of lost progress.Cons Two Minutes to Finish Test: Unfortunately, the fantastic game ends with a lackluster performance as the ending of the game leaves much to be desired. A Word From Our Sponsors: Even though cutscenes for exposition is unavoidable, there are quite a few long and unskippable cutscenes (especially the one right at the beginning). Achievement Unlocked? If you're an achievement hunter like me, there are quite a few achievements in this game that you can fail with no warning whatsoever. They can happen offscreen in areas you left minutes ago, and there's no way to really anticipate or prevent them.Score: 9.4/10

												Up to this day this game is my favorite. Honestly, I have never fully understood why do I like this game so much. Bash me if you want to, but I can't say it's perfect in every possible detail. The thing is, it's not about the details themselves, it's about them being being knit together so good you're getting absorbed by the game as it's going, making it one of the most immersive games in the world. Everything -  story, gameplay, lore, characters, world around you, even the damn yellow filter functions so well together you get a feeling it's not even a made up story but something that WILL happen at some point, that's how good this game is. You're seriosly starting to question yourself about the events that did not happen, but they FEEL like they did. You feel like you're in control of your character, it's you making it happening. It's applaudable on how Eidos Montreal made a protagonist with a personality, yet completely relatable in the things he's (or you're) doing. This is what Deus Ex: Human Revolution is for me, and I totally recommend you playing it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 5, 2015
												Deus Ex: Human Revolution - Directors Cut is a breath of fresh air, especially after the disappointing sequel to one of my favourite games of all time, Deus Ex. Invisible War was a mess. BUT, Human Revolution rejuvenated the franchise after returning to the core roots and pillars of gameplay which were founded in the original. Stealth, action, meaningful choice and consequence events, and of course many other role playing elements. Adam Jensen, ex-SWAT and military, is an awesome protagonist, and is easily one of the franchises best characters, just as JC Denton was in the first game. Augmentations are back, and are as awesome as ever. These give Adam a slick feel, especially as time progresses, and allows endless possibilities with character development. Augmentations give the player new avenues into approaching objectives which allows the game to feel more open ended and replayable.BE WARNED, not all augmentations can be purchased in one playthrough so choose wisely depending on your playstyle.5th time playing it myself (1st time on PC), and I was still discovering new and rewarding approaches to tackle my objectives. The dialogue system, which is very similar to Mass Effect, works extremely well in giving the player more choice and is intricately designed, much like the new hacking system. As far as the story goes, it absolutely works with the themes of the game. Conspiracies, secret organisations and of course...the Illuminati. And not to mention, the writing in the game is impeccable. One of the best scripts I've seen in a video game.The "Directors Cut" tag has added quite a few benefits over the original, the most noticeable being the New Game+ mode which was widely requested by fans for a long time. It's here and it absolutely works. Being able to continue on from where the game ended and keeping all augmentations just makes the game more enjoyable and also a little bit easier, allowing the "Give me Deus Ex" difficulty to be quite manageable, as it is very tough (1 or 2 hits and its "See ya later, Frank"). Only weapons and other inventory items will have been discarded if New Game+ is activated, which is not a very big hassle as it would have made the game way too easy, and that is not at all good for a game like this. The new "Directors Cut" also adds developer commentary which is quite insightful as it delves deeper into how different aspects of the game were considered and made.In conclusion, Deus Ex: Human Revolution - Directors Cut is one of last generation’s best games, in MY OPINION. The rewarding gameplay, multiple approaches to objectives, and just the sheer amount of replayability along with the engaging and well written 20+ hour storyline makes for an extremely enjoyable and immersive experience, especially for fans of the franchise, like myself. The only downsides, which I haven't yet mentioned have to be that the game only rewards one approach of gameplay, stealth and non-lethal, which is actually fine because ultimately this is how Deus Ex should be played, and it’s the way I played it. The other disappointment is in the boss fights. Although the "Directors Cut" added more flexibility to these encounters, they still lacked in the multiple approach department, especially taking these bosses down non-lethally, which isn't very much like Deus Ex. Lastly, the inclusion of the "Missing Link" DLC, adds to the games total play time, but nothing more as it is quite a disappointment. The "Missing Link" should not have been embedded into the main game, as it seems rather forced due to the tedious objectives that need to be completed in a constricted hub, which ultimately results in rather stale and boring gameplay. All in all, I wish I could go over everything, but this was a short review. Deus Ex: Human Revolution - Directors Cut is one hell of a game and can easily be respected as one of the series' best. Hardcore fan or newcomer, this game should be played by anyone who enjoys lasting and rewarding RPG's. Having played the PC and console version, the PC version is far superior.9.3/10Note: I managed to do everything in the game, including most achievements and the DLC, in around 17 hours (speedrun, kinda). If it is your FIRST time playing the game, expect to put in at least 30-35 hours to finish the story and do some of the side quests. I just memorised MOST of the games layout and approaches, and also knew where the main interest locations were.

content:
Posted: September 20, 2016
												Deus Ex: Human Revolution is a worthy successor to the original Deus Ex and an amazing game in it's own right. Although DX:HR does cater to multiple play styles, it is an excellent stealth game at heart. There are many solutions to every problem and it is up to you to decide how to proceed.DX:HR features a rich story line, interesting characters, optional yet worthwhile side-quests, meaningful character choice, weapon and character upgrade paths, and plenty of non-linear scenarios to give almost any player enough to explore and discover.DX:HR is frequently 75% off ($5) but it has more than enough gameplay and replayability to justify the normal $20 price. The Director's Cut includes The Missing Link DLC where it chronologically exists in the storyline, some new weapons, several new items, and 3 improved boss fight locations.

Decisions decisions: How you play, what paths you choose, and choices you make create noticable differences in the gameplay. Checkpoint: Thank the devs for creating a lenient save system that allows quick-saving, quick-reloading, and more than a dozen save slots, so every failure doesn't equate to half and hour or more of lost progress.Cons Two Minutes to Finish Test: Unfortunately, the fantastic game ends with a lackluster performance as the ending of the game leaves much to be desired. A Word From Our Sponsors: Even though cutscenes for exposition is unavoidable, there are quite a few long and unskippable cutscenes (especially the one right at the beginning). Achievement Unlocked? If you're an achievement hunter like me, there are quite a few achievements in this game that you can fail with no warning whatsoever. They can happen offscreen in areas you left minutes ago, and there's no way to really anticipate or prevent them.Score: 9.4/10

Posted: February 23
												[SPOILER FREE]I'm not too sure about recommending the later version of the franchise (Mankind Divided) but Human Revolution is a must buy, eventhough I bought this on a sale, I would say buying the game at full price is worth it.Pros:- Unique artstyle and theme, (yes the yellow filter makes it look like someone took a♥♥♥♥♥♥over the screen) but still, compared to other cyberpunk titles that I've seen, this one has a more warmer and elegant theme to it (warm theme of yellow, black and gold instead of cold and tech-savy color mixtures like blue and such)...- There are no good or bad sides or characters in this game, only shades of grey...- The gameplay, possibilities and decision making for going through a mission are vast and impressive...- The story and character development are well thought and put together...- Most important of all, the endings are phenomenal and convincing...- Amazing ambiance and soundtrack, mostly chilling at times. Great OST overall...- Game difficulty is challenging and fair at the same time. I would recommend medium difficulty (give me a challenge) for an adequate experience of the difficulty.Cons:-Mechanics and enemy behaviour and detection would rarely be buggy at times.- The only game breaking glitch I've found so far is that you might encounter the HUD dissappearance glitch, but if you return to an earlier save file, the problem would be fixed.- You have to go through some places over and over again especially in city hub areas where you can do side missions, the whole game becomes mundane for a while and you just have to be a bit patient about it; but don't worry the good parts are yet to come...Overall rating: 8/10A great game to experience

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12
												It's been a good 13 years or so since first I played the (amazing) Deus Ex and attempted to go back to back with the Deus Ex sequel, Invisble War. Yeah, that didn't go so well. Deus Ex featured open ended, globe trotting goodness  while IW felt like a crappy console port. Thankfully the third game in the series, Human Revolution, has rediscovered the original's roots and paves it's own way into excellence. I'm not going to go into the story of DE: HR becuase frankly the story is lengthy, complicated and is ever changing depending on your decisions. But don't let that scare you off because it is absolutely engrossing. I'd refer to DE: HR more as a "First Person RPG". Gameplay is at it's best when you're sneaking around, diagnosing, and using your brain to find ways around situations. It's especially satisfying when you have robot or turret domination. Press the button to get them on your side and listen to chaos ensue. However, if you're looking to gun your way through this game I'd say you'll be disappointed. The shooting is extremely "eh" and even with your armor maxed, the enemies will be able to take more damage than you.  Also kind of on the eh side is everything really looks the same. You'll be inside most of the time crawling through corridors, sewers and air vents. WAY more to like though. The soundtrack is great and overall the voice acting is as well. There are so many solutions to the problems in this game, even if you're underpowered you'll get through it. The campaign is incredibly lengthy and there are tons of side missions for you to do. I wholeheartedly recommend DE: HR but I can see why this game wouldn't be for everyone.  As long as you aren't expecting a CoD one man army style of shooter it's hard to imagine you'd be disappointed. 9/10 from me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 3, 2016
												The dev team thought of everything.Other reviews can praise this game's stealth, combat, upgrades, art, characters, and story, I just want to show my appreciation for the sheer amount of player choice in this game. Sometimes I was flabbergasted after a mission, going back through the level and realizing just how impressive its design was in terms of making sure that you can get through it ANY way you want to. Pacifict? Check. Terminator? Check. Hacker? Scavenger? Little-of-everything? All of the above. I loved it.And more than just the amount of choice was the implementation. I've said in other reviews that what I want in a game is one where the challenge comes from fighting the bad guys, not from fighting the controls. 99% of everything I tried in this game was a fair challenge. No shoddy, sloppy work. I push the button; thing happens the way it's supposed to. And there were plenty of times when I had a nutty idea and thought, 'Can I do that?' Yes I could. Punch civilians in the head! Throw turrets into the sea! Make modern art with piles of unconscious enemies! Steal EVERYTHING!My only real complaint was with the implanted DLC. While I did grow to enjoy it by the end, (especially Quinn), at times it felt uneccesary and shoehorned in, and there were parts when the writing was bizarrely sexist. Oh well. Once I got off the boat it was back to the main game and everything was fine again.Overall, DXHR is going in my favorites list. I look forward to New Game+. The D-Row Ballers won't know what hit 'em.P.S. Major congrats to Adam Jensen's voice actor. The Neo-esque gravelly growl could have easily been monotone and emotionless, but he managed to put a ton of subtle personality into the performance. Often through taking the lines as read, and knowing exactly which words to punch emphasis into. Kudos!

content:
Posted: December 10, 2016
Product received for free
 Does it have a premise? In the near future, you're a guy named Adam Jensen, working security for Sarif Industries, one of the leaders in the biotech business. One day, however, before a presentation in Washington, an attack occurs. The key staff is presumed dead and you're mortally wounded, however, with the help of advanced augmentation technology, you're brought back from death and are back on the job a mere six months later. What is this game? It's a successor to the original Deus Ex, and a worthy one, at that. It is not an RPG in the traditional sense. Your aim is not impaired if you're untrained in a weapon. There's no locational damage. There are no skills to upgrade, besides your augmentations. It's far more an action/RPG hybrid than the original Deus Ex, while keeping the spirit with large, sprawling, living environments, fleshed out sidequests and a fantastic atmosphere. Does this game have music?  Yes, yes it does. And it is fantastic, one of the core contributing factors towards the atmosphere. It gets more energetic when it needs to, and keeps slow, fades out to the background when you're making your way down town, asthmatically jogging to your next point of interest. How does it play? This is one of the main gripes to be had with the game. The stealth is half-baked. No light levels. At all. You can be up in the rafters concealed in darkness, the AI does not give a damn. It's all line of sight. Some people find this acceptable, but as an officianado of the original Splinter Cell titles and the Thief series, I think it's inexcusable. The shooting is not great, either. The cover mechanics serve the firefights well, but unless you upgrade your weapons, a lot, you're going to be fairly useless by the end of the game. Oh and also, the close combat takedowns take energy and are cutscenes. Oh and also, you can't sprint for longer than 10 seconds, even if you're upgraded to the maximum possible for both your rebreather and legs. Does it have a story? Yes, and a very good one, in fact. The story is a complicated mix of higher powers controlling everyone, corporate warfare, street crime, news spinning and human evolution. Going into any detail would be an injustice towards the game. Who should buy this? To be truthful, everyone. It is by far better than Invisible War, the previous title in the series, and it has enough elements to bring new players in to the classic Deus Ex formula, keeping people hooked with the immersive environments and fantastic story.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 14, 2016
TL;DRHolds up marvelously for a (at the time of writing) 5 year old game, Deus Ex: Human Revolution (DXHR) is a game that strives to let each player enjoy the experience in his or her way.Meeghan!!!How do you revive a game series more than a decade old? DX:HR should be a shining example of such an accomplishment. It took a story-line with potential, mixed it with a bag full of modern tricks and we end up with a fun to play game and a solid adventure to boot. Perhaps the most exemplary of it's traits is that this is a game that offers a stealth option, and then actually rewards the player for playing stealthily. This is a true adventure-stealth game, as evidenced by the fact that one can go through the game without killing a single enemy (save for the bosses). BreakdownPros You Can't See Me: No need to go into every situation guns blazing. Play it Again: Even though the storyline is linear, there's no reason the gameplay is. The game is choc ful of shortcuts and hidden secrets that you'll definitely want to replay it again. Decisions decisions: How you play, what paths you choose, and choices you make create noticable differences in the gameplay. Checkpoint: Thank the devs for creating a lenient save system that allows quick-saving, quick-reloading, and more than a dozen save slots, so every failure doesn't equate to half and hour or more of lost progress.Cons Two Minutes to Finish Test: Unfortunately, the fantastic game ends with a lackluster performance as the ending of the game leaves much to be desired. A Word From Our Sponsors: Even though cutscenes for exposition is unavoidable, there are quite a few long and unskippable cutscenes (especially the one right at the beginning). Achievement Unlocked? If you're an achievement hunter like me, there are quite a few achievements in this game that you can fail with no warning whatsoever. They can happen offscreen in areas you left minutes ago, and there's no way to really anticipate or prevent them.Score: 9.4/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												Although heavily plagued with game-breaking bugs, this combined role-playing cloak-and-carbine first person shooter really revives, revamps, and reconstructs every single criterion that defined the timeless Deus Ex series. Well-designed stealth system, choice of non-lethal pacifism or brutal kill-everyone gameplay, extreme dark dystopian Gattaca+Bladerunner style speculative fiction setting, easy-to-control COD style weapon aiming, cyborg-level customisable character leveling, and most importantly the power to manipulate the entire plot, storyline, boss-fight conditions and final outcome implicitly and cumulatively via emotionally-intensive multiple-choice dialogues throughout each mission. As the title indicates, this game really tests the limits of what it means to be "human" philosophically. +1337 points for  actually calling the antagonists The Illuminati. ILLUMINATI CONFIRMED.

content:
Posted: September 8, 2016
												In retrospect the original DX is, without doubt, an unforgetable but flawed masterpiece which pushed the technology of the day to, and sometimes beyond, the limit. The Hell's Kitchen level is still a design classic, the overall story is still as strong as it ever was but graphics, AI, and shooter mechanic are showing their age. In comparison, HR has improved with age and now seems more topical than ever. HR is more cinematic and sure-footed than DX. The story is deep,  immaculately scripted and there is a sense that the characters are real people. There is also an overall artistic vision missing from the original DX. However, all is not perfect with HR; it was pushed out of the workshop with rough edges and annoying game balance problems. DX:HR Director's Cut includes all of the DLC and a gameplay rebalance. At the moment I am in the basement of the Picus building and playing a ghost/no-kill game on maximum difficulty. It's a worthy challenge. The annoyances involved with  ghosting through the original HR are gone. I had to kill Barret at Highland Park by turning the sentry guns against him, but he deserved it. Coming back to  HR is like meeting a trusted friend after many years; I see things I missed before and have a new appreciation of just how good this game is. Maybe it's a design masterpiece?---the final emergence of the video game as a fully formed story telling artform. It could be the video game equivalent of Casablanca or Citizen Kane. Maybe. Time will tell.

Originally posted by Adam Jensen:I never asked for this game...This game is just awesome and if you're reading this, you want to know why. So let's start with the story (Spoiler free and really short).Deus Ex: Human Revolution is playing in a cyberpunk setting (most underrated setting ever) and you play as Adam Jensen. Your goal is to find the guy(s) who stole your gf and find out why he/they did it.Now the reasons why you SHOULD buy DE:HRThe story. It's very deep and really interesting. If you like, you can get to know more about the background of characters etc. by doing quests and reading e-mails. But don't panic, those e-mails aren't as bad as the skyrim lore books. they're interesting and you get to know muuuuuch more about the background of the main characters.The stealth system. Learning the routes of hostile NPC's is very exciting and the augmentation give you much to play and try with.The action-bubbles. Basically every level is a action-bubble. You free to do in it whatever you want.The dialogues. GOD I ♥♥♥♥ING LOVE'EM. Instead of COD breaching you can actually TALK with your enemies and try to convience them to stop what they're doing.Exploring. You get rewarded if you explore the action-bubbles.Augmentation. Watch the trailers and you know what I'm talking about :p2nd playthrough. If you play DE:HR second/third time, you start with the augmentation which you bought in the last playthrough. Best feature ever.Why you SHOULDN'T buy DE:HRThe boss fights. You have to kill 3 bosses through out the game.WHAT ARE YOU WAITING FOR. BUY IT!!

content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
												Great game. Things I Like > > Things I Don't Like. I tend to be reminded of a game called Splinter Cell. If you could combine Spinter Cell, Deus Ex : Human Revolution, Dishonored, WarFrame, Hitman etc... You could make a very difficult stealth game that requires you to utilize all your superhuman powers to complete the stage. Crawling or duck-walking everywhere is very funny. It's an amazing story and game. $8.98 SGDPROS1. Multi-choiceThere are many ways to play this game. Stealth, Combat, Exploration. Stealth and Combat are self-explainatory but Exploration is something different. E.g. You can get a Hive Membership that allows you to enter a night club (The Hive) as a member instead of sneaking around or shooting everyone up.2. Non-Playable CharactersSemi-interesting. The NPCs respond to you and give you useful information, most of them don't function as "lamp posts". While asking them repeatedly still gets a botted response, it is more interesting compared to other games. It is still far off from an interesting character.3. Wall Hack Vision (F3)Very cool. Very useful.4. HackingFun to hack everything. From doors, safes, security locks and computers. The mini-game isn't so fun though. It's basically "Find-the-shortest-route-to-the-green-balls". You can't hack cameras or turrets directly, only through their control station. You need an upgrade to turn them on their enemies though.5. Tranquilizer GunBeing able to use a non-lethal form of taking out an opponent is most fun. It's difficult to shoot through bars but doable.6. Box bots / Guard RobotsIt's a big giant mecha-walker. Very cool. I thought they would incorporate more of these things. I'm not sure if you can hack into them, yet.7. CASIEDating Sim Simulator. Funny and useful. Going to unlock it soon.8. Boss BattlesIt's not a slug-fest unless you want it to be. There are so many ways to kill the bosses.CONS1. Piraxis PointsYour skill points in the game. Given very rarely and you have to allocate them properly. While the abilities are enjoyable, perhaps I felt that the rate of skill point gain was a bit slow?2. Take-downsSo flashy and so loud. It's a wonder why no one can hear a take-down. Most of all, the target gets to have a look at your face.3. RollingIf you hug the wall and try to stealth roll to the next wall, you will see a "kung fu" barrel roll that makes absolutely no sense.4. KO'ed BodiesThey are there like forever. A tranquilizer dart keeps them on the ground permanently. You can leave and return and the bodies will still be there. Also, the rag doll dragging looks funny and weird, like a bug suddenly occurred.5. Guard RoutesStandard repeats. I don't know how to explain it, but knowing that a guard moves back and forth in a straight line, kind of makes it boring. It doesn't make the guard feel alive. 6. TriggersSome guard routes are only triggered when you enter within range of some guards. This makes alternative routes less viable because they don't move.7. BoxesYour inventory keeps ammunition in a 2 space box. 1 additional bullet requires a 2 space box? Inventory Tetris is not a fun mini-game.8. Bugsa. The female boss after Eliza Chan got bugged after I used both the Typhon and PEPS to kill her. She became permanently invisible and unable to move. I just shot her to death.b. Batter rechargers only 1 level of energy cellc. Dual takedown does not work on sitting opponents.9. Cut-scenesOnce is enough, no need to keep giving cut-scenes for every take-down,kill, Icarus landing or Typhoon firing.10. KeysGrenades and Holster weapon are next to each other on the keyboard (G & H). Imagine if you want to holster and you throw a grenade instead.Cloak and Typhoon are next to each. Imagine if you want to cloak and a Typhoon explosion happened instead.SUGGESTION1. Floor Cleaners Robots / Roombas?I noticed that the game had a lot of Floor Cleaner Robots that don't move around. Make them something that are moving around in the game. Then you hack them and use their cameras to spy on rooms.2. Vending MachinesI have to eat energy bars to replace my electric batteries that powers my robotic arm. While I suspect that it is most illogical, perhaps the vending machines could dispense energy drinks/food?3. Energy / HealthPerhaps, charging through a power point might be better than a energy bar? The power to move a prosthetic limb that can bash through walls comes from an energy bar? Painkillers gets you more health? Perhaps energy shields?4. Hack CommunicationsHack their radio signal and you can jam them, isolate one group, give them false orders, reduce alert status or anything else you can think of. Group link them, so they check on those missing.5. DisguisesSpeaks for itself. Add illusions too?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												I consider Deus Ex: Human Revolution a decent game with some very strong pros but also some alarming cons. Overall I recommend this game because it brings something on the table that's unique and well executed. However, I can't say that I was left completely satisfied or that my positive emotions skyrocketed through the roof.Pros:+ Idea of the so called 'augmentations' highly original.+ Different paths to complete the missions.+ Wonderful stealth takedown.+ Nice character build.+ Memorable protagonist.+ Useful weapons and nice weapon upgrades.+ Cool little hacking minigame.+ Getting shot gets you killed FAST.Cons:- The environment is a maze which really brings down the game tempo. On top of that there's a lot of backtracking which replaces the fun of sneaking past guards with frustration. I found myself over and over again getting impatient about how the game artificially tried to slow me down. - Not the most helpful minimap.- Not that great of a level design.- Poor inventory.- Black and white backstory with a very predictable plot. - Badly written readable material and poor dialogues.- Frustrating boss battles in small contained areas (cage-battles basically).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 15, 2015
												Pros- Breathtaking story- Fluid gameplay- No need to play others to understand the storyline since game itself covers it ( I recommend playing it tho )- Adam's voice- One of a kind soundtrack ( Only Witcher and Mass Effect can go head to head from new genre rpg )- High replay value, 2 plays at least one steath one rambo- Lots of emotional moments- Map design for missions are superb, you don't feel repetitive- Director's Cut brings commentary which may help newcomers pass certain areas without searching for guides- Can achieve certain things that require augmentation with quick thinkingCons- City designs are average, you want to skip right to action without walking around too much- Long cutscenes which can't be skipped can be boring during replays- DLC missions happens in a totaly seperate map which demans you to walk in circles basicly- DLC area loading time is annoying- Not much to do in your home- Mirror in the bathroom of your home still broken after DLC ( fix it damn it )- I never asked for this.Conclusion One of the MUST know games of the gaming history. If you don't agree with me just watch the opening cinematic from youtube. You'll thank me later.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23, 2016
												Buckle up because this is my favourite game of all time.Barring World of Warcraft, Vanilla, which must take the top title on account of the ungodly number of days I spent playing the thing, I have never enjoyed a gaming experience as totally as I did with this game.You must know that this was an important game for me because it accessed my interests in a way that few games in the past five or six years had managed to. Prior to DE:HR I am quite sure I had not completed a narrative-driven game for half a decade. Many great titles had come and gone but none of them had gotten through to me, distracted as I was by University studies, to such an extent that I was motivated to put in the time to complete them.Deus Ex: HR held no such difficulties.Maybe it was the formula, the open ended nature of the levels, perhaps the story. Maybe it was the challenge, certainly a huge part had to do with the stylish presentation - everything from the menu and HUD design to the soundtrack and of course the graphics oozed classy cyberpunk immersion.Really though, it was simply everything. I have never played through this game on any difficult level less than the maximum setting, and I have never played it as a run-and-gun shooter. I urge you to follow suit, because the stealth controls for this title are fantastic. Beyond simple stealth movement, consider the natural extension of that - exploration. The idea of multiple routes to an objective has been adopted in this game to such an extent - in almost all cases - that linearity has departed completely. Even the famous bugaboos of the original build of the game didn't bother me. The boss fights that forced you to engage in combat didn't phase me one iota: here I was, someone who had basically completed entire zones without killing a soul, reloading save after save, refining my game plan and whittling down the boss with horrendously unskilled weapon talents. Quicksaving every time I ran across open ground, got a few rounds into the hulking fellow and found cover again without going splat!. I may be a bit oldfashioned in the way I cosider this kind of difficulty appealing - indeed, I often say that I very much preferred Vanilla WoW to later iterations precisely because it took whole weeks of your life to net anything worthwhile - and those of you reading this review will be pleased to know that the Director's Cut edition no longer contains these bottleneck boss fights - they now all feature multiple routes towards completion, as with the rest of the content. (the boss fights had been outsourced to a separate company who had failed to grasp what DE was all about)The attention to detail, atmosphere, challenge, great variation in gameplay and excellent replayability all go in to making Deus Ex: HR my favourite FPS, favourite RPG, and pretty much my favourite game period, of all time.The downsides are few and far between. Somewhat like the GTA and Elder Scrolls games one finds oneself wishing the non-questgiving NPCs walking around town could contribute even vaguely to the atmosphere the rest of the game has so carefully constructed, and an act set in a futuristic Chinese city has a vaguely disappointing resolution (at least part of that dissapointment comes simply from the fact that the zone ends and you must stop exploring it) The graphics have aged slightly - the character models for one are really previous-gen by now. One would expect bump mapping, skin pores - the kinda things you marveled at on the face of Prophet in Crysis - but instead the faces are dissapointingly smooth, as if cut from clay. That said, and this is applicable to all of the qualms one might have about this game, there is another side: The facial graphics might be a bit tedious by now, but on the same coin the combat, movement, environmental and explosion graphics among many others are all fantastic.Play this game, if you have any respect at all for your human right to enjoy the art of computer gaming then play this game on max difficulty and try to avoid the run-and-gun approach if it is at all possible. That is all.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2015
												Rating: 8/10Replayability: LowBudget: Fairly old game by now, still pricy due to quality - Worth it. Length: Takes a few days to beat. Pros: Great story, decent engine, good graphics (even by today's standards, the game is decent enough to play), the game has a sequel coming up soon, choices and consequences - The game actively makes you reap what you sow, great dialogue system on par with other RPGs from that time, and even some today - fully voice acted, great story. Cons: Human Revolution is optimized for console, which can seem like a big minus, unless you own a controller for your PC, which seriously smoothens the experience. Somewhat confusing inventory system. Very harsh gameplay where you get severely punished for missing minor details early in the game. Very confusing endings (to the point where beating the game actually seems pointless compared to simply playing it). Whether you're new to the Deus Ex series, or this is your first attempt, this game is a good place to start. The older games certainly hold good memories for those who played them when they came out, but due to possitively ancient gameplay - many people simply will not consider them playable anymore. Story-wise, there doesn't seem to be anything you explicitly have to know from the previous games, in order to enjoy Human Revolution, so it's not really a sequel, but just another game in the series.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 23, 2016
												A better version of "Invisible War", but this time with actual stealth. Although stealth in this game can be very much broken, so the game might be leaning in the shooter genre very much so. Same flaws as in the previous game. Reusage of assets, animations e.t.c.. Even if you call level a "HUB" doesn't mean it's fine to play it again. Repetitiveness - basically you do the same thing the whole game, altering paths and choices help, but barely. There is still a lot of talking, but now you have an incentive to actually talk to the people, even though most of them are just to fill the space. There are a lot of weapons, but some of them are really bad for some reason. Crossbow and double-barrel are examples of that. Overall the game is playable, in the beginning it can be actually fun, but the real problem of this release is the DLC - "The Missing Link". It's placed in the middle of the game and boy is it awful. I considered dropping the game just not to have to play this DLC. They take all your weapons and skills you collected and loved through the game; that you are used to by now. Basically, you start all over. Not only that, DLC is not polished at all, its barely finished. And it crashes too. Main game haven't crashed once, but this mission kept crashing all throughout. And for that, i suggest if you want to play this, go with original release. For you would be able not to play this trash called "The Missing Link", because you will be missing not playing it

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 8
												This was my first Deus Ex game from the series, and it didn't disappoint. I bought it at 75-80% off, but I would gladly have paid full price.Human Revolution is a ridiculously fun title which offers tons of replayability due to the different combat approaches and paths available. Personally I usually opted for 'stealthy lethal' tactic in most situations, but it was definitely fun to switch things up a little here and there. I loved the hub worlds; they were so immersive and I always had fun talking to the random NPCs (who would then proceed to insult me in Mandarin but HAHA joke's on them because I understand Mandarin). I had a love-hate relationship with the limited inventory space mechanic, and always found myself hoarding grenades, painkillers, and energy bars I never used. The augmentations were so cool that I just had to attempt the game for a second time (in + mode) so I could get more upgrades and try them all out.If I had one complaint, it would be with the map system. Maybe it's just me being bad at reading maps, but the maps weren't very helpful in my attempt at navigating the hub worlds.

												Deus Ex human revolution อีกเกม rpg ดีๆเกมหนึ่งที่แนะนำด้วยเนื้อเรื่องของเกมที่ดีและฉากจบที่ประทับใจและรู้สึกคุ้มค่าที่เหนื่อยและเสียเวลาไปกว่า50 ชม กับเกมนี้ ตัวเกมยังสอนแง่มุมหลายๆอย่าง ตัวเอกที่ต้องยอมรับการปรับแต่งเป็น augmentations เพื่อกอบกู้มนุษย์ชาติและการหาความจริงต่างๆตัวเกมมีความอิสระในการเล่นมาก อยากบู้ก็ได้ แบบย่องเงียบก็ดี มีเส้นทางลับ ทางลัด การไปถึงเป้าหมายที่มีอยู่หลายเส้นทาง และหลายวิธี ตัวเกมมีภารกิจรองที่มีไม่มากจนเกินไปพอดีๆ augmentations ที่สามารถปรับแต่งได้หลายหลาก และเห็นผลทันตา เกมนี้ยังมีฉากสู้บอสแบบ 1 vs 1 อยู่ทำให้รู้สึกว่ามีความคลาสสิก ที่ต้องหาทางสู้จับจุดอ่อน(แต่รู้สึกว่ามีบอสน้อยไปนิด) ภาพของ Director's Cut นั้นได้ตัดกราฟฟิกโทนเหลืองๆของตัวเกมเดิมออกทำให้ดูดีขึ้นมานิด(โทนเหลืองๆก็อาตๆดี)เสียงภายในเกมก็ดีเลยทีเดียวเข้ากับ โลกอนาคตอย่างมาก สุดท้ายเกมนี้ก็ทำให้ผมได้อิ่มเลยกับเนื้อเรื่อง เกมเพลย์ รวมถึงฉากจบทั้ง 4 แบบที่แสนประทับใจ --Human Revolution--

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2014
												Look, I'm just gonna keep this review clear and make it something most people can understand. Pros:- The name has Director's Cut in it, that's a plus, right?- Fantastic controls - Decent story (I was actually immersed the first time i played through, without DLC)- Decent graphics even at low - Many ways to achieve objectives- Side quests and objectives feel great- If this is your first time playing with the DLC, it's great. - Wonderfully fleshed-out characters, yes, even the main characterCons:- There is no skip option for the DLC. If you're playing New Game+, this will irritate a LOT of people.- Ragdoll glitches may get in the way of stealth (one of my screenshots illustrates this problem)- Sometimes, things float when you grab other things underneath them. That's A-OK in my book, though.- Game rewards stealth too muchI haven't seen the bugs people are apparently complaining about, unless it's the ones I mentioned above.Overall: It's great the first time through, but the third (possibly second) time through will tire you out a bit. Story is compelling enough, at some times immersive.
