content:
Posted: August 15, 2016
												Having never played another game of the Deus Ex franchise so far, I can't get into detail about how this game is different than the original HR one, or how better/worse it is compared to the first ones.BUT!!If you are looking for an amazing stealth based game, with a nice plot, well developed characters, extensivelly thought out backstory and general badassness, search no more. I would definitely recommend this game, but keep in mind these thhings:-if you are  the kind of person that prefers storming into bases while riding an elephant and waving a bazooka around , you might have some trouble here 3:) The game does give you deadly takedown options, and has a variety of weapons -not too extensive but overall sufficient- used to kill, but firing a single bullet can cause troops of enemies to sudenly appear, and let me tell you, they are highly accurate, and your reloading takes a while, so you're better off silently stunning them or looking around for other possible ways. This game rewards you overall for being stealthy, with XP, bonuses, etc, but I for some people it can be really frustrating, sneaking away without killing that one annoying soldier xDBoss fights on the other hand require "open-field" fighting...Hacking and stealthing around could get you somewhere but you need to actively fight them to proceed.-The replayability factor is imo about average, but with the new game+ option you can keep your augmentations (aka skills) in the new game. Especially helpful if aiming for achievements. The game took me around 55 hours to finish.-If you're more of the "I'm here for the story" type, you might find the ending kinda disappointing. I enjoyed the game overall so I didnt mind it THAT much, but, well...Other than that the game is perfect, and since I got it on sale I can easily say this was the best 5$ I ever spent!!

content:
Posted: November 2, 2015
												I'm gonna start off with a bit of background. Deus Ex was a franchise originally started in 2000. It was quite revolutionary for games at that time (no pun intended.) Mainly because, at that time there were mainly linear games. Then along came Deus Ex, introducing stealth mechanics that many games didn't have. Such as enemies able to hear you drop items and such.                                                                                                                                                                                             Anyways, than along came Deus Ex: Invisible War. Which was quite a terrible game. (Hardly any choices, basically a shadow of it's former self.) It was released in 2003. So it was likely rushed.                                                                       In 2007 Deus Ex: Human Revolution was announced under the title "Deus Ex 3." After years of anticipation, there was finally news about it and it was named "Deus Ex: Human Revolution." Now when it first came out it was praised for it's choices, however there was a slight controversy over the ending. Because at the end you just push a button and watch an ending. However I found it rather thought provoking. Anyways, Directors Cut fixes many problems the orignial base game had. (Linear boss fights and such)                                                                                                                            8.5/10.

content:
Posted: February 27
 DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine Deus Ex: Human Revolution and its directors cut counterpart is a game developed by Eidos Montreal and published by Square Enix and is a reboot to the classic stealth franchise of the same nameThe main character is Adam Jensen, head of security in the company Sarif Industries, which during the attack is badly wounded and is rescued thanks to the numerous operations and body modifications.Deus Ex: Human Revolution is an immersive if somewhat deep in gameplay and open-ended FPS RPG involving conspiracy, international conflict, human dilemmas, spying people's emails, choice and dialogue makingIt is truly an amazing game. The level of detail, the graphics, the storyline and hardly and bugs/glitches throughout the whole gameThe only "big" problem with the directors cut version is the integrated DLC. While it's a well made and lengthy expansion that tries to innovate, it feels like it's measnt to be played after the main story and the way it's just tacked in there will cause a substantial difficulty-spike first time throughThe gameplay is great and you can finish the game while killing everyone or completely anybody while passing near them. This production is brilliant, it offers a great story, a lot of nice and diffrent locations, incredible soundtrack and interesting charactersThe game is definitely set to silent approach. Shooting using a guns is ok but it is not so cool. According to me, this is a brilliant title that offers a lot and is pretty well made stealth game. This title is a definitely worth of our timeThat said, you can't get much more polished and enjoyable AAA stealth gameplay this cheap! RECOMMENDED :)

content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												A revolutionary (no pun intended) hybrid of FPS and RPG. Also, and more interestingly, it's a cyberpunk, technologically-focused future story driven by themes of transhumanism and memory implantation. This is a great game that not only challenges players in a variety of FPS goals and objectives, but also invites players to consider the human soul, its worth, and the good and bad actions of man's Way.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2016
												This game has a compelling atmosphere. From the very beginning, the music played when we launch the game makes us feel flung into its world. As a result however, it does make any disappointment a very frustrating experience.It is an excellent game nonetheless. For the reason I just mentioned: the atmosphere is so compelling it reminds me of the first time I played Half-Life 1. We really feel like we are Adam Jensen and we have responsabilities. When I failed to save someone in some parts of the game, I really felt it was my fault. Talking about the music, the intro music is even so good I suffer pain quitting the game or loading a save. Characters are endearing. Jensen's personality isn't extremely original, but still is extremely convicing, as for all the other characters in the game : Sarif, Malik…But this game as awesome also because it has a broad gameplay well made in every aspect. Hacking, stealth, combat, debate, exploration, side quests, deciding your ameliorations and weapons : it's impressive a game can have so many different gameplay aspect yet excels at each one. It is fun and really simple to handle.Now, as I said, this game isn't perfect. I encountered a few bugs : sometimes, a 2 second part of a music was looping, the game has frequently lags, it has also minor bugs with shadows and water effects, it also happened rarely though that the game simply stopped working. The radgoll is also rarely very buggy. Once, I tried to hide a body, but for unknown reasons he got stuck in the floor, so I couldn't move it, and the other guards noticed it. Or another time, a body I was hiding as well just roused itself from me and landed just before a guard. That was annoyng :p But bugs did not alter the overall game's experience. The same can't really be said for the other big problems of this game. Because it feels so real, any disapointment is extremely frustrating.Let's talk about side quests : There is one character, not linked with the game's plot at all, who has a very endealling personality. You can help her getting out of an extremely bad situation. However, as soon as you do, you won't see her anymore. She disappears without explanation. Side quest is done. As if you only saved her because you're completionist and have to do all side quests. There's that other character who has a very big problem as well. When you finished helping, and if you come back to speak to her, she just talks like a decoration NPC, saying "thanks" while looking at her Iphone or whatever. Such aspects of the game should have been more worked. I do as many side quests as I can and I feel really flung into them, for that reason it really makes me feel those aspects of the game are botched.Now the ending : I found it weak. I'm not talking about the story, but how they made the ending. Adam Jensen has a choice to make. I only tested two choices, and they're dispaointing. For two reasons. The first it that it only gets us to see a video made of real videos (which doesn't fit at all with the game and seems to be botched) where Adam Jensen is reading a pupil's dissertation, quoting Albert Einstein like any dumbass do (I'm sorry if you do, but let's admit it, it's as stupid as mentioning the nazis in a debate, as I just did in some ways :/ ).The second reason is going to spoil :  we can choose to tell the truth about the augmentations problem. I made this choice at first because I thought making up accusations against the humanity front without any proves could be uncovered and because there would be no ways any augmentation incident could result in the world definitely rejecting the augmentation technology. Nothing could lead to that in my opinion. It's also the opinion of the scientist who worked with the Deus Ex team. Yet, in this game, if you decide to tell the truth, Adam speaks as if you made this choice because technology is bad and that the choice you made will prevent humans from making the error of using augmentations and  technology again. First, I don't think there could be any benefits rejecting technology. Lastly, it's impossible. Humans will never reject technology.

I would definitely recommend this game, but keep in mind these thhings:-if you are  the kind of person that prefers storming into bases while riding an elephant and waving a bazooka around , you might have some trouble here 3:) The game does give you deadly takedown options, and has a variety of weapons -not too extensive but overall sufficient- used to kill, but firing a single bullet can cause troops of enemies to sudenly appear, and let me tell you, they are highly accurate, and your reloading takes a while, so you're better off silently stunning them or looking around for other possible ways. This game rewards you overall for being stealthy, with XP, bonuses, etc, but I for some people it can be really frustrating, sneaking away without killing that one annoying soldier xDBoss fights on the other hand require "open-field" fighting...Hacking and stealthing around could get you somewhere but you need to actively fight them to proceed.-The replayability factor is imo about average, but with the new game+ option you can keep your augmentations (aka skills) in the new game. Especially helpful if aiming for achievements. The game took me around 55 hours to finish.-If you're more of the "I'm here for the story" type, you might find the ending kinda disappointing. I enjoyed the game overall so I didnt mind it THAT much, but, well...Other than that the game is perfect, and since I got it on sale I can easily say this was the best 5$ I ever spent!!

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
« Get that♥♥♥♥♥♥outta my face, 'fore I shove it up yo'♥♥♥♥♥.»- Random pedestrian in Detroit, sharing his valuable opinionDeus Ex: Human Revolution is the long-anticipated prequel to the legendary game from 2000 and kind of an attempt to please both newcomers to series and connoisseurs of the first Deus Ex.I played the first Deus Ex before and while I don't think it's the greatest PC game ever made (like many proclaimed before me), I still do find it excellent. It was an innovative mix of stealth, FPS action, hacking and conspiracy theories, garnished with a great level design and a memorable electronic soundtrack. Then Invisible War hit the market in 2003 - more or less well received by players who were new to series, but not really appreciated by fans of the first game (to put it mildly).A few years passed, and meanwhile Eidos Interactive was taken over by Square Enix. The new studio in Montreal planned to make good use of the strong IP that the old Eidos left behind, so soon later a new Deus Ex was already in the making.Human Revolution takes place 20 years before the events of the original Deus Ex, in a world where mechanical augmentation of the human body is in great demand; but also highly debated. You play as Adam Jensen, a former SWAT-cop who now works as the security chief of Sarif, one of the world's biggest biotech corporations. After a mysterious terrorist attack on the company Adam Jensen gets fatally wounded and some villains seem to have kidnapped his ex-girlfriend. His life is saved though by his own employer, who installs state-of-the-art augmentations into his body. It's now up to the player to find out more about the motives of the mysterious attackers and the whereabouts of his ex-girlfriend. It's needless to say that things get pretty hairy during his journey around the world...So did Eidos Montreal manage at the end to satisfy both newcomers and fans of the series? I think yes, hell yeah. Many features from the first game were gracefully re-imagined in Human Revolution, even if some of them are missing (like the legendary Spy Drone). Like in the first game you can choose to take either the peaceful way of handling the story or instead being the trigger-happy FPS fella. You don't like finding secret entrances through air vents? Then simply punch a hole into the weak wall. You feel mercy for your enemies and you want to spare their lives? Simply calm them down with your tranquilizer rifle or sneak around them. Like in the first game you can look out for main and side quests, and how you solve them it's completely up to you. Big time amount of replay value.The different augmentations can turn out pretty useful, at some points of the game they are even badly needed. Especially if you intend to take the stealth path or to reach secret areas you almost depend on them. Looking through walls, jumping from enormous hights or being able to see through the intentions of your conversation partners can come in quite handy.Of course not every aspect of Human Revolution is spotless. The level design, while still solid in its base, isn't as widespread and complex as in Deus Ex 1. Especially the sewers in Detroit and Hengsha look pretty repetitive and bland. Also the many hacking sections can get pretty annoying, especially if all what you get are some trivial emails for the umpteenth time. You'll hack a lot in this game, if not too much. Also the last sections of the game aren't as challenging and spectacular as I've expected - Ion Storm did definitely a better job in 2000.But apart from these points I really enjoyed this title and you can easily spend some 40 hours into it. Originally I haven't expected the game to be that good, despite its minor flaws. Explore the dark corners of the Mega-Metropolis Hengsha, discover many references and hints to the first game or try to beat the game in different ways. There's a lot to do and see in Human Revolution.The Good:+ Flawless presentation+ Atmospheric soundtrack+ Interesting stealth and combat+ Augmentations+ Solid story+ Overall a worthy prequel to the originalThe Bad:- Level design sometimes bland- Repetitive hacking- Final section of the game not so spectacularEither way, for the most rewarding and authentic experience I suggest to play Human Revolution with the most difficult settings and without any ingame help features as well. Also remember that there's always still another option for solving a problem in this fantastic game - consider all scenarios.9/10«Oh, and by the way, Jensen? I know you have gone through a lot of physical changes as of late, but you didn't become a woman. Stay out of the ladies restroom.»- Frank Pritchard

content:
Posted: September 11, 2016
												It's not a bad game, and I did enjoy it while I was playing... But after I beat the game, I felt like it was a bit unfinished.The story revolves around you being nearly killed then being turned into a cyborg.What I remember the story was supposed to be about was the tension between cyborgs and normal people, what I got was a revenge story about you hunting your girlfriend's killers... Then ends with cyborg vs normal people.The game is supposed to be a mixture of FPS, RPG, and stealth... but they all feel unfinished.---FPS:The camera switched between first and third person, based on if you're leaned against a wall. This is disorienting at first, but you get used to it.The shooting mechanics feel off. You can enter iron sights, only if you're in first person view. So, if you're using cover you have to use the reticle to aim.There is a small variety of weapons, giving you free choice on how to approach a situation, but I started the game with a pistol and that's what I used throughout the entire game.I carried a silenced sniper rifle with me throughout, and used it maybe 5 times. The combat is very in your face.There is a nice ability to beat down an enemy when they get too close, and it does have very nice animations associated with it.The controls for PC were awkward. Iron sights, crouching, and sprinting are all toggle with no option to change this, and I often fumbled with switching between cover.---Stealth:I can't help but compare this to Metal Gear Solid. I loved the stealth mechanics in MGS, not so much in Deus Ex.You can hide behind walls or inside vents... but that's pretty much the extent of stealth.There is a cloaking ability that you can learn, but it only lasts long enough to rush through a small room, or perhaps across a hallway.There isn't an easy way to distract guards. The only way I found to make noise was to shoot a silenced weapon at a wall.There are no places to hide and there are no items that help with stealth. (noise making grenades, traps, etc)Enemies stay unconscious forever, which is nice, and will be woken up if found by another guard. So hiding bodies is recommended.The guards themselves have simple patrol paths, but there is usually so many guards that it makes it near impossible to get around them all without the cloaking ability.Most of my stealth encounters ended up in a gun fight.---RPG:Deus Ex talks itself up a lot for giving you a choice in how to approach the game. "Play your way."The issue with this is that the abilities are very much FPS based.Everyone needs it:Hacking allows you to unlock security locks and computers, which gives you lore and access codes to make it easier to get through the missions.But hacking is either completely necessary or completely unnecessary... You will run into security locks throughout the entire game. If you don't research hacking, you will miss out on weapons, ammo, money, experience, etc.But, since they want to offer you a choice in everything, you never need to be a strong hacker to finish the storyline. There is always an alternative route.Stealth players:There is the cloaking ability and silent moving for stealth players.Cloaking doesn't last very long, and you still make a lot of noise when moving, so you must have both cloaking and silent moving to be effective.There is also the ability to see the enemies' vision cones and see how far sound is travelling (though I never found that one useful)You can learn to see through walls, but I never put any points into this, as the radar is perfectly fine for telling where the enemy is and where they're looking.Action players:Most of the other abilities.Take more damage, better recoil handling, prevent status effectsThe rest of the abilities are more about exploring, which falls back into more... weapons, ammo, money, experience, etc.So from an RPG aspect, there is a very minor class archetype, then everything else is pretty much, if you don't learn it, you miss out.---Deus Ex also talks up the choice between killing and not killing. This doesn't effect the story, though people will use different dialog when speaking to you.The problem I have with this system is how it's divided on abilities and weapons. There are very few non-lethal weapons, and they don't make it easy to use them.There is a short range taser, a sniper rifle that shoots tranquilizer darts (single shot, very long reload time and most enemies are near each other so timing is very important), very few grenades, and a air gun of sorts for crowds (that I never used)The only other options would be to outright avoid combat (less exp) or stick with "takedowns" which are essentially stealth kills. When using a takedown, you can choose lethal or non-lethal.Lethal is louder, alerting other enemies, offers less exp, and uses the same button, but you must hold the button down instead of just tapping it. (making it a bit more cumbersome to use)So, there is no point in using a lethal takedown.My choice was to use non-lethal takedowns when convenient, and if I got into a fight, shoot everyone dead.--------------So, overall... I enjoyed the game while I was playing it. It took up a few days of my time. But I didn't feel like it was very good.The story lacked depth, the combat was ok, and the promise of choose your own style fell short.

 DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine Deus Ex: Human Revolution and its directors cut counterpart is a game developed by Eidos Montreal and published by Square Enix and is a reboot to the classic stealth franchise of the same nameThe main character is Adam Jensen, head of security in the company Sarif Industries, which during the attack is badly wounded and is rescued thanks to the numerous operations and body modifications.Deus Ex: Human Revolution is an immersive if somewhat deep in gameplay and open-ended FPS RPG involving conspiracy, international conflict, human dilemmas, spying people's emails, choice and dialogue makingIt is truly an amazing game. The level of detail, the graphics, the storyline and hardly and bugs/glitches throughout the whole gameThe only "big" problem with the directors cut version is the integrated DLC. While it's a well made and lengthy expansion that tries to innovate, it feels like it's measnt to be played after the main story and the way it's just tacked in there will cause a substantial difficulty-spike first time throughThe gameplay is great and you can finish the game while killing everyone or completely anybody while passing near them. This production is brilliant, it offers a great story, a lot of nice and diffrent locations, incredible soundtrack and interesting charactersThe game is definitely set to silent approach. Shooting using a guns is ok but it is not so cool. According to me, this is a brilliant title that offers a lot and is pretty well made stealth game. This title is a definitely worth of our timeThat said, you can't get much more polished and enjoyable AAA stealth gameplay this cheap! RECOMMENDED :)

Posted: February 25
												An absolute masterpiece, honestly one of the best games I've ever played, hands down, I can't possibly recommend this game anymore. The story is amazing, it always keeps you on your toes with twists and turns, and choices DO matter, not as much as they may matter in other games, but they still matter enough to be remotely satisfying. The stealth is brilliantly crafted, and very fun, and I don't even like stealth games. The combat is great as well. There are so many different weapons, and there is so much freedom with how you want to tackle your enemies, whether they live, or die. I'm sad the game is over, but I'm excited to pick it up again soon, with New Game+. 9/10

												I'm lucky I only paid $5 for this craptastic game.  Other than the graphics, there's nothing great about this game. Mediocre plot mixed with terrible controls and physics.  The last straw that made me write this review was that I just died after blowing a full 5 rounds with a magnum dead center on an enemy and it was as if I was shooting blanks.  The aiming is god awful and back in my day head shots actually did damage. As for the "stealth" killing aspect, it has been done and was even better in the Metal Gears which were like 10+ years before this game.  This game would be like Tenchu: Stealth Assasins but you get ranged weapons that miss like 90% of the time regardless of where you aim.  It is so bad that you can have an enemy walk into a doorway and you can blast your shot gun point blank and still miss.  It is so bad that this is the only game on Steam I have ever written a review for in hopes that no one ever buys this game again.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2016
												Even after years, this game remained one of my alltime favorites. Deus Ex: Human Revolution in the director's cut brings the base game and the DLC "the missing link" together in one game and delivers a good connection between the two content packages.With 3 different difficulties and even a new game + mode, this game also offers different ways to progress through the story with a lethal and also a pacifist playstyle. I just finished my pacifist run and was surprised in a positive way how the game supports my choice to finish the game, in being not too difficult and still holding my tension through choosing the right augmentations and the right time to activate them to continue unseen. Sometimes direct combat is still necessary so keep watching for ammo for the stun gun!Only thing I dislike is that there is no option to not kill the bosses in this game, but with the new director's cut  there are some more possibilites than just pure combat.Other than that, Deus Ex: Human Revolution is after all a great game, bringing up big questions about augmentations and the human nature, without being too pretentious.

number of helpful: 4 of 8 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 4, 2013
												More game, better bosses, and less yellow. It's still amazing that this game somehow escaped being just another classic IP completely ruined by foolish publishers.One solid look at this game will show it was made by fans for fans who actually meant what they said about loving everything that made the original great, it also manages to marry common console gimmicks like cover and regenerating health into an enjoyable experience. Every obstacle can be over come in so many different ways and the xp/praxis system is an ideal compromise of the original Deus Ex's skill system and Invisible War's over simplification of augmentations. Callbacks, shout outs, and little details that refer to the original help cement this game's ties to Deus Ex while maintaining its own plotline dealing with transhumanisim and the ethics behind augmentation, this game wasn't just an excuse by Eidos to try to grab cash, it's a worthy prequel to one of the best games ever designed and it's been made that much better by dealing with the problems the original release had while integrating The Missing Link into one large seamless experience.

number of helpful: 20 of 41 people (49%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 10, 2016
												This game was a huge disappointment for me. A Deus Ex game should have delivered a great story with nefarious conspiracies, and game objectives that could be completed in multiple ways. In this game the story makes absolutely no sense, the biggest "conspiracy" is that television lies, you barely discover anything about the organizations and the people behind the events, the whole augmentation debate is discussed on kindergarten-level, and the ending is mind-meltingly stupid. I could write an entire book about how badly written this game is. It's true that multiple playstyles are supported, but there is an optimal one that is heavily favored by the game rules: stay undetected, use only nonlethal melee takedowns (yes, this game is not a shooter), and hack everything. If you follow the optimal style, all weapons, ammo, and weapon mods are useless (take the laser rifle to the last boss though), all health-restoring items are useless, and there is no difference between the difficulty levels either, because every enemy goes down with a single button press. The only difficulty is finding the correct order of taking down the guards without alerting the remaining ones, but thanks to the rtarded patrol routes it's usually quite easy. I could list the flaws in the game mechanics for pages, but it's tl;dr anyway. The boss fights are often criticized for being out-of-place, but the real issue is that the boss characters have no part in the story other than appearing as an obstacle at a certain point. Overall, this game is not completely awful, for example, the dialog challenges are interesting, the hacking minigame is nice, the visual design is impressive, and I liked some of the side-quests. My biggest grief is that for lots of people this is The Deus Ex Game, while in reality both its predecessors were vastly superior in almost every way. Oh, and why does the DC version occupy twice the disk space as the original release?Edit: I watched the developer commentaries on youtube, and it's mind-numbing how incompetent and clueless they are (except for the sound designer guy).Edit 2: I watched some steam broadcasts, and it turns out most people play this game like CoD. Disappointing.

content:
Posted: April 15, 2014
												I'm a big fan of the Deus Ex series. Human Revolution was a really worthy return to the Cyberpunk series. However I can't recommend this release at all. It's nothing more than an outsourced poorly realized package. Design choices in terms of the lighting were completely thrown out as just one example, another is just how incredibly buggy it is.The lighting that I refer to was a "gold" tint of perhaps Jensen's augmentations in first person and even indicative perhaps of a "new renaissance" thematically. This was in promotional footage, cases etc. There are other visual differences but this is the biggest. They completely ignored the original teams aesthetics and choices.If you were an unlucky soul that happened to have a PC which had both a dedicated and integrated video card the game wouldn't even launch. Nvidia users that the game actually worked for also reported unplayable performance on a wide variety of GPUs.The "Director's Cut" label is nothing more than a marketing con. It was outsourced and it shows with design choices of the original team ignored to the quality of the release altogether. I will treasure my original PS3 copy even more now due to the original release no longer being available on steam as this is not a definitive Deus Ex release, not even close.Edit/ This AWESOME person has made a small mod using Sweetfx making it possible to return HR a little to what it was. http://www.gamefaqs.com/boards/719090-deus-ex-human-revolution-directors-cut/67658785 Doesn't fix everything but it is very welcome as I'm sure it is by a lot of other people.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2015
												To save his life, the fundamental choice of whether or not to become augmented with cybernetics has been removed from Adam Jensen's life. Driven by the conviction of never having a choice taken from him again and using his newfound power, his need for answers will unravel the truth behind a conspiracy rooted in the foundation of the world around him as it incites a new revolution.Deus Ex: Human Revolution follows up on the critically acclaimed Deus EX and Deus Ex: Invisible War as the the third game in the strategic sci-fi action series. When a black ops team breaks in and kills the scientists Adam were hired to protect as a guard of one of America's most experimental biotechnology firms, everything you thought you knew about your job changes. At a time when scientific advancements are routinely turning athletes, soldiers and spies into super-enhanced beings, someone is working very hard to ensure mankind's evolution follows a particular path. You need to discover why -- because the decisions you take and the choices you make will be the only things that can determine mankind's future.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
												This is one of the best games i've ever played, thankfully one of my friends convinced me to get all the other deus ex games when i got mankind divided, anyways...The shooter aspect in this game is better then any other fps game i've seen. The cover system is pretty wonky using mouse and keyboard but thats fine, i've had worse. The use of the cover system when trying to be stealthy is also amazing. I always try to be stealthy in this game even though i really suck at it. It feels so good to get that Ghost pop up when you finish a mission. The hacking part in this game is pretty cool too, thought later in the game it just gets too easy and tedious in my opinion. The story with the choices you make during it with certain people is phenomenal, I haven't seen such unique facial expressions either, this game nails it in to you for what the person you're talking too feels. Another factor that I love is the inventory system, I haven't played a game in a long time that uses that type of system and it is my favorite out of any. Makes it seeem at least somewhat realistic in my sense. The only problem i've had so far is some audio glitches when you hold your gun up to someone and try to talk to them. This game earned a full 100% or whatever out of me.

content:
Posted: August 21, 2016
												Astonishing cyberpunk experience with rather distinct vibes from movies like Blade Runner and Robocop. Easily one of my favorite games of all time. Gameplay is enjoyable and unique and the story isn't bad either, in fact it has a quite deep meaning. The game deals with fairly heavy themes like what it means to be a human, is self controlled evolution right, is controlling and manipulating masses necessarily evil and does our advancement in technology allow the discrimination of those who can't afford the newest conveniences. Human Revolution leans heavily on stealth, which can be frustrating for those who are used to more action packed approach, as the game practically punishes the player if he decides to go guns blazing into the action. All in all I would recommend this game for those who enjoy stealth games and the cyberpunk setting. Also someone who finds enjoyment in conspiracy theories might find this game interesting, but then again I'm not going to spoil anything! Just see it for youself.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Deus Ex: Human Revolution is a masterpiece of a game. The AI may not be very good, but the theme, story, and lore that is vibrant throughout the streets of Detroit and other areas you visit in the year 2027 is great to take in. You play as Adam Jensen, an ex-cop working security for Sarif Industries, a human augmentation company. After you are attacked, you recieve augmentations that make you almost super human, and it's accompanied by RPG style leveling and upgrades that make you stonger, carry more, hack easier, jump higher etc... The gameplay is fun, and you have the choice of dealing with your enemies lethally or non-lethally. Both of which are satisfying. The gunplay works, the stealth is sorta strange, as it's a little too easy because of somewhat dumb AI. But all in all, if you like games like this, you will love this game and probably replay it at least once. Not to mention the directors cut, featuring a standalone DLC tie in to the actual game, which is an improvement. The developer logs are also a nice touch, as well as the reworked bosses. I highly recommend this game.

From what I can see, there is no known fix to this problem outside of restoring to an earlier save, and the problem has been known since at least 2013.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												Deus Ex Human Revolution is a great game - a great game with an awful last act, one that brings down the rest of the game with it.  The DLC was "okay", but not essential by any stretch of the imagination.The Director's Cut is a mess.First of all, the performance. In the original, standalone game, there were initially some performance issues - periodic frame hiccups when the game streams area data if you were lucky, low framerate across the board if you weren't.  They fixed this, and the standalone game runs beautifully now.  The Directors Cut is not based on the most recent version, like you would expect.  The awful framerate and obnoxious frame hiccups are back, and it doesn't look like Squeenix has any intention of fixing this.There are some registry settings you can change to make the performance "better", but if you've already got the original version (which is, sadly, no longer sold), there's virtually no reason to bother with the Director's Cut.  All the Director's Cut does is cram the game, the pre-order garbage, and the DLC together haphazardly, and gives you a few more options against the bosses.  The latter addition is very much welcome, as you can actually focus on a non-combat build if you'd like now, but the former makes the concept of a "build" even more laughably irrelevant.  The original game had this problem where, after a certain point, you're so stocked with abilities that there is nothing off limits to you.  A bad fighter isn't forced to hack - because you're a killing machine.  And a bad hacker isn't forced to fight - because you're a hax0r par excellence.  Plus you can jump around and throw dumpsters and go invisible.  It defeats the purpose of the game's open-ended design, where your ability choices will be helpful in some situations and a liability in others, so that you try and find a way to avoid those disadvantageous situations.  Since they duct taped the DLC on, this problem is even worse.  Yes, you still lose all your equipment and abilities at the start of the DLC, but at the end you get all your equipment back and a load of praxis equalling the amount you entered the DLC area with, meaning by the end of the game you're completely maxed out.  It makes the Singapore area a joke, and it makes the final area...  well, the final area is completely worthless any way you slice it.Deus Ex Human Revolution is one of the better big budget AAA games of the last several years - it has its issues, but it's definitely worth playing.  The Director's Cut is not.  Avoid.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												Technology is a double-edged sword. While it provides us with many benefits, in a way it also causes mankind to become divided. Deus Ex: Human Revolution is a game which questions mature themes such at this, and delivers an amazing story complemented by satisfying and fun gameplay, providing players with choices that determine the how the game plays out, giving us control over the game world that other game rarely provide. Let me go into detail below.  As hinted a while ago, Deus Ex: Human Revolution is set in the future, 2027 to be exact. In this age, technology has advanced to the stage where humans can implement technology into their own bodies, to change and supposedly "improve" one's capabilities. These are called augmentations, and usually replace parts of our body. The discovery and invention of augmentations by celebrated scientist Hugh Darrow has caused much conflict among mankind: some think that augmentations are very useful for humans, as augmentations such as retinal augs and neural augmentations can make life very convenient for us; others, however, think that augmentations take away our humanity, and binding of flesh and metal is against our very own human nature. In the game, you play as Adam Jensen, an ex-Swat with a troubled past, who gets hired by Sarif Industries, one of the leading developers of augmentations, as a security guard. However, a mysterious group of augmented mercenaries attack Sarif Industries headquarters, killing many scientists and badly injuring Jensen. Against his will, Jensen is subjected to extensive augmentation to rebuild his body, giving him new and powerful abilities, but causing him a certain extent of mental scarring. Back on his feet with the new augmentations, he is tasked with investigating the attack and finding the people behind it, eventually uncovering a conspiracy that is not only against Sarif Industries, but the whole world. The game has a very strong premise, and it takes many twists and turns which I cannot divulge here, as it would ruin the experience. The best way to experience the story is if you have almost no clue about the plot, since the surprises had a much bigger impact on me that way. The story is able to surprise the player many times, and it is able to explore themes such as whether progress is truly for the greater good. Characters and dialogue are all very well-done and thought-out, and the game contains many memorable characters that each have motives that are neither black or white.  A big part of this game is choice: you have a choice on many aspects of the game, which all influence the outcomes of situations and the ending of the game, as well as the attitude NPCs in the game will have towards you. Your playstyle is one of the major choices you have to make; the game supports both loud and stealthy playstyles, and you can also incorporate a bit of both, like I did for most playthroughs. The stealth in this game is pretty basic, and you cannot lure enemies with noise or anything like a lot of stealth game; as long as you stay out of enemies’ line of sight, and stay away from cameras and sentry guns, you can remain undetected. For a loud playstyle, the game becomes pretty much Call of Duty and every other first person action shooter ever. The game, however, seems to encourage stealthy approaches more, as seen from NPC reactions and overall outcomes, as well as giving more XP for stealthy approaches. Despite this slight bias, I think that the game is very open and allows the player a lot of freedom. Through a few playthroughs of different scenarios, I found that many missions can have lots of different approaches, and countless different outcomes depending on how you play.  And that brings me to the skill tree in this game, known in-game as augmentations. XP is earned by doing actions such as discovering secret areas, performing takedowns, killing enemies, completing quests and being able to persuade someone in a conversation. Once you have enough XP, you are rewarded with Praxis points (which are basically just skill points), which you can use to buy augmentations. These skills are all generally useful and fun to use, but many are evidently meant to be used in certain playstyles. For example, the hacking skills are best used in stealth playthroughs, since by hacking, you can deactivate cameras and sentry guns, and also gain access codes or even gain entry to alternate paths. Alternatively, armor strengthening skills are more ideal for loud playthroughs, as they allow you to hold on longer in firefights. Since you have limited points, you must choose wisely, and forces players to use critical thinking and tactics during gameplay. I like this type of style, since you won't be blindly blundering into an area and firing at everything, but instead thinking about approaches and planning strategies. Because it is impossible to just enter a room and kill everything. Like I said, the game seems to support stealth more, as enemies can have a ton of health and even at medium difficulty, Jensen may only be able to survive a couple of shots. The game forces you to think, which is a good point in my opinion. However, while for the most part, the game seems to be stealth-oriented, you are forced into combat in several unnecessary boss fights. Boss fights are really one of the biggest negative points of this game, as they are unavoidable. Sure, the Director's cut allows you to use stealth to an extent during the bosses, but you are ultimately forced into direct combat with these bosses, who are all underdeveloped and just cartoonish, with only Namir seeming to have some sort of backstory.  Choices also extend to dialogue choices. In the game, you will interact with several NPCs, who will have information you need or are in a situation you must defuse. Such examples include an NPCs holding a hostage, an NPC threatening to commit suicide and so on. In these situations, your choices will affect the fates to the NPCs, and requires quick thinking and intuition to succeed. Augmentations can also be used to ease this process. Overall, it is a great mechanic in the game and it is interesting to see the various incomes of different attitudes towards them.  The game, while having beautiful architecture and some downright stunning backdrops, as well as atmospheric lighting, the game's graphics are hardly its strong point. Water effects and many character models look dated, and seem as though they walked straight out of a decade-old game. Adam Jensen and a few important NPC character models look amazing at certain angles, but it seems the developers focused on the quality of story and gameplay more. Luckily, the graphics don't detract much from the overall experience, and the game is optimized well enough, maintaining 100 fps or above on my rig.  The Director's Cut Edition includes the DLC, the Missing Link, which is a mandatory part of the game, and feels like a standalone section of its own, detailing a little adventure that Adam has while stowing away on a boat towards the final section. The story is alright, with several plots twists, but it ultimately suffers from a cliched villain and an overall feeling of unnecessity. Backtracking several areas, as well as mostly being forced into stealth, is among the reasons this DLC is overshadowed by the main game. Also, all of your skills and weapons are removed, which takes a lot from the enjoyment. However, it is not as bad as many people say, and is a cool little mission of its own that takes one to two hours to complete, adding a new stunning environment for Jensen to explore, although without the memorable characters of the main game.  Deus Ex: Human Revolution may not be a genre-defining game, but it takes all the great things from modern-day RPGs, combined with a great story, to deliver an amazing and engrossing game, and you owe it to yourself to try it out.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2016
												Hi,Wow, what a game! The beginning seemed as nothing special and I did not have any bigger expectations but what came after totally blew me away. I need to mention that this is my first approach to Deus Ex game.Pros:-	The story has really got my attention – we will see how it develops-	Shooting •	properly difficult – you are out after one head-shot and you do the same to your foes•	very responsive-	Hacking – love the idea-	Dialogue•	feels very natural and the voice acting is really good•	I really like NPCs comments on what you have done (Example: How you are being told off by Pritchard for strolling into ladies rest room  or if you kill too many people your co-workers will judge you.•	Choices given to you during dialogue are straight to the point and I have a feeling they matter-	Inventory -	Levelling up – quite innovative for me at least-	You can shoot and kill friendly npcs/civilians (at least some of them)-	World feels alive with all the talking around and a lot f NPCIn the middle-	Graphics are a bit dated but that isn’t really con for me; this game is dated 2013 on steam but I have a feeling it is a bit older than thatCons:-	The beginning of the game does not impress – feels like just another shooter in which you just go forward and cannot collect almost anything-	Rewards for being stealthy and not killing anyone – Where are the rewards for killing every one of these ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ alive?-	Save/load every-time-you-like system – this is a bit outdated now, they should have come up with something better like even checkpoints. I do really appreciate save systems like in Diablo, Dark Souls or Lords of the Fallen.-	Sprint does not really feel like a proper sprint at all – protagonist is out of steam after 2 seconds or so. Shouldn’t android be in a better shape?-	Where are the driving cars in the city?My rating: 9/10 so far but I will update the review later onUPDATE:-	After hours of gameplay I must admit that the game starts to disappoints. It all gets repetitive and boring… Levels are very similar with nothing really interesting about them. Now I just changed from “Exploring-every-centimetre-of-the-game” to “rushing-towards-end”. It all  can be displayed on the following diagram:  _/`````\----- (beginning poo, then the middle great and the end not as bad as beginning but really boring) -	Same enemies all over again… -	They give me way more exp for not killing hostiles, so I kill everyone – go with a bang every time-	Perks has got nothing interesting to offer after a while and I almost level up by random-	Side mission as much as they were interesting in first and second chapter from the riots they are really boring-	Enemies are really stupid – I find this issue with every stealth or/and FPS + Great main story – I still play the game to see where is Megan + Hacking is still fun+ Combat is still fast and responsive+ Great cut scenesALL IN ALL: After like 20 hours gameplay I will still recommend the game but I do not longer thing it stands out that much. It has some nice things to offer and is easily enjoyable but my rating drops down quite heavily from 9/10 to 6+/10.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												Technology is a double-edged sword. While it provides us with many benefits, in a way it also causes mankind to become divided. Deus Ex: Human Revolution is a game which questions mature themes such at this, and delivers an amazing story complemented by satisfying and fun gameplay, providing players with choices that determine the how the game plays out, giving us control over the game world that other game rarely provide. Let me go into detail below.  As hinted a while ago, Deus Ex: Human Revolution is set in the future, 2027 to be exact. In this age, technology has advanced to the stage where humans can implement technology into their own bodies, to change and supposedly "improve" one's capabilities. These are called augmentations, and usually replace parts of our body. The discovery and invention of augmentations by celebrated scientist Hugh Darrow has caused much conflict among mankind: some think that augmentations are very useful for humans, as augmentations such as retinal augs and neural augmentations can make life very convenient for us; others, however, think that augmentations take away our humanity, and binding of flesh and metal is against our very own human nature. In the game, you play as Adam Jensen, an ex-Swat with a troubled past, who gets hired by Sarif Industries, one of the leading developers of augmentations, as a security guard. However, a mysterious group of augmented mercenaries attack Sarif Industries headquarters, killing many scientists and badly injuring Jensen. Against his will, Jensen is subjected to extensive augmentation to rebuild his body, giving him new and powerful abilities, but causing him a certain extent of mental scarring. Back on his feet with the new augmentations, he is tasked with investigating the attack and finding the people behind it, eventually uncovering a conspiracy that is not only against Sarif Industries, but the whole world. The game has a very strong premise, and it takes many twists and turns which I cannot divulge here, as it would ruin the experience. The best way to experience the story is if you have almost no clue about the plot, since the surprises had a much bigger impact on me that way. The story is able to surprise the player many times, and it is able to explore themes such as whether progress is truly for the greater good. Characters and dialogue are all very well-done and thought-out, and the game contains many memorable characters that each have motives that are neither black or white.  A big part of this game is choice: you have a choice on many aspects of the game, which all influence the outcomes of situations and the ending of the game, as well as the attitude NPCs in the game will have towards you. Your playstyle is one of the major choices you have to make; the game supports both loud and stealthy playstyles, and you can also incorporate a bit of both, like I did for most playthroughs. The stealth in this game is pretty basic, and you cannot lure enemies with noise or anything like a lot of stealth game; as long as you stay out of enemies’ line of sight, and stay away from cameras and sentry guns, you can remain undetected. For a loud playstyle, the game becomes pretty much Call of Duty and every other first person action shooter ever. The game, however, seems to encourage stealthy approaches more, as seen from NPC reactions and overall outcomes, as well as giving more XP for stealthy approaches. Despite this slight bias, I think that the game is very open and allows the player a lot of freedom. Through a few playthroughs of different scenarios, I found that many missions can have lots of different approaches, and countless different outcomes depending on how you play.  And that brings me to the skill tree in this game, known in-game as augmentations. XP is earned by doing actions such as discovering secret areas, performing takedowns, killing enemies, completing quests and being able to persuade someone in a conversation. Once you have enough XP, you are rewarded with Praxis points (which are basically just skill points), which you can use to buy augmentations. These skills are all generally useful and fun to use, but many are evidently meant to be used in certain playstyles. For example, the hacking skills are best used in stealth playthroughs, since by hacking, you can deactivate cameras and sentry guns, and also gain access codes or even gain entry to alternate paths. Alternatively, armor strengthening skills are more ideal for loud playthroughs, as they allow you to hold on longer in firefights. Since you have limited points, you must choose wisely, and forces players to use critical thinking and tactics during gameplay. I like this type of style, since you won't be blindly blundering into an area and firing at everything, but instead thinking about approaches and planning strategies. Because it is impossible to just enter a room and kill everything. Like I said, the game seems to support stealth more, as enemies can have a ton of health and even at medium difficulty, Jensen may only be able to survive a couple of shots. The game forces you to think, which is a good point in my opinion. However, while for the most part, the game seems to be stealth-oriented, you are forced into combat in several unnecessary boss fights. Boss fights are really one of the biggest negative points of this game, as they are unavoidable. Sure, the Director's cut allows you to use stealth to an extent during the bosses, but you are ultimately forced into direct combat with these bosses, who are all underdeveloped and just cartoonish, with only Namir seeming to have some sort of backstory.  Choices also extend to dialogue choices. In the game, you will interact with several NPCs, who will have information you need or are in a situation you must defuse. Such examples include an NPCs holding a hostage, an NPC threatening to commit suicide and so on. In these situations, your choices will affect the fates to the NPCs, and requires quick thinking and intuition to succeed. Augmentations can also be used to ease this process. Overall, it is a great mechanic in the game and it is interesting to see the various incomes of different attitudes towards them.  The game, while having beautiful architecture and some downright stunning backdrops, as well as atmospheric lighting, the game's graphics are hardly its strong point. Water effects and many character models look dated, and seem as though they walked straight out of a decade-old game. Adam Jensen and a few important NPC character models look amazing at certain angles, but it seems the developers focused on the quality of story and gameplay more. Luckily, the graphics don't detract much from the overall experience, and the game is optimized well enough, maintaining 100 fps or above on my rig.  The Director's Cut Edition includes the DLC, the Missing Link, which is a mandatory part of the game, and feels like a standalone section of its own, detailing a little adventure that Adam has while stowing away on a boat towards the final section. The story is alright, with several plots twists, but it ultimately suffers from a cliched villain and an overall feeling of unnecessity. Backtracking several areas, as well as mostly being forced into stealth, is among the reasons this DLC is overshadowed by the main game. Also, all of your skills and weapons are removed, which takes a lot from the enjoyment. However, it is not as bad as many people say, and is a cool little mission of its own that takes one to two hours to complete, adding a new stunning environment for Jensen to explore, although without the memorable characters of the main game.  Deus Ex: Human Revolution may not be a genre-defining game, but it takes all the great things from modern-day RPGs, combined with a great story, to deliver an amazing and engrossing game, and you owe it to yourself to try it out.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2016
												Hi,Wow, what a game! The beginning seemed as nothing special and I did not have any bigger expectations but what came after totally blew me away. I need to mention that this is my first approach to Deus Ex game.Pros:-	The story has really got my attention – we will see how it develops-	Shooting •	properly difficult – you are out after one head-shot and you do the same to your foes•	very responsive-	Hacking – love the idea-	Dialogue•	feels very natural and the voice acting is really good•	I really like NPCs comments on what you have done (Example: How you are being told off by Pritchard for strolling into ladies rest room  or if you kill too many people your co-workers will judge you.•	Choices given to you during dialogue are straight to the point and I have a feeling they matter-	Inventory -	Levelling up – quite innovative for me at least-	You can shoot and kill friendly npcs/civilians (at least some of them)-	World feels alive with all the talking around and a lot f NPCIn the middle-	Graphics are a bit dated but that isn’t really con for me; this game is dated 2013 on steam but I have a feeling it is a bit older than thatCons:-	The beginning of the game does not impress – feels like just another shooter in which you just go forward and cannot collect almost anything-	Rewards for being stealthy and not killing anyone – Where are the rewards for killing every one of these ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ alive?-	Save/load every-time-you-like system – this is a bit outdated now, they should have come up with something better like even checkpoints. I do really appreciate save systems like in Diablo, Dark Souls or Lords of the Fallen.-	Sprint does not really feel like a proper sprint at all – protagonist is out of steam after 2 seconds or so. Shouldn’t android be in a better shape?-	Where are the driving cars in the city?My rating: 9/10 so far but I will update the review later onUPDATE:-	After hours of gameplay I must admit that the game starts to disappoints. It all gets repetitive and boring… Levels are very similar with nothing really interesting about them. Now I just changed from “Exploring-every-centimetre-of-the-game” to “rushing-towards-end”. It all  can be displayed on the following diagram:  _/`````\----- (beginning poo, then the middle great and the end not as bad as beginning but really boring) -	Same enemies all over again… -	They give me way more exp for not killing hostiles, so I kill everyone – go with a bang every time-	Perks has got nothing interesting to offer after a while and I almost level up by random-	Side mission as much as they were interesting in first and second chapter from the riots they are really boring-	Enemies are really stupid – I find this issue with every stealth or/and FPS + Great main story – I still play the game to see where is Megan + Hacking is still fun+ Combat is still fast and responsive+ Great cut scenesALL IN ALL: After like 20 hours gameplay I will still recommend the game but I do not longer thing it stands out that much. It has some nice things to offer and is easily enjoyable but my rating drops down quite heavily from 9/10 to 6+/10.

For people going the action route might not enjoy the controls and the game doesn't really lend itself to the shooter norm. I can not wait for the Mankind Divided.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2013
												Deus Ex: Human Revolution is a really great game with good gameplay and an amazing story. The "Director's Cut" additions add the Missing Link DLC and commentary, along with a couple other things. These aren't as great as they could be. The integration and quality of the commentary is a little poor to be honest, and could be better. The commentary is pretty insightful though, but leaves you a little disappointed because a lot of it is talking about how they cut stuff from the game such as Upper Hengsha, a Bangalore city hub, more missions, and lots of other bits and pieces. If you have DX:HR already, you should buy this because it's 5 or 10 dollars (depending if you have Missing Link or not) and why not. If you don't have DX:HR, you should ABSOLUTELY buy this for an amazing game that is still one of my favorites years later.Also, newgame+ is probably going to be one of my favorite features, but I haven't had a chance to try it yet. When you start a new game, you keep your augs from a previous playthrough. Great idea.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												From my experiences, this game contains no more bugs than it's original version. Stability is good, but I've experienced a few crashes, but not many (I think 5 or less during my 26 hours of game time).The additional DLC content that comes along with the Directors Cut gave me three more hours of content and tied directly into the campaign (occuring at about the 3/4th point). Human Revolution is an RPG FPS that gives the option of non lethal and stealthy means to complete objectives. There are quite a sidequests, and they all reward well.A great game, just like the original version. If you want more details, reading reviews of the non-Director's Cut edition of the game, or by looking at more reviews for this game. I've seen other people complain of major instability with this version, but I've yet to experience any major concerns.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2016
												Deus Ex: Human Revolution is everything that you want from Deus Ex i.e. atmospheric, consequential gameplay, interesting side quests, fantastic soundtrack etc. You chose your path. Every mission can be completed in multiple ways. Exploring your surrounding would also bring joy to you, especially when you find things you haven't seen before. Boss fights, as many have eluded to already, aren't what you expected from a Deus Ex title. If you have played the first game, you know what I am talking about. Director's cut did try and rectify it, but still... The DLC, however, does a good job of showing what the Boss Fights could have been. The RPG elements are well done, but I didn't absolutely like the new melee system (because there is no real hand-to-hand combat). Still, it's a very satisfying experience, and with more Deus Ex coming out in near future, this is one franchise to look forward to.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17, 2015
												This game is really for those who think outside the box. If you want some quick run-and-gun cowboy massacre of a game, then this probably isn't for you. If you're interested in looking at the situation, finding a few alternative paths, and deciding which is for you (i.e. stealth, negotiation tactics, straight up violence, etc.) then this is for you. There are a few glitches and stealth problems though, because the enemies have a one-see-you-and-all-see-you system, and the gunfights in this game, aren't bad, in any sense, but they ARE difficult. It's not like CoD, where you can take 2 deagle rounds to the chest and just walk it off, ya know.

content:
Posted: May 17, 2014
												Over all a yes...It's no original but its good. Especially for people who havent played the original but enjoy fps/rpgs... youll probably think this is the best one. It kinda sucks though just because of the xp system... it rewards you for things that become tedious chances to farm xp... Now this DC version has one real good thing going for it; a new game plus system which lets you play through a second time with all the augs you gained on your first playthrough. I beat the game before it was director's cut (I guess they were "expecting" a game of the year edition... I'm really sick of Canadian game companies at this point... anyways... yeah the new game plus would be sweet....BUT... they included the DLC from the original release... in which you lose all your augs... I'm still playing through the DLC part but I'm pretty sure its not giving me back ALL the augs I had... so more lame xp farming on the play through Im doing... the boss fights are a little better I guess... they just added a few extra paths to the ones I've seen and they still are kinda lame...anyways the game is pretty good tho... good music... cool combat and skills... multiple paths... endings in the original version of the game were kinda lame... but idk if this DC revamped them... at 5 bucks on sale tho... get it

content:
Posted: October 28, 2013
												The definitive form of DXHR. Incorporates all of the previously released DLC into the timeline of the original game.The weapons that you normally get by purchasing them through DLC (Silenced Sniper Rifle, Double Barrel Shotgun) are found in various locations throughout the game, instead of you starting the game with them (removes the "pay to win" aspect). The Grenade Launcher is still a mission reward after you rescue Tracer Tong, and you can still purchase Remote-Detonated Explosives and Automatic Unlocking Devices at any shop.Notes on the way the Missing Link DLC is integrated: Basically, you lose all of the stuff you've acquired throughout the entire game when you begin The Missing Link. After completing The Missing Link, an extra moment has been spliced into the game, where you are left standing next to the exit (which takes you back to the main storyline of the game), and there is a weapons container next to you as well. Upon opening this box, you recieve all of your original Praxis points and items back (you also get to keep anything you got while playing The Missing Link).The improved boss battles are just that - a huge improvement. Remember in the original Deus Ex, when you could kill Walton Simons just by electrocuting him on the rails of a minecart track? You can do things like that in the revised version of DXHR, as well. You're able to dispatch bosses by means of turrets, poison gas, and patrolling sentry robots, in addition to the good old-fashioned "shoot them in the face" strategy. Sadly, you can't just flat-out ignore the bosses like you could in the original DX; you have to kill them for "story purposes".All in all, if you haven't played Deus Ex: Human Revolution yet, first, what is wrong with your brain, and second, the Director's Cut is the only version you should purchase.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 2, 2014
												A little background on where my viewpoint comes from: I have not played Deus Ex Original nor Invisible War, and before this was a complete newbie to these sort of 'fps-stealth-rpg games'. Not a huge deal of experience in shooting games and almost none in stealth games (I find most rather frustrating). However, I found the theme rather intriguing. Without further ado:A game I reccomend to the end of the earth, if you have any intrest in the issues presented by it (transhumansim). Picked this up for $5 on a Steam Sale, easily the best buy I've made in a long while. Very suitably atmospehric and well themed and it godamm manages to make those specs and a trenchcoat look cool.The gameplay is also rather good, with a great mix of both shooting and stealth. The shooting is cover-based and stealth also involves hacking, etc. However, I don't think for somebody that has invested a lot of time into stealth or shooting games that they will find these aspects of the game incredible. Games like Dishunoured would outcompete it in stealth and many games would outcompete it in shooting. However, if you are someone with little experince in either like me, you will find both immensely satisfying and I'm sure even a stealth/shooting veteran could find some good elements. The stealth/shooting is by no means bad, it is actually very good, it just doesn't compete with games dedicated to these apects.Deus Ex: Human Reveloution - A game with an amazing and immersive story, great world building and good stealth and shooting mechanics. My favourite "one time play" (i.e. not a MOBA of online FPS or the replayability of the like) to this date. No doubt.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
												Having beat the original, Non-Director's Cut (the better one anyway), it is insane to me how simple and complicated this game can be; all good factors. Simple in the sense of navigation throughout the cities in Hong-Kong and Detroit and complicated in how you can approach a mission in stealth or balls to the wall action. I also need to add that I get a HUGE feel of Vampire: The Masquerade Bloodlines from this. I cant help but feel like they were influenced when you roam about in these cities and choose side quests and dialogue options. There is even a persuasion option which is really handy and actually feels like you are cutting through butter in terms of personality and behavior.The combat includes gunplay with hiding behind cover in third person. Shooting outside of cover is definitely an option but I would not recommend on higher difficulties. The stealth mechanic is really nice and I love the takedowns with just the tap of a button. Multiple upgrades on your character from immunity to falling from great heights to hacking terminals faster, gives you a greater sense in how you approach missions by finding shortcuts that are supplemental to your upgrade choices. I LOVE THIS!All in all, the game is great and if you can, get the original somewhere. If not, The Director's Cut is decent enough.It's one of those games that you will not realize time passes you by.

content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												Deus Ex: Human Revolution puts the player in the scientific future of 2027. Adam Jensen is the head of security at Sarif Industries, a biotech corporation specializing in human augmentation. Six months after an attack left many scientests dead, Adam wakes up with a large ammount of augemtations implanted to save his live. Adam must travel around the world in search of clues to find out about the attackers at Sarif. The gameplay is truly exelent. It is a stealth game where you can choose to kill or pacify your foes, take many different routes, and use Adam's augmentations to give yourself an advantage. The game is about 25 hours long, so it is definetly worth the price that comes with it. Deus Ex: Mankind Divided is just months away, and nobody can wait for more stealthy, multi-route action.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2016
												This is a fantastic game and i highly reccomend it to anyone who enjoys stealth,fps action,or rpg experiences. There is an extreme level of choice avaliable in the game which is made better with the games excellent level design. The story is not the best ever or anything, but the world the game sets up is incredible and executed in a way that few games are able to achieve. The gameplay is fantastic and varied. Every side quest has more depth than the main quests and other games and has multiple possible outcomes. Depending on how you level up your character you will play the game in entirly different ways. So much so that if you roleplay a different way and choose a different combat style it will feel like a completely different game. The only negativevis the game(particlarly character faces other than the main characters) look fairly bad and graphics do not look fantastic. Despite that the aesthetic is great and there is a high level of detail in the areas. Plus graphics are often the least important part of the experience. Overall you should definently buy this game.        On sale it is 5 dollars which is an absolute steal. It is worth the price even when not on sale.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 13, 2016
												Played the original back on the Xbox 360 and wanted to run through it again before Mankind Divided came out. Human Revolution still holds up after all these years. The graphics and gunplay are a little dated, but everything else still works well.Haven't experienced any bugs or glitches. The game runs smooth. The Director's Cut additions aren't as noticable as I thought they would be. Just minor tweaks here and there.The Missing Link DLC - Didn't enjoy it at all. It adds some interesting plot points near the end of the story, but you're constantly backtracking through the same areas for hours, going through mandatory "bio scans" to move from one area to another and back again. Worst part about it is you lose most of your inventory unless you reupgrade your carrying capacity instead of respec'ing into useful augmentations. Explaining any further is a spoiler, so I won't go into detail. When you continue on with the regular story after the DLC is over, you get ALL of your praxis upgrades back, but you're stuck with whatever weapons you finished the DLC with. It sucks, but I can live with that. I couldn't live with the backtracking though.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												So, I played DXHR a first time, and my review was just "I DIDN'T ASK FOR THIS"I replayed it just to review the upgrade to Director's Cut, and I suppose I should say more than that. So, here goes:The upgrade doesn't fix DXHR's plot, which is an absolute trainwreck. In the CYBERPUNK FUTURE, nobody has heard of drugs, and augmentations are used basically as a word filter for drugs, to an extent that doesn't even make sense. Instead of getting ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s addicted to crack, evil pimps get them implanted with cybernetic enhancements... for better sex, I guess? And anyway it means they get to control them, even though that's not how that works ingame.The gameplay is almost identical to the way it was in default DXHR, and so some really annoying flaws never got fixed.The main addition to this mode is The Missing Link DLC, which is a self-contained mission on a prison ship. It's some really excellent content, implemented in a really hamfisted way.Despite all that, despite how much I hate this game for how dumb it is, I can't beat the appeal of cybershades and vibrosword arms. They really are the winning quality that makes this game worth coming back to. If you want to replay DXHR, buy this version of it. And then look up some good mods, it needs them. This game about augmentations needs some augmentation.

												A bit tough to review this since SquEnix is messing up Eidos Montreal's plans. This tiny review is done, whilst trying to ignore SquEnix's meddling. Eidos Montreal is a great dev studio, besides, most of the meddling was done to the newer title Mankind Divided and not as much with this one.I'll keep it simple:+ The commentary is excellent. Funny devs and great insight. + The reduction in the gold filter is not too bad. Still has that characteristic look the game is known for.- Seems buggier than the vanilla version. - Sometimes, the HUD goes off the bottom of the screen. - NPCs you knock unconcious with a Tranq Rifle or Stun Gun, die mysteriously. - Some of the difficult achievements do not get unlocked sometimes and are not yet fixed. - Adjusting FOV still looks weird, where the weapons get squeezed into a corner of the screen.Other than those technical issues, the game's still as great as the vanilla version. A modern stealth-FPS classic with RPG elements and great voice acting. Please buy it.Score:0451/10 would spill my drink again*edit 25-11-16 : updated review*

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 29, 2016
												I've just finished it and I'm left feeling it was decent, but nothing that special. I've always wanted to try the series and now that I have I'm not blown away by it, but I will pick up Mankind Divided once it's heavily discounted in the hope that some small improvements will bump my overall score up a notch.I'll start by saying the story itself was great, it was engaging and interesting throughout and the voice acting was really on point as well which helped sell it, the story was what kept me playing until the end. It's just a shame the lip syncing often fell out of sync during cutscenes.The gameplay just didn't match quality of the story for me, though, the AI was often quite brain-dead and just clunky, with obvious hard leashes which made tougher encounters easier as you could just run out the door, regain health and go in again. Swapping through weapons and items was clunky and slow, I would have happily spent an augment point on upgrading the speed I could switch weapons but I didn't see one (please tell me I didn't miss it), the cover system was quite awkward and often I'd try to lean out to shoot and the game just wouldn't let me for no apparent reason. One of my biggest complaints has to be the inventory though, I maxed it out but was still constantly full and unable to loot items, if items stacked, or stacked in higher quantities it would have eliminated this major annoyance. I get that they don't want you to carry around everything at once, but I felt it was overly restrictive to the point it hurt the gameplay.Technically the game fell somewhat as well, I mentioned earlier the lip sync issues, there was also a weird bug where the combat rifle had slight delay on its audio after pulling the trigger, apparently it's a common issue with Asus cards which I happen to have. I also suffered with a lot of stuttering, especially outside in open cities and once again the Steam forums are filled with complaints regarding this issue, which apparently was fixed in the non DC version, but not the DC which is bizarre to me. I will say I GREATLY reduced this by forcing the new Fast Sync technology using Nvidia Inspector, it eliminated almost all of the stuttering and removed all tearing all while having VSync off so the mouse didn't feel heavy, Fast Sync is incredible and I highly suggest you guys try it in place of VSync as you get all the benefits without the negatives.Overall it was a fantastic story let down by the core gameplay and mechanics which felt clunky and often became frustrating. I will say I'm not a massive fan of stealth games so I was probably playing it "wrong", often picking my silenced pistol over simply hiding and dodging enemies which often made the game harder (and it was surprisingly hard even on normal, you die so fast) but that didn't negatively impact my enjoyment of the game, other than some fairly large progress losses because the autosave system is quite stingy, I used F5 a lot more towards the end.6/10Nvidia users: Force the new Fast Sync technology, it makes the game much smoother. Download Nvidia Inspector and force the VSync bits to "0x18888888". You need the latest version of Nvidia Inspector and the latest Nvidia drivers for this to work. Fast Sync gives you all the benefits of VSync without the negatives like input delay and mouse heaviness, it's really great and made the game much more enjoyable for me.
